c.  A statement specifying the nature of the violation; 
d.  A description of the remedial measures necessary to bring the action or inaction into compliance with the permit, the stormwater management plan or this article and the date for the completion of such remedial action; 
e.  A statement of the penalty or penalties that may be assessed against the person to whom the notice of violation is directed; and, 
f.  A statement that the determination of violation may be appealed to the city building official or his designee by filing a written notice of appeal within 30 days after the notice of violation (except, that in the event the violation constitutes an immediate danger to public health or public safety, 24 hours notice shall be sufficient). 
(2)  Penalties. In the event the remedial measures described in the notice of violation have not been completed by the date set forth for such completion in the notice of violation, any one or more of the following actions or penalties may be taken or assessed against the person to whom the notice of violation was directed. Before taking any of the following actions or imposing any of the following penalties, the city building official or his designee shall first notify the applicant or other responsible person in writing of its intended action, and shall provide a reasonable opportunity, of not less than ten days (except, that in the event the violation constitutes an immediate danger to public health or public safety, 24 hours notice shall be sufficient) to cure such violation. In the event the applicant or other responsible person fails to cure such violation after such notice and cure period, the city building official or his designee may take any one or more of the following actions or impose any one or more of the following penalties. 
a.  Stop work order. The city building official or his designee may issue a stop work order which shall be served on the applicant or other responsible person. The stop work order shall remain in effect until the applicant or other responsible person has taken the remedial measures set forth in the notice of violation or has otherwise cured the violation or violations described therein, provided the stop work order may be withdrawn or modified to enable the applicant or other responsible person to take the necessary remedial measures to cure such violation or violations. 
b.  Withhold certificate of occupancy. The city building official or his designee may refuse to issue a certificate of occupancy for the building or other improvements constructed or being constructed on the site until the applicant or other responsible person has taken the remedial measures set forth in the notice of violation or has otherwise cured the violations described therein. 
c.  Suspension, revocation or modification of permit. The city building official or his designee may suspend, revoke or modify the permit authorizing the development project. A suspended, revoked or modified permit may be reinstated after the applicant or other responsible person has taken the remedial measures set forth in the notice of violation or has otherwise cured the violations described therein, provided such permit may be reinstated (upon such conditions as the city building official or his designee may deem necessary) to enable the applicant or other responsible person to take the necessary remedial measures to cure such violations. 
d.  Civil penalties. In the event the applicant or other responsible person fails to take the remedial measures set forth in the notice of violation or otherwise fails to cure the violations described therein within ten days, or such greater period as the city building official or his designee shall deem appropriate (except, that in the event the violation constitutes an immediate danger to public health or public safety, 24 hours notice shall be sufficient) after the city building official or his designee has taken one or more of the actions described above, the city building official or his designee may impose a penalty not to exceed $1,000.00 (depending on the severity of the violation) for each day the violation remains unremedied after receipt of the notice of violation. 
e.  Criminal penalties. For intentional and flagrant violations of this article, the city building official or his designee may issue a citation to the applicant or other responsible person, requiring such person to appear in municipal court to answer charges for such violation. Upon conviction, such person shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 or imprisonment for 60 days or both. Each act of violation and each day upon which any violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 05-11, § I, 3-22-05; Ord. No. 06-5, § I, 5-9-06) 
Chapter 11 - FIRE PROTECTION AND PREVENTION[1] 
  
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; emergency services, Ch. 9. 
State Law reference- Authority to provide police and fire protection, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3(1); state-wide application of Standard Fire Prevention Code, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25; The Uniform Act for the Application of Building and Fire Related Codes to Existing Buildings, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-200; providing of fire escapes by building owners, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-50; obstruction or hindering of firefighters, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-24.1; regulation of fire and other hazards to persons and property generally, O.C.G.A. § 25-2-1 et seq.; local fire departments generally, O.C.G.A. § 25-3-2 et seq.; authority to enact ordinances or fire and life safety codes, O.C.G.A. § 25-3-4; firefighter standards and training, O.C.G.A. § 25-4-2 et seq.; mutual aid resource pacts, O.C.G.A. § 25-6-1; Georgia Fire Academy Act, O.C.G.A. § 25-7-1 et seq.; regulation of fireworks, O.C.G.A. § 25-10-1 et seq.; electronic security systems installed and serviced by counties or municipal corporations, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-12. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 11-1. - Rules and regulations of state safety fire commissioner adopted. 
    The rules and regulations promulgated for the prevention of destruction of life and property by fire, explosion and related hazards in this state by the state safety fire commissioner, under authority of the powers vested in and duties imposed upon such commissioner by Acts of 1949, shall be and the same are hereby adopted as the rules and regulations of this city. 
(Code 1972, § 10-1) 
Sec. 11-2. - Fire chief designated local fire marshal. 
    The fire chief shall be and is hereby designated local fire marshal for the city. 
(Code 1972, § 10-2) 
Sec. 11-3. - Fires in streets and alleys. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to build a fire in the open air of any street or any public alley, unless a permit from the fire department shall first be obtained. 
(Code 1972, § 10-3) 
Sec. 11-4. - Fire on private property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to build any fire in the open air on any private lot without first having secured a permit from the fire department. The issuance of said permit shall be subject to the rules and regulations of the fire department. 
(Code 1972, § 10-4; Ord. No. 96-27, 12-12-96) 
Sec. 11-5. - Gasoline drums to be emptied and removed. 
    It shall be the duty of every person in this city, upon the receipt of gasoline, benzine, naphtha, or the lighter products of petroleum, to immediately store the same in tanks provided therefor, and it shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to empty the products immediately. It shall be the duty of every person who has emptied gasoline, benzine, naphtha, or the lighter products of petroleum, to immediately remove from his premises, or the streets and alleys of the city, the empty tanks, drums or cans in which the same was received. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to remove the tanks, drums or cans. 
(Code 1972, § 10-5) 
Sec. 11-6. - Inspection and correction of dangerous stovepipes and chimneys. 
    The fire marshal shall examine all dangerous stovepipes and chimneys in this city reported to him, order them made safe, and see that the order is complied with. It shall be unlawful for any owner or agent of such owner to refuse to comply with the order within a reasonable time. 
(Code 1972, § 10-6) 
Sec. 11-7. - Parking of trucks carrying gasoline. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any gasoline truck or any truck upon which there is a container containing or used for carrying gasoline on any street in the city, except that such truck may be parked temporarily for business purposes, and except in cases of emergency. When parked in emergency cases, it shall be the duty of the driver to place a danger signal to protect persons using such streets. 
(Code 1972, § 10-7) 
Sec. 11-8. - Following fire trucks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate an automobile, bicycle, motorcycle or any other vehicle in the city within 100 yards of any fire trucks or similar apparatus when such fire truck or similar apparatus are responding to a fire alarm. 
(Code 1972, § 10-8) 
Sec. 11-9. - Driving near scene of fire; driving over fire hose. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or drive a vehicle through the streets and alleys in which the fire department is assembled for the purpose of extinguishing a fire; or to ride or drive a vehicle over hose or other apparatus in the street while the fire department is parading or practicing, or while the same is being used to combat a fire. 
(Code 1972, § 10-9) 
Sec. 11-10. - Damaging fire apparatus. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully and knowingly injure or damage, in any way, or by any means whatever, any hose, hook, ladder, reel or vehicle, or any other implement, material or apparatus of any kind belonging to, connected with, or used by the fire department in this city, as a part of their machinery, material or equipment for extinguishing fires. 
(Code 1972, § 10-10) 
Sec. 11-11. - Use of whistles, sirens or signalling devices similar to those of fire department. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to use a gong, siren, whistle or signal device similar in kind to the siren, gong, whistle or signal device used by the fire department of the city, to signal the approach of fire apparatus; provided, however, that nothing contained in this section shall be construed to apply to such gongs or devices on any locomotive, engine, police patrol vehicle or ambulance. 
(Code 1972, § 10-11) 
Sec. 11-12. - False fire alarms. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to give or cause to be given a false alarm of fire with intent to deceive, or to ring the fire bell except in case of fire. 
(Code 1972, § 10-12) 
Sec. 11-13. - Obstructing fire hydrants. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct any fire hydrant in the city without first notifying the fire department in writing and obtaining the consent of the department. 
(Code 1972, § 10-13) 
Sec. 11-14. - Tampering with fire hydrants. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to open any fire hydrant or remove the nuts from the opening, or to have in his possession any wrench, with the intent or for the purpose of opening any fire hydrant. However, nothing in this section shall be so construed as to interfere with the water superintendent's inspecting and opening them in the discharge of his duties, or any firefighter under the direction of the chief of the fire department at a fire or parade, or at practice. 
(Code 1972, § 10-4) 
Sec. 11-15. - Persons prohibited in vicinity of fire. 
    It shall not be lawful for any person except firefighters, the mayor and councilmen, police officers, the owners of property, their agents, and the agents of insurance companies, to go within the immediate vicinity of any fire, without being ordered there by the officer in command of the fire department. 
(Code 1972, § 10-15) 
Sec. 11-16. - Arrest of thieves at fire. 
    The officer in command of the fire department at a fire shall arrest or cause to be arrested by the police of the city, any person who shall be caught stealing goods or other articles of value from any store or other house at or in the vicinity of the fire. 
(Code 1972, § 10-16) 
Sec. 11-17. - Fire trucks answering calls outside city. 
    City fire trucks shall not answer calls outside the city limits, except calls by churches and schools. 
(Code 1972, § 10-17) 
Sec. 11-18. - Storage of gasoline at stations restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to store gasoline at a gas station or service station if the station is unattended for a period of seven days or longer. 
(Code 1972, § 10-18) 
Sec. 11-19. - Hazardous materials; charges for cost of clean-up to responsible party. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term: 
(1)  Discharge means leakage, seepage, or other release of hazardous materials on land or into a river, stream, lake, pond, sewer, or into the air; 
(2)  Hazardous materials means any material which because of its quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical, or infectious characteristics may: 
a.  Cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness; or 
b.  Pose a substantial threat or potential hazard to human health or to the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, disposed of, or otherwise managed. 
(b)  In the even of any discharge of any hazardous materials which results from the transportation, storage, holding, detention, delivery for transportation, or acceptance of hazardous materials in the city, the person, firm, or corporation responsible for the discharge of hazardous materials shall remedy the effects of such discharge at no cost to the city. When deemed necessary by the fire chief, the city may take action necessary to prevent, abate, or remove such hazardous materials. In such an event, the city may recover from any shipper, carrier, bailor, bailee, or any person responsible for such storage, transportation, holding, detention, delivery, or acceptance all costs incurred by the city in the prevention, abatement, or removal of any such discharge or threatened discharge, including reasonable attorneys' fees incurred with respect to recovery. 
(Ord. No. 98-42, § 1, 7-21-98) 
Secs. 11-20-11-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, adopted June 11, 2002, amended the Code by repealing former art. II, §§ 11-31-11-37, and adding a new art. II. Former art. II pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the Code of 1972, §§ 10-31-10-36; Ord. No. 9-93, adopted March 22, 1993; Ord. No. 95-32, adopted November 28, 1995; and Ord. No. 00-27, adopted September 12, 2000. 

Sec. 11-31. - Fire prevention code. 
    There is hereby adopted by the city council of the city, that certain code known as the "Standard Fire Prevention Code" being the 2000 Edition, and the Georgia State Amendments revised January 1, 2002, except that Chapter 1 shall not be deleted, and the whole thereof, save and except such portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified, or amended in section 11-47, and is hereby incorporated by reference as fully as if set out at length herein and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the incorporated area of the city. Not less than one copy of the Standard Fire Prevention Code is filed at city hall in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-32. - Adoption of state code. 
    In addition to above referenced Standard Fire Prevention Code, there is hereby adopted by the city council the state minimum fire safety standards as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 25-2-12 and all subsequent revisions thereof. This code is hereby incorporated by reference as fully as if set out at length herein and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the incorporated area of the city. Furthermore, it is hereby resolved that pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 25-2-12(b), the city will enforce the minimum fire safety standards as set forth in subsection 25-2-12(a). 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-33. - Position of city manager 
    The city manager or his designee of the city fire department shall be responsible for the direct administration and enforcement of the city Standard Fire Prevention Code, this chapter and other fire prevention and protection rules, regulations and ordinances. The city manager or his designee may appoint qualified members of the fire department/building department as inspectors as shall from time to time be necessary. The city manager or his designee of the city fire department may also designate such number of inspectors as shall from time to time be authorized by the city. When used hereinafter in this chapter, the term "fire marshal" shall include the city manager and the lawful designees. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-34. - Violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate this chapter, to permit or maintain such a violation, to refuse to obey any provision thereof, or to fail or refuse to comply with any such provision or regulation. Proof of such unlawful act or failure shall be deemed prima facie evidence that such act is that of the owner or other person in control of the premises. Prosecution or lack thereof of either the owner, occupant, or the person in charge shall not be deemed to relieve any of the others. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-35. - Applicability of provisions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply equally to both public and private property, and it shall apply to all structures and their occupancies, except as otherwise specified. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-36. - Exercise of police power. 
    This act shall be deemed an exercise of the police powers of the city for the preservation and protection of the public health, peace, safety, and welfare, and all the provisions of this chapter shall be liberally construed for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-37. - Submission of plans and specifications required. 
    Owners, their agents or designees, of all buildings and tenant spaces covered by this chapter are required to submit plans and specifications of the project to the building official or his designee. The building official or his designee shall forward all plans to the fire marshal's office for approval prior to construction. A final inspection and letter of compliance must be obtained from the fire marshal prior to occupation or conducting of business. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-38. - Duties of fire marshal. 
    It shall be the duty of the fire marshal (which shall be a concurrent duty of the police department of the city) in addition to the general duties of section 11-32, to enforce all laws and ordinances of the city covering the following: 
(1)  The prevention of fires; 
(2)  The storage, sale and use of combustible, flammable or explosive material. 
(3)  The installation and maintenance of automobile and other fire alarm systems, and fire extinguishing equipment. 
(4)  The maintenance and regulations of fire escapes. 
(5)  The means and adequacy of exit in case of fire, from factories, schools, hotels, lodging houses, asylums, hospitals, churches, halls, theaters, amphitheaters, and all places in which numbers of persons work, live or congregate, from time to time, for any purpose. 
(6)  The investigation of the cause, origin, and circumstances of fires. 
(7)  The establishment of fire lanes. 
(8)  Fire safety, fire prevention, and fire protection. 
    The fire marshal shall investigate the cause, origin and circumstances of every fire occurring in the city, by which property has been destroyed or damaged and, as far as possible, shall determine whether the fire is the result of carelessness or design. Such investigations shall begin immediately upon the occurrence of such a fire, and if design is suspected, the fire marshal shall take charge immediately of the physical evidence and cause a complete investigation to be initiated to include prosecution. Every fire shall be reported in writing with the fire department as soon as possible after the occurrence of an investigated fire. Such reports shall be in such form as shall be prescribed by the fire marshal and shall contain a statement of all facts relating to the cause, origin, and circumstances of such fire, the extent of the damage thereof, and the insurance upon such property and such information as may be required, including the injury, death or rescue of persons. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-39. - Powers of fire marshal. 
    The fire marshal or his designees and fire inspectors are hereby vested with the powers of police officers while acting in their fire department capacity, and are authorized to issue citations for violations of the Standard Fire Prevention Code, this chapter, rules and regulations, or other fire protection ordinances enacted by the city. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-40. - Fire prevention scope. 
    The provisions of the Standard Fire Prevention Code, this chapter, rules and regulations and other fire protection ordinances of the city, shall apply equally to both public and private property, and it shall apply to all structures and their occupancies, except as otherwise specified. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-41. - Inspections. 
(a)  The fire marshal or his assistants and inspectors shall inspect or cause to be inspected all premises on a periodic basis for compliance with the Standard Fire Protection Code, this chapter, rules and regulations and other fire protection ordinances of the city, and shall make such orders as may be necessary for the enforcement of the laws and ordinances governing the same. 
(b)  Additionally, upon complaint submitted in writing alleging a failure to comply with the Standard Fire Prevention Code, this chapter, and fire related rules, regulations and ordinances, the fire marshal or assistants or inspectors may enter in or upon any building or premises complained of for the purpose of investigating the complaint. 
(c)  Additionally, if the fire marshal or assistants or inspectors has been deputized by the state safety fire commissioner pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 25-2-12.1, then that person is further authorized to seek inspection warrants against non-cooperating parties pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 25-2-22.1. Inspection warrants may be issued by any judge of the superior, state, municipal or magistrate court upon proper oath or affirmation showing probable cause. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-42. - Order to remove fire hazard. 
    Whenever the fire marshal or inspector, shall find in any building or upon any premises or other places, combustible or explosive matter or dangerous accumulations of rubbish or unnecessary accumulation of waste paper, boxes, shavings, or any highly flammable material especially liable of fire, and which is so situated as to endanger property, or shall find obstructions to or on fire escapes, stairs, passageways, door or windows, liable to interfere with the operations of the fire department or egress of occupants in case of fire, the fire marshal or inspector shall order the same to be removed or remedied, and such order shall forthwith be complied with by the owner or occupant of such premises or buildings, subject to the appeals procedure provided for in this chapter. Any owner or occupant failing to comply with such order within a reasonable period after the service of the said order shall be liable to penalties as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-43. - Service of order to remove hazard. 
    The service of any such order may be made upon the occupant or owner of the premises to whom it is directed, either by delivering a copy of same to such occupant or owner personally, or leaving it with any person in charge of the premises, or in case no such person is found upon the premises, by affixing a copy thereof in a conspicuous place on the door to the entrance of said premises, such order may be served either by delivering to and leaving with said person a copy of the order, or, if such owner is absent from the jurisdiction of the officer making the order, by mailing such copy by certified mail to the owner's last known address. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-44. - Penalties for violations. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the Standard Fire Prevention Code, this chapter, or other fire-related ordinance or rule or regulations, or shall fail to comply therewith, or shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder, or shall build in violation of any details, statements, specifications, or plans submitted or approved thereunder, or shall operate not in accordance with the provisions of any certificate, permit, or approval issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or shall fail to comply with such order as affirmed or modified by the city council or by a court of competent jurisdiction within the time fixed herein shall severally for each and every violation and noncompliance, respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of up to $1,000.00 and/or by imprisonment for not more than 30 days or by both such fines and imprisonment. The imposition of a penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation nor excuse required correction or remedy of such violations or defects within a reasonable time, and when not otherwise specified, the application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-45. - Permits. 
    In accordance with requirements as detailed in chapter 4 of the Standard Fire Prevention Code, a permit shall be obtained from the fire marshal to conduct certain operations described therein or to store, handle, or use those processes described therein that are considered to present an extra or unusual fire hazard to life or property. 
    Before permits may be issued, the fire marshal or assistants and inspectors shall inspect and approve the receptacles, processes, vehicles, buildings, storage places or sites to be used for any such purposes. A $10.00 processing fee to cover administrating cost shall be imposed upon each permit application. The cost of each permit shall be $25.00 as set forth in the city fee schedules. No processing fee or permit fee shall be required for the reduction of leaves and any other organic material by the owner or person in control of a residential occupied property, provided that such property meets the requirements otherwise set forth in this chapter. The city shall revoke, or suspend an individual's or entity's business license for violation of this section. Violation of this section shall be punished by a fine of up to $1,000.00 and/or imprisonment of up to 30 days. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-46. - Building numbering and identification for emergency response. 
    Each one-, two- and multi-family (three or more dwellings units) and each commercial and industrial building or structure shall have posted and maintained in a conspicuous place on the property, visible from the street providing general, public access, the address of such dwelling unit building or structure as required in the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-47. - Outdoor burning. 
    No open burning shall be conducted in violation of Georgia Department of Natural Resources Environmental Protection Division Regulations, Chapter 391-3-1, as revised. In addition to any environmental protection division authorizations which may be required, no open burning shall take place in the city except as otherwise provided herein without a permit issued by the fire marshal or his designee, and in full compliance with any conditions imposed by the fire marshal. The fire marshal may prohibit any or all burning when local conditions make such fires hazardous. Failure to obtain a permit and keep such permit at the site or follow the fire marshal's requirements set forth for the permit will result in revocation of the permit and/or a fine up to $1,000.00 for each and every occurrence. 
    Permits shall not be required for the following: 
(1)  Outdoor cooking of food for immediate human consumption is allowed. 
(2)  Small outdoor fires using untreated wood are allowed to keep persons warm for working outdoors. 
(3)  Fires set for the purpose of fire fighting training are allowed. 
    The burning of tires, asphaltic materials, heavy oils, petroleum based products, rubber or plastic products, pressure treated wood and household garbage is prohibited under all circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-48. - Fire prevention code, amendments and changes. 
    The Standard Fire Prevention Code of the Southern Building Code Congress International, Inc. is amended and changed in the following respect: 
(1)  Amend chapter 1 of the Fire Prevention Code by adding a new section 105.8 as follows: 
Sec. 105.8 Appeals. Whenever the Fire Marshal shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a permit when applied for, or when it is claimed the provisions of the Standard Fire prevention Code, this chapter, or other City fire-related rules, regulations, or ordinances do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the same has been misconstrued or improperly applied, claimant may appeal the decisions to the City Council of the City of Newnan, Georgia, within 30 days from the date of decision. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-49. - Fire lanes. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or stand a vehicle within a designated fire lane. 
(b)  A fire lane shall be the 20-foot traffic lane closest to buildings and other structures unless otherwise designated. The police chief or the fire marshal shall be authorized to designate fire lanes within the city by posting of signs or by markings upon the pavement or roadway, so designating the fire lanes, or by requiring the owner of the property to so designate the fire lane. 
(c)  This section shall be enforced by any police officer of the city. Citations for violations shall be issued by such officers. 
(d)  Any person, corporation, partnership or other entity violating this section shall be tried before the municipal court of the city. Upon conviction, a violation of this article shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 and/or by imprisonment of up to one year. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 6-11-02) 
Secs. 11-50-11-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 02-11, adopted June 11, 2002, amended the Code by renumbering former §§ 11-47-11-56 as new §§ 11-60-11-69. 

Sec. 11-60. - Establishment; composition; appointment of chief. 
    There is hereby created and established a fire department for the city consisting of the fire chief, who shall be director of the department, and such other members as may be provided for by the council. The chief shall be appointed in accordance with charter provisions of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 10-47; Ord. No. 02-11, § 2, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-61. - Chief to have control of department and apparatus; members subject to orders of chief. 
    The fire chief shall have the control, subject to the order and direction of the city manager, of the fire department and all fire apparatus belonging to the city. Whenever any fire apparatus needs repairing, the fire chief shall cause the same to be done without delay. All persons who are members of the department shall serve subject to the orders of the chief of the fire department. 
(Code 1972, § 10-48; Ord. No. 02-11, § 2, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-62. - Command at fires; removal of buildings to prevent spread of fire. 
    In case of fire, the fire chief and his assistants shall rank in the order named, and the officer of the highest rank at the fire shall take command of the fire department and direct the management thereof for the suppression of the fire, in the best manner possible. When it may be necessary for the protection of other property and to prevent the spread of the conflagration, the officer in command may cause buildings to be removed, torn down or destroyed in the best manner possible. 
(Code 1972, § 10-49; Ord. No. 02-11, § 2, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-63. - Records and reports. 
    The fire chief shall keep or cause to be kept such records and make such reports, concerning the activities of his department as may be required by statute or as may be required by the city manager. 
(Code 1972, § 10-50; Ord. No. 02-11, § 2, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-64. - General duties. 
    It shall be the function and duty of the fire department and every member thereof to extinguish accidental or destructive fires, to prevent the occurrence or spread of such fires, to promote safety from fires and to patrol the central business district nightly. The inspector shall inspect all business premises on a regular basis and note any fire hazards and have same corrected immediately. 
(Code 1972, § 10-51; Ord. No. 02-11, § 2, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-65. - Enforcement of article. 
    It shall be the duty of all officers of the fire department and all police officers of the city to see that the provisions of this article are enforced and to arrest on view any person who shall be found violating any of the provisions of this article or who shall hinder, resist, or refuse to obey any such officer in the discharge of his duty, and to that end all such officers are hereby vested with the usual power and authority of police officers. 
(Code 1972, § 10-52; Ord. No. 02-11, § 2, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-66. - Investigation of fires. 
    The fire marshal shall investigate the causes of all extended or destruction fires occurring within the city. 
(Code 1972, § 10-53; Ord. No. 02-11, § 2, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-67. - Conduct of members. 
    It shall be the duty of every member of the fire department to conduct himself in a proper and law-abiding manner. 
(Code 1972, § 10-54; Ord. No. 02-11, § 2, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-68. - Rules and regulations of chief. 
    The chief of the fire department may make or describe such rules and regulations for the guidance of the members of the department as he shall see fit. Such rules, when approved by the city manager, shall be binding on such members. 
(Code 1972, § 10-55; Ord. No. 02-11, § 2, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 11-69. - Qualifications of members. 
(a)  Each person employed as a member of the fire department shall possess the following qualifications: 
(1)  Be at least 21 years of age. 
(2)  Be a graduate of an accredited high school or have obtained a G.E.D. 
(3)  Pass a physical exam by a physician. 
(4)  Possess a valid state driver's license. 
(5)  Pass intensive background investigation. 
(b)  In addition to the above qualifications the person employed by the department shall: 
(1)  Successfully complete entry level written examination. 
(2)  Successfully complete physical agility test. 
(3)  Pass oral examination by board composed of officer of department as constituted by the chief of fire department. 
(Code 1972, § 10-56; Ord. No. 02-11, § 2, 6-11-02) 
Chapter 12 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of municipal court to try and punish all violations of city ordinances, § 4.4. 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; animals, Ch. 4; emergency services, Ch. 9; environment, Ch. 10; municipal court, Ch. 13; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 14; traffic and vehicles, Ch. 20; vehicles for hire, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Authority to exercise police power, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3(a)(1); law enforcement officer appreciation day, O.C.G.A. § 1-4-6; peace officer memorial day; police week, O.C.G.A. § 1-4-7; Georgia Peace Officer Standards and Training Act, O.C.G.A. § 35-8-1 et seq.; training requirements for police chiefs, O.C.G.A. § 35-8-20; special policemen, O.C.G.A. § 35-9-1; torts of police or other officers, O.C.G.A. § 36-33-3; definition of police officer, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1; impersonating law enforcement officer, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-395. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 12-1-12-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-26. - Composition; appointment of chief. 
    The police department shall consist of the chief of police and such other members and officers as may be provided for from time to time by the city council. 
(Code 1972, § 21-1) 
Sec. 12-27. - General duties of members. 
    It shall be the duty of the members of the police department to see to the enforcement of all ordinances of the city and all statutes effective in the city, and to preserve order and prevent infractions of the law and to arrest any person violating such laws. 
(Code 1972, § 21-2) 
Sec. 12-28. - Conduct of members. 
    It shall be the duty of every member of the police department to conduct himself in a proper and law abiding manner, and to avoid the use of unnecessary force. 
(Code 1972, § 21-6) 
Sec. 12-29. - Duty of member to appear as witness. 
    Every member of the department shall appear as a witness whenever this is necessary in a prosecution for a violation of a city ordinance or of a state or federal law. 
(Code 1972, § 21-7) 
Sec. 12-30. - Qualifications of officers. 
    Each person employed as a police officer shall meet the following requirements. 
(1)  Be at least 20 years of age; 
(2)  Be a citizen of the United States; 
(3)  Have a high school diploma or its recognized equivalent; 
(4)  Not have been convicted by any state or by the federal government of any crime the punishment for which could have been imprisonment in the federal or state prison or institution nor have been convicted or sufficient misdemeanors to establish a pattern of disregard for the law; provided that, for purposes of this subsection, violations of traffic laws and other offenses involving the operation of motor vehicles when the applicant has received a pardon shall not be considered; 
(5)  Be fingerprinted and a search made of local, state and national fingerprint files to disclose any criminal record; 
(6)  Possess good moral character as determined by investigation under procedure established by the council; 
(7)  Have an oral interview with the hiring authority or its representative to determine the applicant's appearance, background, and ability to communicate; 
(8)  Be found, after examination by a licensed physician or surgeon, to be free from any physical, emotional, or mental conditions which might adversely affect his exercising the powers or duties of a peace officer; and 
(9)  Within six months after appointment, attend and pass a course at the state police academy to be a certified police officer. 
(Code 1972, § 21-9) 
Secs. 12-31-12-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CHIEF OF POLICE 

Sec. 12-46. - Appointment. 
    The chief of police shall be appointed in accordance with charter provisions of the city and shall be the head of the police department. 
(Code 1972, § 21-1) 
Sec. 12-47. - Bond. 
    The chief of police shall be bonded at the city's expense in the amount of $25,000.00. 
(Code 1972, § 21-10) 
Sec. 12-48. - General powers and duties. 
    The chief of police shall have jurisdiction over the operations of the department. He shall in addition be the keeper of the city jail, and shall have custody of all persons incarcerated therein. He shall keep such records and make such reports, concerning the activities of his department as may be required by statute or ordinance or as may be required by the city manager. The chief shall be responsible for the performance by the police department of all its functions, and all persons who are members of the department shall serve subject to the orders of the chief of police. 
(Code 1972, § 21-3) 
Sec. 12-49. - Rules and regulations. 
    The chief of police may make or prescribe such rules and regulations for the guidance of the members of the department as he shall see fit. Such rules, when approved by the city manager, shall be binding on such members. 
(Code 1972, § 21-8) 
Sec. 12-50. - Custodian of lost, abandoned, stolen property. 
    The chief of police shall be custodian of all lost, abandoned or recovered stolen property in the city. 
(Code 1972, § 21-4) 
Sec. 12-51. - Process serving. 
    The chief of police shall be authorized to serve writs, summons, and other processes, but no patrolman shall serve any such summons or process except on the order of the chief of police. 
(Code 1972, § 21-5) 
Chapter 13 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 
  
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Municipal court, § 4.1 et seq. 
Cross reference- Law enforcement, Ch. 12; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 14; traffic and vehicles, Ch. 20. 
State Law reference- Establishment and jurisdiction of municipal courts, Ga. Const. art. 6, sec. 1, par. 1; municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Establishment, function. 
    There shall be a municipal court in the city, named the Municipal Court of the City of Newnan, for the trial of offenders against the laws and ordinances thereof as well as those laws of the state, which court is specifically authorized to try and to punish for a violation of same. 
(Code 1972, § 23-1) 
Sec. 13-2. - Location and frequency of sessions. 
    The municipal court shall be held in the courtroom of the police department as often as necessary. 
(Code 1972, § 23-2) 
Sec. 13-3. - Powers enumerated. 
    The municipal court shall have the following powers: 
(1)  Conduct hearings. To hear and determine all causes of prosecution for violating the penal laws and ordinances of the city and all other controversies arising under the laws and ordinances of this city. 
(2)  Subpoena power. To compel the attendance of parties and witnesses and compel the production of papers. 
(3)  Issuance of process. To issue all processes and writs necessary to the exercise of its jurisdiction. 
(4)  Punish for contempt. To punish contempt by fine or imprisonment, or both. 
(5)  Appoint officers. To appoint such special officers as may be necessary in the absence of the chief of police to execute its writs and processes including the designation of warrant clerks. 
(6)  Prescribe rules. To prescribe rules of practice in cases where there are no rules applicable. 
(7)  Conduct sessions. To sit at such times as it may appoint for hearing cases. 
(8)  Authority as to violations of state law. To bind over or commit to jail offenders against any criminal laws of this state, whenever in the course of investigation before such officer a proper case therefor shall be made out by the evidence. 
(9)  Other powers. To exercise such other powers as are necessary in the matters of its jurisdiction, or as may be conferred on it by law or ordinance, including the same powers and authorities as magistrates in the matter of and pertaining to criminal cases of whatever nature in the several courts of this state. 
(Code 1972, § 23-3) 
Sec. 13-4. - Motions, appearances and notice to city attorney. 
    All motions and notices of appearance by defense counsel, who intend on proceeding with a bench trial, shall be made, in writing, before time of arraignment, with a copy provided to the city attorney. All such motions and bench trials in which defendants are represented by counsel shall be heard and considered at such time, date and place as set by the presiding judge. Generally, such motions and bench trials will be heard during regular court sessions; however, in order to accommodate the presiding judge, defense counsel, the city attorney, witnesses and parties to other cases, motions or bench trials involving unusual or complicated legal or factual issues may be specifically set, in the court's discretion. 
Sec. 13-5. - Arguments of counsel; rules of evidence. 
    The city attorney, or anyone representing the city, shall have the opening and conclusion in each case, unless the defendant introduces no evidence, in which case the defendant shall be entitled to the opening and conclusion of the argument. The defendant shall announce first if he is ready for trial. The rules of evidence shall be the same as in the superior court, as far as applicable, to the case on trial. 
(Code 1972, § 23-4) 
Sec. 13-6. - Failure to appear for trial. 
    If any person shall fail, refuse or neglect to appear for trial, after arrest and notice of the time of trial, or to render a satisfactory excuse or showing for such failure, neglect or refusal to appear and answer the charge specified, he may be punished for contempt as prescribed, and the case shall be continued until such time as the court may direct. It shall be the duty of the police of the city to arrest the offender, when so ordered by the presiding officer of the court, and keep him in custody until he is brought before the court for trial. 
(Code 1972, § 23-5) 
Sec. 13-7. - Preservation of order, compelling attendance of witnesses; punishment for contempt. 
    The court shall have the power to preserve order and compel attendance of witnesses, punish for contempt by imprisonment or fine as prescribed, one or both. 
(Code 1972, § 23-6) 
Sec. 13-8. - Service of subpoenas for witnesses. 
    Subpoenas for witnesses may be served at any time before the time for appearance of the witness. 
(Code 1972, § 23-7) 
Sec. 13-9. - Service of subpoenas duces tecum. 
    Subpoenas duces tecum shall be served at the latest on the day before the papers are to be produced. 
(Code 1972, § 23-8) 
Sec. 13-10. - Right to examine witnesses separately. 
    In all cases before the court, either party has the right to have the witnesses of the other party examined out of hearing of each other. The court shall, upon motion of either party, take proper care to effect this object as far as practical and convenient, but any mere irregularity, or a failure of the witness to obey the order of the court, shall not prevent the witness from testifying. 
(Code 1972, § 23-9) 
Sec. 13-11. - Preventing witnesses from attending court; intimidating witnesses. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent or attempt to prevent the attendance of any witness, or to intimidate any witness at or subpoenaed to attend the court, by threat, menace, persuasion or any other means. 
(Code 1972, § 23-10) 
Sec. 13-12. - Bonding of witnesses. 
    The presiding officer shall have authority to order any witness, either for the city or the defendant, to be put under bond in an amount determined by the presiding officer of the court, for his appearance at the trial of any case in which he is subpoenaed as witness. Upon failure of the witness to give bond, he shall be committed until the day or hour of trial. 
(Code 1972, § 23-11) 
Sec. 13-13. - Imposition of costs of prosecution upon prosecutor. 
    Costs of prosecution shall not be chargeable to the prosecutor, unless the court trying the same shall find the prosecution malicious and without probable cause, in which event the prosecutor shall pay the costs instanter, under penalty of punishment for contempt. 
(Code 1972, § 23-12) 
Sec. 13-14. - Continuances of proceedings. 
    When the ends of justice require it, all cases may be continued. All continuances shall be addressed to the sound discretion of the court under the rules governing continuances in the superior court of the state. 
(Code 1972, § 23-13) 
Sec. 13-15. - Judgment to be in writing, signed and recorded. 
    Upon the trial of any case, judgment of the court shall be in writing, signed by the presiding officer of the court trying the same, and recorded upon the minutes. 
(Code 1972, § 23-14) 
Sec. 13-16. - Form of judgment. 
    The form of judgments against offenders may be substantially as follows: 
Upon hearing the evidence in this case, it is the judgment of the court that the defendant is guilty and the defendant is sentenced to confinement in the Newnan City Jail for a period of ____________ days. Upon payment of a fine of $;$rule;, said defendant may be discharged. This ____________ day of ____________ , 19 ____________ . 
_____
Judge of Municipal Court of Newnan  
Amount of fine paid $;$rule;. 
(Code 1972, § 23-15) 
Sec. 13-17. - Imposition of sentences. 
(a)  The court shall have authority to try offenses against the laws of the city, and shall have power to impose fines and/or sentences of imprisonment. A suspended sentence shall be interpreted to mean that the defendant, during the term of the sentence, shall not again violate the law. 
(b)  The court shall have the authority to impose alternative forms of punishment allowed by law in case such fines are not paid. 
(c)  The court shall have the authority to impose a sentence of community service. 
(d)  The court shall have the authority to impose a sentence consisting of any combination of the penalties provided for in this section. 
(Code 1972, § 23-16) 
Sec. 13-18. - Execution to collect fine. 
    On failure of any person upon whom a fine is imposed to pay the same, the presiding officer of the court may execute orders to collect the unpaid fine, although such person be imprisoned in default of paying such fine. 
(Code 1972, § 23-17) 
Sec. 13-19. - Executions; direction, return. 
    All executions issued by authority of the city shall be directed to the chief of police, bear test in the name of the presiding officer of the court and be returnable to a regular meeting of the board, except executions to collect forfeiture recognizances, which shall be directed to all sheriffs, coroners, constables and marshals of this state, and may be executed by any of the officers. 
(Code 1972, § 23-18) 
Sec. 13-20. - Certiorari from municipal court. 
    Parties dissatisfied with the decision in the municipal court may petition for a writ of certiorari to the superior court as provided by law. 
(Code 1972, § 23-19) 
Sec. 13-21. - Limitation of prosecution for violation of city ordinance. 
    All prosecutions for violations of city ordinances shall be commenced within two years after such violations, and any offense against such ordinances for which no prosecution is begun within two years shall be barred, and no person shall be tried therefor, unless the party shall have been beyond the limits of the city, in which case the time of absence from the city shall not be embraced or computed as within two years. 
(Code 1972, § 23-20) 
Sec. 13-22. - Authority to permit prisoners to spend time at home. 
    Upon the application of any person serving a sentence in the city and by permission of the presiding officer of the court, when such person is not actually at work, the person shall be allowed to spend the time at home or place of abode; however, the release of the prisoner for such purpose shall in no instance operate to discharge him from serving the full term of imprisonment imposed upon him by the sentence of the court. 
(Code 1972, § 23-21) 
Secs. 13-23-13-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CHIEF JUDGE 

Sec. 13-41. - Office created. 
    The office of chief judge of the city is hereby created. 
(Code 1972, § 23-32) 
Sec. 13-42. - Selection; term. 
    Annually at their first regularly scheduled meeting in January, the city council shall elect a chief judge for the city, who shall hold the office for one year, unless sooner removed and until a successor is elected and qualified. 
(Code 1972, § 23-33) 
Sec. 13-43. - Compensation. 
    The compensation of the chief judge shall be prescribed by the city council each year at the beginning of the term of service or as soon thereafter as practicable, which compensation shall not be changed except at the beginning of a year. 
(Code 1972, § 23-34) 
Secs. 13-44-13-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ASSOCIATE JUDGES 

Sec. 13-61. - Office established; selection, term. 
    There is hereby established an office of associate judge who shall be elected by the city council and shall hold office at the pleasure of the city council. 
(Code 1972, § 23-38) 
Sec. 13-62. - Jurisdiction. 
    The associate judges shall have jurisdiction to issue summons, subpoenas, arrest warrants and search warrants in all cases arising under the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city; shall preside over the municipal court when requested to do so by the chief judge; and shall have all powers and be able to perform any duty designated by this section to be performed by the chief judge. 
(Code 1972, § 23-40) 
Secs. 13-63-13-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - QUALIFICATIONS 

Sec. 13-81. - Qualifications. 
    No person shall be qualified or eligible to serve as judge of the municipal court unless that person is at least 21 years old. The chief judge shall be a member of the State Bar of Georgia. 
Sec. 13-82. - Oath. 
    Before taking on any duties of office, each judge shall take an oath to be administered by the mayor and shall promise to discharge honestly and faithfully the duties of office without fear, favor or partiality. The oath shall be entered upon the minutes of the city council. 
(Code 1972, § 23-39) 
Chapter 14 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Municipal court to try and punish all violations of city ordinances, § 4.4. 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; dangerous dog control, § 4-66 et seq.; violation of building regulations, § 5-6; emergency services, Ch. 9; nuisances, § 10-26 et seq.; law enforcement, Ch. 12; municipal court, Ch. 13; littering, § 17-36 et seq.; traffic and vehicles, Ch. 20. 
State Law reference- Limitations on home rule powers of municipal corporations, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2); Criminal Code of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 16-1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Misdemeanors under state law. 
    Any act the commission of which constitutes a misdemeanor under the laws of the state is prohibited within the city, and if committed within the city is hereby declared to be an offense; provided, however, that the penalty therefor shall not exceed the penalty prescribed in section 1-14 of this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 16-12) 
State Law reference- Criminal Code of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 16-1-1 et seq. 
Sec. 14-2. - Conspiracy. 
    It shall be unlawful for any two or more persons in this city to conspire to do any act which is contrary to the laws or ordinances of this city. They may be jointly or severally prosecuted. 
(Code 1972, § 16-3) 
State Law reference- Conspiring, O.C.G.A. § 16-4-8. 
Sec. 14-3. - Refusing to pay for lodging or food at hotel or restaurant. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, without contracting for credit therefor, to board or lodge at a hotel or similar establishment, or eat at an eating house or similar establishment and then to refuse or fail to pay for the same. 
(Code 1972, § 16-2) 
State Law reference- Affray, O.C.G.A. § 16-8-5. 
Sec. 14-4. - False pretenses. 
(a)  Generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to attempt to obtain or to obtain entrance into any residence or place of lodging in the city by false representation or pretense, or by impersonating another, or by representing himself to be the representative of a person whom he does not represent. 
(b)  Obtaining lodging under false representation of being man and wife. It shall be unlawful for any persons to obtain lodging in this city, by representing themselves to be man and wife, when in fact they are not legally married. 
(Code 1972, § 16-7) 
State Law reference- Theft of services, O.C.G.A. § 16-8-5; deceptive practices, O.C.G.A. § 43-21-61. 
Sec. 14-5. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-20, adopted Oct. 9, 2012, repealed § 14-5, which pertained to distribution of handbills, circulars and similar matter and derived from Code 1972, § 16-8. 
Sec. 14-6. - Interference with another's business. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter upon the premises of another in the city for the purpose of interfering with the business of such person or to interfere directly or indirectly with the business of any person. 
(Code 1972, § 16-9) 
Sec. 14-7. - Interference with another's work. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent or restrain or attempt to prevent or restrain another from going to or from his work or place of work, or to prevent or restrain, or to attempt to prevent or restrain, any person from remaining at his work or place of work. 
(Code 1972, § 16-10) 
Sec. 14-8. - Soliciting. 
    Soliciting shall be prohibited in the business zone. In residential zones, the same shall be allowed only upon permit issued by the chief of police. 
(Code 1972, § 16-16) 
Sec. 14-9. - Impersonating police officer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in this city, not being a police officer, to assume to be, or act as such, or represent himself, as such police officer. 
(Code 1972, § 16-21) 
State Law reference- Impersonating public officer, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-23. 
Sec. 14-10. - Interfering with police. 
    When any police officer in this city shall have any party under arrest it shall be unlawful for any person to approach or stay within 30 feet of such arresting officer after being warned by him not to do so. 
(Code 1972, § 16-22) 
State Law reference- Obstructing law enforcement officers, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-24. 
Sec. 14-11. - Resisting, interfering with officers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to resist, obstruct or oppose or in any manner to interfere with a police officer or any other officer or employee of the city in the discharge of such officer's or employee's official duty. 
(Code 1972, § 16-23) 
Sec. 14-12. - Curfew. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any minor under 16 years of age to loiter, wander, stroll or play in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots or any place unsupervised by an adult having the lawful authority to be at such places, between the hours of 12:00 midnight on any day and 6:00 a.m. of the following day; and provided, that the provisions of this section shall not apply in the following instances: 
(1)  When a minor is accompanied by his parent, guardian or other adult person having the lawful care and custody of the minor; 
(2)  When the minor is upon an emergency errand directed by his or her parent or guardian or other adult person having the lawful care and custody of such minor; 
(3)  When the minor is returning directly home from a school activity, entertainment, recreational activity or dance; 
(4)  When the minor is returning directly home from lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in the above referenced places during the prescribed period of time; and 
(5)  When the minor is attending or traveling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of first amendment rights of free speech, freedom of assembly or free exercise of religion. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian, or other person having custody or control of any child under 16 years of age to permit, or by insufficient control, to allow, such child to be in or upon the public streets or any other places between the hours of 12:00 midnight on any day and 6:00 a.m. the following day, except in circumstances set out in subsections (a)(1) through (a)(5) of this section. Upon conviction of a violation of this section for the first time, a person shall be given a warning citation. Upon further convictions, a person shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 and costs, or imprisonment in the city jail for not more than 60 days, or work on the city streets or work on the public works of the city for not more than 60 days, or be subject to any one or more of the within punishments. Each violation of this shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  Institution of an extended curfew. 
(1)  When imposed: Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the governor, or upon the determination by the city governing authority, or its mayor or its mayor's designee, of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the city council, its mayor or the mayor's designee may adopt a resolution instituting an extended curfew when it is determined necessary to protect and safeguard the people and property of the City of Newnan. 
(2)  Where imposed: All of the territory of the incorporated city shall be subject to the terms of the curfew, unless otherwise specified in the resolution. 
(3)  Times for extended curfews: The resolution instituting the curfew shall include the dates and hours that the curfew shall be in effect. 
(4)  Definitions. 
    Curfew. A "curfew" is a regulation requiring the withdrawal from any person not otherwise exempt from this section from appearing in certain public areas during specified hours. 
    Exempt individuals. Unless otherwise specified in the resolution implementing the curfew, "exempt individuals" include those individuals engaged in the provision of designated, essential services, such as fire, law enforcement, emergency medical services and hospital services, military services, utility emergency repairs. The resolution may, in the discretion of the governing authority, also exempt regular employees of local industries traveling to and from their jobs with appropriate identification, news media employees, building and repair contractors, properly registered according to the City of Newnan Ordinance No. 12-16 ("Ordinance to Require Registration and Licensing of Building and Repair Services During a State of Emergency"), performing activities related to construction, repair, renovation or improvement of buildings and other structures damaged during the disaster or emergency. 
    State of emergency. As defined by O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3(5), a condition declared by the governor when, in his judgment, the threat or actual occurrence of a disaster, emergency, or energy emergency is of sufficient severity and magnitude as to warrant extraordinary efforts in preventing or alleviating the damage, loss, hardship, or suffering threatened or caused thereby. 
(5)  Prohibition. It shall be prohibited for any person, other than exempt individuals, to appear in public in the territory subject to the curfew, including but not limited to, streets, highways, alleys, sidewalks, vacant lots, parks, public buildings or any other public places in all or a delineated part of incorporated City of Newnan during the stated hours of the curfew. 
(6)  Penalties. Any individual violating this section, upon conviction, shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 per violation or imprisonment not to exceed 60 days, or both. 
(7)  Severability. If any section, paragraph, sentence, clause, phrase or word of this section is, for any reason, held to be unconstitutional, inoperative, or void by any court of competent jurisdiction, such holding shall not affect the remainder of this section. 
(8)  Effective date. This section shall become effective upon adoption by the City Council of the City of Newnan. 
(Ord. No. 12-91, § 16-93, 10-21-91; Ord. No. 12-15, § 1, 8-28-12) 
Cross reference- Emergency services, § 9-1 et seq. 
Sec. 14-13. - Loitering. 
(a)  In public places. It shall be unlawful for any person to be found idling, loitering or loafing, in any alcoholic beverage establishment, hotel, motel, billiard room, street, lane, sidewalk or alley, or in any other public place within the city to the encouragement of loafing and idleness; to be one of an assembly of persons loafing, idling or loitering in streets, lanes, sidewalks or alleys, or in any public places within the city to the encouragement of loafing and idleness; or to act or conduct himself in a suspicious manner or to fail to give a satisfactory explanation for his presence at this place under these circumstances. 
(b)  Duty as to minors. It shall be unlawful for any person, guardian or any other person within the county, having the custody or control of any minor, to permit, allow or encourage such minor to become a common loiterer. Upon conviction of violation of this section for the first time, a person shall be given a warning citation. Upon further convictions, a person shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 and costs, or imprisonment in the city jail for not more than 60 days, or work on the city roads or work on the public works of the county for not more than 60 days, or be subject to any one or more of the within punishments. Each violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 12-91, § 16-94, 10-21-91) 
Secs. 14-14-14-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PROCEDURES AND PENALTIES UPON ARREST[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Criminal procedure, O.C.G.A. § 17-1-1 et seq. 

Sec. 14-31. - Warrant against offenders. 
    Offenders against the laws of the city shall be tried upon warrant issued either upon information on the oath of the informant, or on the knowledge of the person issuing the warrant. The complaint or warrant may be amended instanter as often as necessary. 
(Code 1972, § 16-104) 
Sec. 14-32. - Information required to obtain warrant. 
    The information required to obtain a warrant shall describe the offense substantially in the terms of the ordinance and with such particularity as to put the accused on notice of the nature of the charge, and may be substantially of the following form: 
State of Georgia, City of Newnan: 
The undersigned, upon his quote, deposes and says that on the ____________ day of ____________ , 19 ____________ , at ____________ (a.m.-p.m.) ____________ (name) ____________ (address) ____________ (occupation) did unlawfully in the city, county and state aforesaid commit the following offense: ____________ contrary to the city code. 
    Sworn to and subscribed before me, this ____________ day of ____________ , 19 ____________ . 
(officer sign) _____
(official title) _____  
(Code 1972, § 16-105) 
Sec. 14-33. - Form of warrant. 
    A warrant shall be attached to the information, and shall be in a form substantially as follows: 
State of Georgia, City of Newnan: 
    To the policemen of said city: 
    The foregoing affidavit having been made before me, you are therefor commanded to arrest the body of said accused person, and bring the same before the chief judge or other persons authorized to hold municipal court, to be dealt with as the law directs. Herein fail not. 
    Witness my hand and official signature, this ____________ day of ____________ , 19 ____________ . 
Signed _____
(Official Title) _____  
(Code 1972, § 16-106) 
Sec. 14-34. - Corporations violating penal ordinances. 
    Whenever complaint is made, under oath, that a corporation has violated a penal ordinance of this city, it shall be the duty of the officer to whom complaint is made, having authority to issue a warrant for a violation of the city ordinances, to issue a summons directed to such corporation, requiring it to appear by agent or attorney, at the municipal court, at a time therein named, to answer such charge. Service in such cases may be made by delivering a copy of the affidavit of complaint, and of the summons to any agent or employee of the defendant at least three days before the time set for the hearing, any person, being competent to make such service, the entry of the arresting officer of the city, or affidavit of any other person, being evidence of service. The trial may proceed ex parte, if the defendant fails to appear. If judgment is against the defendant, it shall be for a fine and costs, the same to be collected by execution. 
(Code 1972, § 16-107) 
Sec. 14-35. - Warrant required for arrest; authority to arrest without warrant. 
    Generally an arrest must be made by authority of warrant; but an arrest may be made without a warrant if the offense is committed in the presence of the officer, or if the offender is endeavoring to escape, or if for other cause there is likely to be a failure of justice for want of an officer to issue a warrant. 
(Code 1972, § 16-108) 
Sec. 14-36. - Duty upon arrest without warrant. 
    In every case of an arrest without a warrant, the person arresting shall without delay convey the offender before a proper officer and obtain a warrant, and no imprisonment shall be legal beyond a reasonable time allowed for the purpose. After such warrant has been obtained the proceedings shall be the same as in cases of arrest under warrant. 
(Code 1972, § 16-109) 
Sec. 14-37. - Arrest by private citizen. 
    A private person may arrest for a city offense under circumstances which would justify such arrest for a state offense. 
(Code 1972, § 16-110) 
State Law reference- Arrest by private person, O.C.G.A. § 17-4-60 et seq. 
Sec. 14-38. - Posse summoned by arresting officer. 
    Whenever a police officer may deem it necessary, he may, verbally or in writing, summon to his assistance, in making an arrest, or endeavoring to do so, any male person found in this city; and the acts of such posse in aid of such officer shall be protected as official acts. It shall be unlawful for any person summoned to refuse to assist in good faith. 
(Code 1972, § 16-111) 
State Law reference- Summoning posse, O.C.G.A. § 17-4-24. 
Sec. 14-39. - Right of accused to speedy trial. 
    The accused shall have a right to a speedy trial; and to that end the city shall have a right to a peremptory continuance but one time; it must after that show good cause for additional delay. If the accused is in custody, a continuance shall not be for a time longer than three days, except upon agreement of the defendant. If the accused is not in custody a continuance may be to such time as the court may appoint. 
(Code 1972, § 16-112) 
Sec. 14-40. - Escape. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person lawfully arrested by authority of this city to escape from the arresting officer, or break or escape from the city jail, or city work-gang. 
(Code 1972, § 16-113) 
Sec. 14-41. - Defendant's bond generally. 
    Any person arrested under a warrant may give to the arresting officer a bond with good security, to be approved by such officer or by the municipal court, which bond shall be joint and several, and in such sum as may be endorsed on the warrant by the officer issuing the same. The condition of the bond shall be for the appearance of the defendant at the municipal court at a specified time, and from time to time thereafter as required, then and there to stand to his trial on such charge, and not to depart thence without leave of the court. 
(Code 1972, § 16-114; Ord. No. 10-93, § 1, 4-5-93; Ord. No. 15-94, § I, 11-22-94) 
Sec. 14-42. - Power of bail over principal. 
    The principal shall be subject to the control of his bail and may be imprisoned or surrendered by them at any time. 
(Code 1972, § 16-115) 
Sec. 14-43. - Fixing type of bond; check not taken. 
(a)  Bond may be in the form of a cash bond; a real or personal property bond, provided that the surety produce evidence of ownership of such property as required by such officer or the municipal court and provided that if the property is located outside of the corporate limits of the city, approval by the sheriff of the county in which the property is located; a surety bond of a professional bondsman or person as defined in O.C.G.A. § 17-6-50 provided that such bondsman or person has made application to the chief of police for approval to furnish bonds and has been approved to act as surety by the municipal court; or by posting the driver's license of a licensed driver charged with a traffic offense as allowed by general state law and approved by such officer or the municipal court. 
(b)  Application for approval to serve as surety by a professional bondsman or person as set forth in this section shall be to the chief of police. Such bondsman shall post with the initial application and by March 1 of each year thereafter a current financial statement evidencing financial responsibility and showing a net worth of $75,000.00. Such bondsman shall post with the initial application and by March 1 of each year thereafter a certificate that all occupational taxes due for the current year have been paid. The form of the application shall be as approved by the municipal court. 
(c)  In no event shall a check be taken from an accused violator as bail. 
(Code 1972, § 16-116; Ord. No. 15-94, § II, 11-22-94) 
Sec. 14-44. - Forfeiture of bond or recognizance. 
(a)  Issuance of scire facias. Upon failure to appear of any principal in any bond or recognizance given by a person charged with a penal offense, or by a witness to appear and testify, the principal and the sureties on the bond or recognizance shall be called in the manner practiced in the superior courts of this state, and on failure of such persons so called to cause such principal to appear at once in court, such obligation shall be forfeited, whereupon the court shall order scire facias to issue, calling upon the principal and sureties to show cause why judgment should not be entered against them for the amount of the bond. 
(b)  Return of scire facias. The clerk shall issue scire facias according to the order returnable to the municipal court at a certain time therein specified. 
(c)  Service of scire facias. Such scire facias shall be served by any police officer, if the same can be done within the city. If service cannot be perfected within the city, the same may be done by any person within the state. 
(d)  Manner, time of service. The defendant may be served with a copy personally or by leaving the same at his residence or place of business, at least three days before the return day, or on a defendant residing out of the state, or whose residence is unknown, by publication of the scire facias in the official newspaper of the county twice before return day of the scire facias, or in such other manner as the court may direct. 
(e)  Evidence of service. The official return of the police officer or any constable or sheriff, or the affidavit of a private person, as to the service of the scire facias, shall be sufficient evidence of such service. 
(f)  Entry of judgment. Judgment on the recognizance shall be entered for the penal sum thereof at the return day thereof, or at a subsequent term, against the principal and sureties, or either or any who have been served, unless sufficient cause be shown to the contrary. A surrender of the principal before the return day of the scire facias and a payment of the accrued cost shall relieve the sureties from further liability. 
(Code 1972, § 16-117) 
Secs. 14-45-14-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE AND SAFETY 

Sec. 14-61. - Disorderly conduct. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits of the city to engage in any conduct described in the following subsections; provided, however, that no person shall be convicted of any of the following sections upon a showing that the predominant intent of such conduct was to exercise a constitutional right: 
(1)  To act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby any person is placed in fear of the safety of his life, limb or health; 
(2)  To act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby the property of any person is placed in danger of being damaged or destroyed. 
(3)  To cause, provoke or engage in any fight, brawl or riotous conduct so as to endanger life, limb, health or property of another; 
(4)  To be in or about any place, where illegal sale or possession of alcoholic beverages or narcotics or dangerous drugs is practiced, allowed, or tolerated, for the purpose of or intent to engage in the purchase, use, possession or consumption of such illegal drugs, narcotics or alcoholic beverages; 
(5)  To direct "fighting words" toward another, that is, words which by their very nature tend to incite a breach of the peace; 
(6)  To interfere with, by acts of physical obstruction, another's pursuit of a lawful occupation; 
(7)  To congregate with another or others on or about any public way so as to halt the flow or vehicular or pedestrian traffic, and to fail to clear that public way after being ordered to so do by a police officer or other lawful authority; 
(8)  To disrupt, by actions which tend to incite a breach of the peace, the undisturbed activities of any house of worship, hospital or home for the elderly; or 
(9)  To throw bottles, paper, cans, glass, sticks, stones, missiles or any other debris on public property. 
(Code 1972, § 16-14) 
Sec. 14-62. - Disturbing assemblies or exhibitions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person visiting or attending theaters, concerts or other public exhibitions or public assemblies, in this city, in any manner to disturb either the performance in such exhibition, or the audience assembled, by acting in a disorderly manner, by talking, hooting, whistling or cheering in a loud and boisterous manner, or by using vulgar or indecent language, or by committing any other indecorous conduct in the presence of the audience assembled or any part thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 16-6) 
State Law reference- Public disturbance, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-34. 
Sec. 14-63. - Abandoned iceboxes, refrigerators and similar receptacles. 
(a)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any owner or tenant of any premises within the city to allow or permit any abandoned or discarded icebox, refrigerator, trunk, chest or other receptacle or container in which a person might become imprisoned; to be or remain on such premises if such icebox, refrigerator, trunk, chest, receptacle, container or device has a virtually airtight lid, door, snap lock, latch or other locking device, without first removing such door, lid, snap lock, latch or other locking device. 
(b)  Definition. Any such container shall be considered and deemed abandoned or discarded when it is no longer used for the purpose for which it was intended, and is unattended outside of any building or structure, or is within an abandoned or unoccupied house, shed, bar or structure within the city. 
(Code 1972, § 16-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-100. 
Sec. 14-64. - Weapons. 
(a)  Drawing concealed weapons. It shall be unlawful for any person in this city to draw from a place of concealment about his person any pistol, dirk, or knife. 
(b)  Drawing weapon on another. It shall be unlawful for any person to draw on another any weapon; provided that, any person may in good faith draw in self-defense any weapon not a concealed weapon. 
(c)  Discharging firearms. It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge a gun or pistol in the city, except a duly licensed gunsmith may test fire firearms in a specific facility approved for safety annually by the chief of police. 
(Code 1972, § 16-20) 
State Law reference- Dangerous instrumentalities and practices, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-100 et seq.; Georgia Firearms and Weapons Act, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-120 et seq. 
Sec. 14-65. - Use of airguns, bow and arrow, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fire or use any air rifle, pellet rifle, BB gun, bow and arrows or slingshot. 
(Code 1972, § 16-15) 
Sec. 14-66. - Throwing rocks, stones.
