(a)  Duty. It shall be the duty of any person who has flowers, trees or shrubs growing on his premises or who has planted the same on the outer edge of the sidewalk adjacent to his property, to keep them trimmed so that they do not extend on or into any part of any sidewalk or street in the city. 
(b)  Failure to perform. If any person whose duty it is to trim or prune any flower or shrub because it extends onto any sidewalk or street of the city shall fail or refuse to do so, then it shall be the duty of the superintendent of streets to prune or trim any such flower or shrub at the expense of the person who planted or who owns the flowers or shrubs. 
(Code 1972, § 24-12) 
Sec. 18-14. - Tractors with cleats prohibited on paved streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated tractors with cleats, on or over any paved streets in the city. 
(Code 1972, § 24-13) 
Sec. 18-15. - Vehicles hauling over city streets, equipment prescribed. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to haul or cause to be hauled on any paved street of the city, unless the vehicle carrying the load is equipped in accordance with the provisions of state law regulating size, weight and speed of carriers. 
(Code 1972, § 24-14) 
Sec. 18-16. - Hauling dirt from streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dig or haul any dirt from any of the streets or alleys of the city without the written permission of the street superintendent. 
(Code 1972, § 24-15) 
Sec. 18-17. - Damage caused by hauling. 
(a)  Liability. Any person who shall damage by hauling or transporting any load over any paved street, bridge, viaduct, water main or sewer in the city shall be liable for the damage thereto, which damage shall be collected as provided in this section. 
(b)  Notice required. The city clerk as soon as any such damage is discovered shall notify in writing the person causing the same, of the damages, the time as near as the time can be ascertained, the character and place of the damage, and the time that the city shall commence repairs. 
(c)  Performing work, execution for cost thereof. The city after such notice is given shall then proceed at the time specified in such notice with the work of repairing the damage at the expense of the person liable therefor, and within five days after the completion of such work the person in charge of the same shall report under oath in writing to the city clerk the amount and value of the services performed or expense incurred in such work, whereupon the clerk shall issue execution, as other executions are issued by the city, for such amount against the person liable therefor. 
(d)  Contest of execution. An affidavit of illegality may be made and filed on oath, contesting the whole or any part of the amount for which execution issued, and stating what amount contestant admits to be due, if any, which amount so admitted to be due shall be paid before such affidavit is recorded. Such affidavit when recorded shall be returned to the superior court of the county and there tried, and the issue determined as in cases of illegality subject to all the penalties provided by law for illegality filed for purpose of delay. 
(Code 1972, § 24-16) 
Sec. 18-18. - Playing in public streets prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to play ball, skateboard or ride or use skates on the public streets or sidewalks in the city. 
(Code 1972, §§ 24-19, 24-22) 
Sec. 18-19. - Camping. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to camp in any street, alley or public place in the city. 
(Code 1972, § 24-20) 
Sec. 18-20. - Washing vehicles within first fire district. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to wash or cause to be washed any automobile or other vehicle on any of the streets or sidewalks within the first fire district of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 24-17) 
Sec. 18-21. - Pouring oil, petroleum products on streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to pour oil or any petroleum product on any street in the city without first obtaining permission to do so from the street superintendent. Such activity shall be under the supervision of the street superintendent. 
(Code 1972, § 24-18) 
Secs. 18-22-18-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - IMPROVEMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Authority to provide for public improvements, § 1.4(12). 

Sec. 18-46. - Authority of city council. 
    The city council shall have full power and authority to pave or otherwise permanently improve any or all of the streets, sidewalks or alleys of the city now, or that may hereafter be opened, laid out or constructed, and to lay curbing along any of such streets, sidewalks or alleys. 
(Code 1972, § 24-32) 
Sec. 18-47. - Assessments for improvement, authority limited; payment in installments. 
(a)  The city council shall have full power and authority to assess the actual cost of paving sidewalks, and placing curbing by the same, against the real estate abutting on the sidewalk, but only on the side of the street on which the sidewalk is improved, if on one side only. They shall have full power to assess one-third of the cost of paving or otherwise permanently improving any roadway or street proper on the real estate abutting on one side of the street improved, and one-third of the cost on the real estate abutting on the other side of the street so improved; and the real estate abutting on both sides of the street shall not together be assessed more than two-thirds of the entire cost. 
(b)  Property owners whose property abuts on the streets and sidewalks shall have the option to pay the assessment in cash upon the completion of the work or in installments as follows: 
(1)  One-third cash on completion of the work and one-third annually thereafter with interest upon such deferred payments at the rate of seven percent per annum, payable annually on the unpaid annual balance. 
(2)  Should any of such installments become delinquent, the remaining unpaid installments shall immediately become due and payable, at the option of the mayor and council. 
(c)  At least ten days before assessments shall be made, the city manager shall cause to be served upon each property owner a notice showing the number of front feet and the cost per front foot of the work done, and each property owner shall be required to sign the following acknowledgment which shall be presented with the notice and returned to the city manager within ten days: 
"GEORGIA, COWETA COUNTY 
    Due and legal service of the above acknowledged, and all other and further notice waived. 
    I hereby notify the City of Newnan, through its proper officers that I desire to pay for said improvements as follows: 
( )  Cash on completion and assessment. 
( )  1/3 cash on completion and assessment and 1/3 annually thereafter with interest at 7% payable annually on the unpaid annual balance. 
_____
(SIGNED)"  
Such notice and acknowledgment shall be served in person or by leaving a copy at the owner's last known place of residence. If the owner is a nonresident of the city, such notice and acknowledgment shall be mailed to such owner at his last known place of residence and if such owner is unknown, a copy of such notice and acknowledgment shall be posted at a conspicuous place on the premises. 
(d)  If such property owner shall fail or refuse to sign such acknowledgment and return it to the city manager within the prescribed time, same shall be taken and deemed to be an election to pay cash for such work upon completion and assessment. 
(e)  Upon the expiration of ten days the city clerk shall proceed to make an assessment, and a lien shall arise and exist in favor of the city against the property of the person owning same from the date of such assessment until each assessment is paid. If not promptly paid when due, the city clerk is authorized and directed to collect same by the issuance and levy of fi. fas. and the sale of such property in the same manner as for the collection of taxes, and such fi. fas. shall be transferable in the same manner as tax fi. fas. When such debts and liens are transferred by the city the holders thereof shall be subrogated to and enjoy all the rights of the city, including the right to foreclose and enforce such liens. 
(f)  The procedure and remedies allowed by the charter and ordinances of the city with reference to the levy and collection of taxes shall be available for the enforcement and collection of assessments made hereunder as fully as if set forth in this article. 
(Code 1972, § 24-33) 
Sec. 18-48. - Assessment against railroads. 
    Any railroad company having track running along or across the streets of the city shall be required to pay the cost in full for paving or otherwise improving such street between their tracks and for two feet on each side thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 24-34) 
Sec. 18-49. - Ordinance assessing for improvements. 
    The city council shall have power and authority to direct by ordinance, that any or all of the streets, sidewalks or alleys or a portion of any street of the city be permanently improved, and to prescribe with what material the improvement shall be done. When such authorities order any street improved, the owners of the abutting property shall be given notice that the street is ordered improved and the kind of material with which the street shall be improved by publishing the ordinance directing the work, and prescribing the material to be used, once in the paper in the city in which sheriff advertisements are published. 
(Code 1972, § 24-35) 
Sec. 18-50. - Lien of assessments for improvements. 
    The amount of assessments on each piece of real estate for improvements pursuant to this article shall be a lien on such real estate from the date of the passage of the ordinance providing for the work and making the assessment. 
(Code 1972, § 24-36) 
Sec. 18-51. - Material for paving, quality prescribed. 
    All paving shall be accomplished only with plant mix or material of equal or superior quality; provided, that the city council may, from time to time, authorize and direct the paving of existing dedicated and accepted city streets with bituminous application or seal. 
(Code 1972, § 24-38) 
Sec. 18-52. - Curbs and gutters, minimum sizes prescribed. 
    All curbs and gutters installed shall be 30-inch gutters with six-inch curbs. 
(Code 1972, § 24-39) 
Sec. 18-53. - Cutting public pavements to lay pipes, special permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or municipal agency or public utility to cut into any public pavement or hard-surfaced street within the city without first obtaining a special permit from the street superintendent. 
(Code 1972, § 24-40) 
Sec. 18-54. - Relocation of pipes under streets, sidewalks, other public places. 
(a)  Duty upon notice. It shall be the duty of any person who has laid, constructed, maintains or owns a pipe line system in or under any of the streets, sidewalks, alleys or other public places within the city, within ten days after notice from the city council, to relocate at the expense of such person the pipe line or pipes in accordance with the terms of the notice. 
(b)  Service of notice. The notice referred to in this section shall be served upon the person subject thereto by delivering a copy to the agent of such person in charge of its property in the city, or to any person in the employ of such person to be notified. 
(c)  Noncompliance with notice. If any person subject to this section should fail or refuse to relocate his pipe or pipes within ten days after notice, in that event the city council shall relocate the pipe or pipes at the expense of the person notified. 
(Code 1972, § 24-41) 
Sec. 18-55. - Private improvement of sidewalk. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to improve any sidewalk in the city except as follows: 
(1)  Grade line required. The person desiring to improve any sidewalk shall, before beginning the work, make written application to the street superintendent stating in the application the location of the sidewalk to be improved, and shall obtain from the street superintendent a permanent grade line at the location where the sidewalk is to be improved. 
(2)  Permit requirements. After making the application required in subsection (1) of this section and obtaining the grade line, the person desiring to improve a sidewalk shall also, before beginning the work, make written application to the city council, which application shall be accompanied by a profile showing the grade line as proposed by the street superintendent and shall obtain from the city council permission to improve the sidewalk desired to be improved. If permission to make the improvement is granted, then the work of improving the sidewalk shall be made and done only in accordance with the grade line shown by the profile. 
(Code 1972, § 24-42) 
Secs. 18-56-18-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - POLES AND WIRES 

Sec. 18-76. - Authority of city council. 
    All telegraph and telephone companies and other companies owning or using poles placed in the streets of the city shall have the right to keep and use such poles subject to the power of the city council to regulate the placing and removal of such poles, and the council shall have authority in its discretion to reject any poles already in use, or which any of such companies propose to erect; and in case of rejection of poles already in use, to require their removal and to prevent the use of poles which it deems to be unsuitable or unsafe. It shall also be within the power of the city council to require the removal of such poles when necessary, in its judgment, to facilitate the improvement of any street, or portion of the street, or the improvement or convenient use of any lot abutting thereon. 
(Code 1972, § 24-53) 
Sec. 18-77. - Permit prerequisite to erection, removal of poles. 
    No telegraph, telephone or other company owning or using poles in the city shall cause any pole to be erected or removed without first obtaining permission to remove or erect such pole from the city council or from its agent authorized to issue such permit. 
(Code 1972, § 24-54) 
Sec. 18-78. - Setting of poles; surplus dirt to be removed. 
    All telegraph, telephone and other companies who set poles upon or along streets, sidewalks or alleys in the city shall remove all surplus dirt after setting such poles. 
(Code 1972, § 24-55) 
Sec. 18-79. - Restoration of surface after erection or removal of poles. 
    Telegraph, telephone and other companies which erect or remove poles on city sidewalks, streets and alleys shall leave the surface thereof in as good condition as it was before such work was done. It shall not be sufficient in removing poles to saw off the poles on a level with the surface, leaving the body thereof in the ground, but the same shall be removed and the hole filled and the sidewalk or street replaced with material similar to that already on such sidewalk or street. 
(Code 1972, § 24-56) 
Sec. 18-80. - Maintaining poles. 
    All telegraph or telephone poles erected on the streets of the city shall be kept in good repair. 
(Code 1972, § 24-57) 
Sec. 18-81. - Authority to cut wires. 
    The chief of the fire department, or other authority acting under him, is hereby authorized to cut any and all wires which they deem necessary in case of fire, without expense to the city for so doing; provided, that nothing herein contained shall imply that the city authorizes any person to undertake the risk of cutting any of such wires or renders itself liable for any injury to the person so doing. 
(Code 1972, § 24-59) 
Sec. 18-82. - Noncompliance with notice to remove condemned pole. 
    Any person who shall fail or refuse, within five days after notice from the city council, to remove any pole deemed to be unsuitable, unsafe or improperly located, or the location of which they shall require to be changed, shall on conviction be punished as prescribed in section 1-14. 
(Code 1972, § 24-60) 
Sec. 18-83. - Liability of city. 
    Nothing contained in any of the ordinances, resolutions or acts of the city council in relation to the erection of telephone, telegraph or any other wires, shall be construed to mean that the city holds itself in any manner responsible or liable for damage to person or property by reason of any accident or occurrence, but the city disclaims any liability whatever in the premises. 
(Code 1972, § 24-61) 
Secs. 18-84-18-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DRIVEWAY ACCESS 

Sec. 18-106. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Arterial and collector streets means those streets designated as such on official maps or in resolutions or ordinances of the city. 
    Curbline means the exposed approximately vertical face of the curb. Where there is no curb and gutter, "curbline" shall mean the edge of pavement of the public street and "curb cut" shall mean the width of the intersection of the driveway pavement (including radii) with the public street pavement. 
    Extended property line means a line extending from the front property corner of a lot to the curbline of the street, perpendicular to such curbline. 
    Heavy industrial uses means those permitted in a heavy industrial zoning district, but not in a light industrial zoning district. 
    Intersection of two streets, unless otherwise specified, means the intersection of the extended curblines, made by extending the tangents to the corner radius. 
    Joint driveway means a driveway which straddles a property line and is used in common by both lots. 
    Light industrial uses means those permitted in a light industrial zoning district. 
    Pull-off parking means the arrangement of offstreet parking spaces in such a manner that automobiles must back onto the public street in order to exit from the parking spaces. 
(Code 1972, § 24-77; Ord. No. 13-88, § I, 8-22-88) 
Sec. 18-107. - Sight distance. 
    No driveway shall be permitted to enter a public street at a point where sight distance is inadequate, as determined by the city manager. 
(Code 1972, § 24-72; Ord. No. 13-88, § I, 8-22-88) 
Sec. 18-108. - Driveway design. 
(a)  Width. Width of a driveway intersecting a public street shall not exceed the following: 
(1)  Residential use, one- or two-dwelling units, 12 feet. 
(2)  Other residential uses, 16 feet for a one-way drive and 30 feet for a two-way drive. 
(3)  Nonresidential uses, 16 feet for a one-way drive, 30 feet for a two-way drive (except 35 feet for a service station), and 40 feet for a joint driveway. 
(b)  Radii. At the intersection of a driveway with the curbline of a public street, a minimum curbline radius shall be formed on each side, as follows: 
(1)  Residential one-lane driveway, three feet. 
(2)  Other residential, nonresidential (except industrial), 20 feet. 
(3)  Industrial, 30 feet. 
No radius may exceed 30 feet except in conjunction with an approved traffic channelizing structure. 
(c)  Angle. The angle of a driveway shall be such that no vehicle will have to make a deflection of greater than 90 degrees when entering or leaving the property, but in no case shall the angle be less than 45 degrees. 
(d)  Tie-in type. A street intersection type tie-in shall be provided wherever ditch drainage is used and where otherwise made necessary by the level of driveway traffic. 
(1)  A concrete valley gutter tie-in shall be provided to a street with curb and gutter and piped storm drainage. 
(2)  If a street intersection type tie-in is preferred by the property owner, catch basins must be provided to channel gutter flow into the storm drainage system. 
(e)  Grade. On streets with ditch drainage along the street and a street intersection type tie-in, the driveway shall slope downward and away from the road surface at a rate not less than one-half inch in one foot out to the ditchline. Driveway grade for a concrete valley gutter tie-in shall conform to standards of the city. 
(f)  Drainage. Curb inlets shall be designed for a ten-year storm. Driveway pipes shall be designed for a 25-year storm unless a larger pipe is emptying into the ditch that leads to the driveway pipe. 
(1)  Pipes 48 inches in diameter and larger shall have an inlet and outlet headwall. Pipes smaller than 48 inches shall have at least a flared end section. 
(2)  All structures and materials shall meet city standards. 
(g)  Adjacent slope. No new slope to be placed on the right-of-way shall be steeper than 4:1 (horizontal:vertical) sloping from the street or 2:1 sloping from the driveway. 
(Code 1972, § 24-73; Ord. No. 13-88, § I, 8-22-88) 
Sec. 18-109. - Curb cuts. 
(a)  Length. The length of a curb cut shall be the sum of driveway width plus the radius on each side. 
(b)  Separation, two-way driveways. Distance between two-way driveways (not including radii), for driveways on the same lot and on the same street frontage, shall be at least 100 feet (except that for a service station or convenience store which includes gasoline sales and has at least 150 feet of frontage, the minimum distance shall be 50 feet). Lots not wide enough to meet this and related driveway placement requirements may have only a single two-way driveway. 
(c)  Separation, one-way driveways. Where one-way driveways are used, the exit from the property shall be downstream, in the direction of traffic flow from the entrance. Distance between driveways (not including radii) on the same lot and on the same street frontage shall be at least 50 feet on collector streets and 80 feet on arterial streets. 
(d)  Number of driveways. On a collector or an arterial street, no lot with less than 300 feet of frontage shall have more than one two-way driveway or two one-way driveways (except that a service station or convenience store which includes gasoline sales and has at least 150 feet of frontage may have two two-way driveways); no lot with less than 1,000 feet of frontage shall have more than two two-way driveways; and a lot with frontage of 1,000 feet or more may have driveways as determined on a case-by-case basis by the city manager. 
(e)  Distance from property lines. No curb cut may extend across an extended property line, except a curb cut for a joint driveway; and no curb cut shall be within four feet of an extended property line. 
(f)  Distance from intersections. On a local street, no driveway shall be permitted within 50 feet of an intersection with another street. On a collector street, no driveway shall be permitted within 90 feet of an intersection with another street. On an arterial street, no driveway shall be permitted within 120 feet downstream or 90 feet upstream of an intersection with another street. At signalized intersections on collector or arterial streets, respective distances shall be increased by 100 feet. Exceptions may be granted where the city manager determines that: 
(1)  There is no reasonable alternative; and 
(2)  Traffic capacity and safety would not be significantly affected. 
(g)  Subdivision of arterial street frontage. On an arterial street, where a tract of land is subdivided after the adoption of this provision such that a lot with less than 150 feet of frontage is created, access to such lot shall be from either: 
(1)  A driveway serving the remainder of the tract from which the lot was cut; 
(2)  A joint driveway; 
(3)  A frontage road; or 
(4)  If a corner or double-frontage lot, an adjacent nonarterial street. 
(h)  General location criteria. Unless substantially constrained by topography or the needs of internal traffic circulation on the property, driveways shall be located so as to maximize distance between driveways along the street section, maximize the length of deceleration lanes, and minimize conflict with other features of the street section. 
(i)  Traffic channelizing structures. No median, island, or other traffic channelizing structure may be installed in a driveway entrance without approval of the city manager. Upon approval, the permitted length of the curb cut may be increased to accommodate such structures. 
(j)  Pull-off parking. Limitations on length of curb cut shall not apply to pull-off parking where such parking is otherwise permitted. 
(Code 1972, § 24-74; Ord. No. 13-88, § I, 8-22-88) 
Sec. 18-110. - Curb and gutter. 
(a)  Required. Where there is existing curb and gutter on the public street, curb and gutter shall be constructed for a driveway entrance. Where there is no curb and gutter on the public street, it shall be constructed for a driveway entrance where one of the following conditions occurs: 
(1)  A new nonresidential use or multifamily (three or more dwelling units) or other residential use utilizing a common driveway entrance for three or more dwelling units is established on previously vacant land. 
(2)  A nonresidential use is established on land previously in residential use. 
(3)  The number of dwelling units on a lot is increased to three or more. 
(4)  Changes to developed property, such as the piping and covering of ditches, result in uncontrolled access to the public street. 
(b)  Length. Where curb and gutter is required by the above conditions, the length of curb and gutter to be constructed shall be determined as follows: 
(1)  Curb and gutter shall be used to construct the radii where the driveway intersects the public street and, for street-intersection type tie-ins, shall extend along the driveway to the right-of-way line. 
(2)  Except where tapers for acceleration/deceleration lanes are present, curb and gutter shall be extended by the property owner at least 20 feet in each direction along the public street from the end of each radius section (except that no property owner shall be required to extend curb and gutter along the street beyond an extended property line). 
(3)  Where changes to developed property result in uncontrolled access to the public street, curb and gutter shall be provided along the entire frontage of the property unless a landscaped barrier (e.g., a strip planted in shrubs or trees, a grassed berm, flower beds bounded by railroad ties, etc.) or other onsite barrier (e.g., parking lot curbing) to access is provided. 
(c)  Distance from centerline. Distance from the centerline of the public street to the edge of the curb and gutter shall be adequate for provision of 12-foot travel lanes, including future lanes indicated on official maps or ordinances of the city. 
(1)  Where a left-turn lane to serve both sides of the street will be necessary and the city has adopted plans to construct such lane, an additional six feet of lane width shall be provided by the property owner. 
(2)  Where a median with a left-turn lane will be necessary to serve a particular development, an additional 16 feet of lane width shall be provided by the property owner. 
(d)  Right-of-way dedication. Any additional right-of-way necessary for construction of curb and gutter and the accommodation of utilities shall be dedicated to the city by the property owner. 
(e)  Storm drainage. Storm drainage from curb and gutter sections constructed by a property owner shall be discharged at locations and through structures approved by the city manager. 
(Code 1972, § 24-75; Ord. No. 13-88, § I, 8-22-88) 
Sec. 18-111. - Acceleration, deceleration lanes. 
(a)  Required. At the driveways providing access to a nonresidential use or a multifamily (three or more dwelling units) or other residential use utilizing a common driveway entrance for three or more dwelling units on an arterial street, acceleration and deceleration lanes shall be constructed by the property owner in conjunction with the curb and gutter required above, and the length of curb and gutter shall be increased to the full length of such lanes. 
(1)  An acceleration lane shall not generally be required, but the driveway radius shall turn out as though a lane were to be provided and a taper shall be constructed. 
(2)  An acceleration lane shall be required where: 
a.  The owner's property extends to an intersection with a collector or arterial street within 150 feet of the driveway in the direction of traffic flow; or 
b.  The required taper will merge with the taper of an existing deceleration lane or is within 20 feet of merging. 
(b)  Length. Each such lane shall be 150 feet in length, with an additional tapered transition section 50 feet in length. Lane pavement width shall be 12 feet. Where the taper of a new deceleration lane will merge with the taper of an existing driveway or is within 20 feet of merging, the deceleration lane shall be extended to that driveway. 
(c)  Property lines. Where a lane or taper would merge with a lane or taper provided for adjoining property or would encroach on the corner radius of a street intersection, an altered design may be approved by the city manager. Where a lane or taper would extend across an extended property line, such lane or taper shall be constructed if there is adequate right-of-way in front of the adjoining property. 
(d)  Right-of-way dedication. Any additional right-of-way necessary for construction of a lane and the abutting curb and gutter and the accommodation of utilities shall be dedicated to the city by the property owner. 
(e)  Exceptions. The following land uses are excepted from the requirement for acceleration/deceleration lanes: 
(1)  Warehouse use with less than 10,000 square feet of building area. 
(2)  Manufacturing use with less than 13,000 square feet of building area. 
(3)  Other light industrial use with less than 7,000 square feet of building area. 
(4)  Other heavy industrial use with less than 33,000 square feet of building area. 
(5)  Apartment development with fewer than nine dwelling units. 
(6)  Nursing home with fewer than 19 beds. 
(7)  Medical office use with less than 1,000 square feet of building area. 
(8)  General office use with less than 3,000 square feet of building area. 
(9)  Office park (mixed office uses) with less than 2,000 square feet of building area. 
A mixture of the above uses will require a case-by-case determination of traffic generation by the city manager. Acceleration/deceleration lanes shall be required when sufficient additional development occurs on property previously excepted from the requirement. 
(Code 1972, § 24-76; Ord. No. 13-88, § I, 8-22-88) 
Sec. 18-112. - Left-turn restrictions. 
    On arterial streets, left turns shall be prohibited to and/or from driveways by the construction of approved channelizing structures under the following conditions: 
(1)  Inadequate corner clearance. 
(2)  Inadequate sight distance. 
(3)  Inadequate driveway spacing. 
(4)  Site has a signalized driveway on the same arterial at which left turns can be made. 
(5)  Other capacity, delay or safety conditions make specific left turns dangerous. 
(Code 1972, § 24-77; Ord. No. 13-88, § I, 8-22-88) 
Sec. 18-113. - Paving. 
    Driveways shall be paved to the right-of-way line. Acceleration and deceleration lanes and gaps between existing pavement and new curb and gutter shall also be paved. Pavement structure shall at least match that of the adjoining existing pavement and shall not be less than specified in writing or drawings by the city manager. Materials and construction methods shall meet city standards. 
(Code 1972, § 24-78; Ord. No. 13-88, § I, 8-22-88) 
Sec. 18-114. - Administrative standards. 
    The city manager may establish standards (in writing or in drawings) for structures and approve driveway access designs permitted by this article but not specified herein; and establish such additional standards (in writing or in drawings) as are necessary to clarify this article and assure traffic safety and protection of traffic capacity on the public streets. 
(Code 1972, § 24-79; Ord. No. 13-88, § I, 8-22-88) 
Secs. 18-115-18-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PARADES AND ASSEMBLIES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Permit for exhibition or parade of animals, § 4-2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-136. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Parade is a parade, march, ceremony, demonstration, show, exhibition, pageant, or procession of any kind involving one or more persons or one or more vehicles. 
    Parade permit is a permit as required by this article. 
    Vehicles includes any device which moves on wheels or tracks whether under its own power or otherwise. 
Sec. 18-137. - Exceptions. 
    This article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Funeral processions, provided the police department is notified of each procession's time and route; 
(2)  Students going to and from school classes or participating in educational or school sponsored activities, providing such conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities; or 
(3)  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
Sec. 18-138. - Public conduct during parades. 
(a)  Interference. No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct or impede, or interfere with any parade or parade assembly or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used in a parade. 
(b)  Driving through parades. No driver of any vehicle shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising a parade when the vehicles or persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade. Punishment for violations of this subsection shall be as provided in section 1-14. 
(c)  Parking or parade route. The chief of police shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a highway or part thereof constituting a part of the route of a parade. The chief of police shall post signs to the effect. It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. No person shall be liable for parking on a street unposted in violation of this article. 
Sec. 18-139. - Distribution of material during procession prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute or cause to be distributed from any vehicle participating in a parade or procession or other public demonstration in the public streets or public highways within the city limits any item other than materials protected by freedom of speech, either perishable or otherwise to any bystander or onlooker. It shall also be unlawful for any owner or operator of any vehicle participating in a parade within the city limits to allow or permit any item, perishable or otherwise, to be distributed to any bystanders or onlookers from the vehicle. It shall also be unlawful to litter the parade route with any items including those materials which it is otherwise lawful to distribute. This prohibition shall also apply to gratuities to items offered for sale. 
Secs. 18-140-18-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 18-151. - Required. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, no person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any parade, unless a parade permit shall have been obtained from the office of the city manager. 
Sec. 18-152. - Application. 
    A person seeking issuance of a parade permit shall file application with the office of the city manager on forms provided by the city. 
(1)  Filing period. An application for a parade permit shall be filed not less than ten days or more than 30 days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade. 
(2)  Contents. The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: 
a.  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct the parade; and the applicant, if different. 
b.  If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of that organization. 
c.  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade leader and who will be responsible for its conduct. 
d.  The date when the parade is to be conducted. 
e.  The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point. 
f.  The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute the parade; the type of animals, and description of the vehicles. 
g.  The hours when the parade will start and terminate. 
h.  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed. 
i.  The location by streets of any assembly and dispersal areas for the parade. 
j.  The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any assembly area or areas and a designation of the assembly area and the dispersal area. 
k.  The interval of space to be maintained between units of the parade. 
l.  If the parade is designed to be held by, and on behalf of or for, any person other than the applicant, the applicant for the permit shall file with the office of the city business license department a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on its, his behalf. 
m.  Any expenditure of funds by the applicant or his organization for or on behalf of participants in the parade, the amounts thereof and the names and addresses of to whom paid. 
n.  Any additional information which the city business license department shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should issue. 
(3)  Late applications. The city manager, where good cause is shown therefor, shall have the authority to consider any application under this division which is filed less than ten days before the date the parade is proposed to be conducted. 
(4)  Fee. No fee shall be charged for such permit. 
Sec. 18-153. - Standards for issuance. 
    The office of the city manager shall issue a permit under this division when, from a consideration of the application and from any other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route. 
(2)  The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city. 
(3)  The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of the city other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and areas contiguous thereto. 
(4)  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to assembly areas. 
(5)  The conduct of the parade will not unreasonably interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to a fire. 
(6)  The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance. 
(7)  The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays enroute. 
(8)  The parade is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, goods or event, and is not designed to be held purely for private profit. 
(9)  The parade will not unreasonably burden the streets and sidewalks or the city so as to substantially interfere with the normal use thereof by the public. 
(10)  The parade will not interfere with another parade for which a permit has been approved. 
Sec. 18-154. - Notice of rejection. 
    The office of the city manager shall act upon the application for a parade permit within three days after the filing thereof. If the city disapproves the application, there shall be mailed to the applicant within two days after the date upon which the application was filed, a notice of the action, stating the reasons for the denial of the permit or communicate sooner if the date for the parade requires a quicker response. 
Sec. 18-155. - Appeal procedure. 
    Any person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the denial of a parade permit to the city council. The appeal shall be taken within two days after notice. The council shall act upon the appeal within two days after its receipt and may grant or deny a permit by a majority vote of the members present. 
Sec. 18-156. - Alternate permit. 
    The city business license department may grant the permit conditioned on the conduct of the parade on a date, at a time, or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within two days after notice of the action, file a written notice of acceptance with the city. An alternate parade permit shall conform to the requirements of, and shall have the effect of, a parade permit under this division. 
Sec. 18-157. - Notice to city and other officials. 
    Immediately upon the application for a parade permit, the office of the city manager shall send a copy thereof to the following: 
(1)  The mayor; 
(2)  The police chief; 
(3)  The fire chief; and 
(4)  The director of the department of streets and sanitation. 
Sec. 18-158. - Contents of permit. 
    Each parade permit shall state the following information: 
(1)  Starting time. 
(2)  Minimum speed. 
(3)  Maximum speed. 
(4)  Maximum interval of space to be maintained between the units of the parade. 
(5)  The portions of the streets to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade. 
(6)  The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof. 
(7)  Any other information as the city manager shall find necessary to the enforcement of this article. 
(8)  Number of participants. 
Sec. 18-159. - Duties of permittee. 
(a)  A permittee under this division shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
(b)  The parade leader or other person heading or leading the activity shall carry the parade permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade. 
Sec. 18-160. - Revocation of permit. 
    The city manager shall have the authority to revoke a parade permit issued under this division upon application of the standards for issuance as set forth under section 18-153. 
Secs. 18-161-18-169. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SPECIAL EVENTS 
DIVISION 1. - TOURS 

Sec. 18-170. - Tours permitted, frequency, time. 
    It shall be lawful for a property owner to permit tours of any residential building, structure or land owned by him for compensation paid either directly or indirectly to the property owner. Tours shall be permitted only between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., unless a later time is approved by the city manager or his designee. Effective January 1, 1997, no property owner shall permit a tour of a residential building, structure or land owned by him more than 12 times in any calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 96-2, § I, 2-13-96) 
Sec. 18-171. - Tours, permit required. 
    No person shall engage in, aid, form or permit tours of any residential building, structure, or land without first obtaining a special events permit from the office of the city manager as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 97-20, § I, 8-26-97) 
DIVISION 2. - NONPROFIT GATHERINGS, POLITICAL GATHERINGS. 

Sec. 18-172. - Permissible gatherings. 
    It shall be lawful for a property owner to permit gatherings, parties, tours or other similar type entertainments in any residential building, structure or land, without compensation to the property owner (other than reimbursement for expenses), by a nonprofit organization, school, church, group, association, or individual for fund raising purposes so long as the funds raised are for educational or charitable purposes, or to support a political candidate or party. 
(Ord. No. 97-20, § I, 8-26-97) 
Sec. 18-173. - Permit required. 
    No person shall engage in, aid, form or permit a gathering, party, tour or other similar type entertainment in any residential building, structure or land without first obtaining a special events permit from the office of the city manager as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 97-20, § I, 8-26-97) 
DIVISION 3. - SPECIAL EVENTS PERMIT 

Sec. 18-174. - Required. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, a special events permit shall be required for the activities set forth in Division I and Division II of this article. 
(Ord. No. 97-20, § I, 8-26-97) 
Sec. 18-175. - Application. 
    A person seeking issuance of a special events permit shall file application with the office of the city manager on forms provided by the city. 
(1)  Filing period. An application for a special events permit shall be filed not less than 10 days or more than 30 days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the activity. 
(2)  Contents. The application for a special events permit shall set forth the following information: 
a.  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct the activity; and the applicant, if different. 
b.  If the activity is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of that organization. 
c.  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the activity leader and who will be responsible for its conduct. 
d.  The date when the activity is to be conducted. 
e.  If the activity is a tour, a map of the route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point. 
f.  The approximate number of persons who will participate in the activity. 
g.  The hours the activity will start and terminate. 
h.  A plan that identifies adequate provisions for parking and transportation of participants in the activity. 
i.  If the activity requires police protection or traffic control, the number of officers to be employed by applicant to provide such protection and control. 
j.  Any additional information which the city manager or his designee shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a special events permit should issue. 
(3)  Late applications. The city manager or his designee where good cause is shown therefor, shall have the authority to consider any application under this division which is filed less than 10 days before the date the special event is proposed to be conducted, but in any event no less than five days before the date of the special event. 
(4)  Fee. A fee of $10.00 shall be charged for such special events permit. 
(Ord. No. 97-20, § I, 8-26-97) 
Sec. 18-176. - Standards for issuance. 
    The city manager or his designee shall issue a special events permit under this article when, from a consideration of the application and from any other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the special event will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to the activity. 
(2)  The conduct of the special event will not require the diversion of any of the police officers of the city to police the activity, but that adequate provisions for police protection and traffic control have been made by the applicant. 
(3)  The conduct of the special event will not unreasonably interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to a fire. 
(4)  The conduct of the special event is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance. 
(5)  The special event is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, goods or event, and is not designed to be held purely for private profit except as provided in this article. 
(6)  The special event will not unreasonably burden the streets and sidewalks of the city so as to substantially interfere with the normal use thereof by the public, but that adequate provisions for parking and transportation of participants in the activity have been made by the applicant. 
(7)  The special event will not interfere with another special event for which a special events permit has been approved. 
(Ord. No. 97-20, § I, 8-26-97) 
Sec. 18-177. - Notice of rejection. 
    The city manager or his designee shall act upon the application for a special events permit within three days after the filing thereof. If the application is disapproved, there shall be mailed to the applicant within two days after the date the application is disapproved, a notice of the action, stating the reasons for the denial of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 97-20, § I, 8-26-97) 
Sec. 18-178. - Appeal procedure. 
    Any person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the denial of a special events permit to the city council. The appeal shall be taken within two days after receipt of the notice by the applicant. The council shall act upon the appeal at the next regularly scheduled meeting after its receipt and may grant or deny a special events permit by a majority vote of the members present. 
(Ord. No. 97-20, § I, 8-26-97) 
Sec. 18-179. - Notice to city and other officials. 
    Immediately upon the application for a special events permit, the city manager or his designee shall send a copy thereof to the following: 
(1)  The city council; 
(2)  The police chief; 
(3)  The fire chief; and 
(4)  The director of the department of streets and sanitation. 
(Ord. No. 97-20, § I, 8-26-97) 
Sec. 18-180. - Duties of permittee. 
(a)  A permittee under this article shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
(b)  The permittee, leader or other person heading or leading the activity shall carry the special events permit upon his person during the conduct of the activity. 
(Ord. No. 97-20, § I, 8-26-97) 
Sec. 18-181. - Revocation of permit. 
    The city manager or his designee shall have the authority to revoke a special events permit issued under this division upon a finding that the application filed contains misleading or incomplete information and does not comply with the standards for issuance as set forth under section 18-176. 
(Ord. No. 97-20, § I, 8-26-97) 
Secs. 18-182-18-189. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - EXCEPTIONS. 

Sec. 18-190. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to private gatherings, parties, tours, or other similar type entertainments hosted by a property owner in the property owner's own residential building, structure or land for the property owner's own enjoyment and benefit, without compensation, and otherwise permitted under the city's ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 97-20, § I, 8-26-97) 
Secs. 18-191-18-199. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES 

Sec. 18-200. - Violations prohibited; penalties. 
(a)  No person shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or assist another in evading the requirements imposed by this chapter. 
(b)  Any person knowingly violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of an offense against the city, punishable upon citation before the municipal court. Any person convicted of violating any provision of this article shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, imprisonment not to exceed 12 months, or both. 
(Ord. No. 97-20, § I, 8-26-97) 
Secs. 18-201-18-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PROCEDURE FOR CHANGING STREET NAMES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 97-4, § I, adopted February 25, 1997, amended the Code by adding a new Art. VI, §§ 18-180-18-182. In order to avoid duplication of article and section numbers, the editor has redesignated said new provisions as Art. VII, §§ 18-211-18-213. 

Sec. 18-211. - Petition required. 
    Should any person or group of persons wish to change the name of any street within the city they shall present a petition signed by a majority of the property owners and the owners of a majority of the street frontage on the street to be affected to the city council. The petition shall contain the following: 
(1)  Statement requesting change of name. 
(2)  An explanation as to why the change is requested. 
(3)  If to be renamed for a person or group of persons, a history of the person stating what part the person played in local, state or national history. 
(4)  Each petition shall contain the signature as well as a typed or printed name along with that person's mailing address/street address. 
(Ord. No. 97-4, § I, 2-25-97) 
Sec. 18-212. - Investigation by staff. 
    Upon receipt of such a petition, the city council shall refer the petition to the city staff who will investigate the request and shall require the city's department heads to advise if the change would have any bearing on how services are rendered to the citizens of that street and whether or not the change would effect any service. In addition, staff shall send the request to the U.S. post office, each utility, the office of 911 and any other entity that will need to adjust services if the street is renamed. Each of these entities shall be requested to furnish a statement of how the change would effect services if any and be requested to furnish that information in writing to the city. 
    Upon receipt of the information above, staff shall develop a recommendation on whether or not the street's name should be changed and submit said recommendation to the city council. 
    Simultaneous to this the staff shall advertise the request for a street name change in a newspaper of local circulation and schedule a public hearing for the city council at a regular meeting of the council on the request. Prior to the public hearing the staff shall notify all of the property owners on the street of the request to change the name of the street by U.S. Mail. 
(Ord. No. 97-4, § I, 2-25-97) 
Sec. 18-213. - Action by city council. 
    Upon hearing the request at the public hearing the city council shall decide whether or not to change the name of the street and shall so notify all of the owners of property on the effected street of the council's action on this request. 
    Should the council vote in the affirmative to change the name of any street the effective date of the change shall be on the first day of the next quarter (January, April, July, October), provided that period is at least two months from the date of the decision unless council determines that the date of the change should be at another time. 
(Ord. No. 97-4, § I, 2-25-97) 
Secs. 18-214-18-219. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - STREET CLASSIFICATIONS 

Sec. 18-220. - Types of classification. 
    Streets in the city shall be classified as either alleys, minor residential, residential, residential collector, collector, subcollector, nonresidential local, minor arterial, major, arterial, or industrial as more fully defined in chapter 3, definitions, of the zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 00-35, 11-14-00) 
Sec. 18-221. - Table of street classifications adopted. 
    Table 18-221, "City of Newnan Street Classifications" attached to Ord. No. 00-35 as Exhibit "A" is hereby adopted establishing the street classification for the city. Table 18-221 is not set out herein, but is on file and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 00-35, 11-14-00) 
Chapter 19 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Taxation and finance, § 6.1 et seq. 
Cross reference- Excise tax on malt beverages, § 3-31; business license tax on depository financial institutions, § 6-161. 
State Law reference- Taxation power of municipal governments, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 4, par. 1; limitation on taxing power of municipalities, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 8; ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-2; municipal taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq.; specific business and occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 19-1-19-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PROPERTY TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Property tax, § 6.1. 

Sec. 19-25. - Annual levy generally. 
    The city council shall impose, by ordinance, an annual tax, in such amount as it may deem necessary for corporate purposes, subject to constitutional and statutory limitations, on all real estate lying within the corporate limits and including all bonds and stocks of banks and other corporations, and the real estate of churches and school associations from which the churches and school associations draw a revenue or which are intended to be rented out for such purposes, except such as is exempt from taxation under the constitution and laws of this state. Such ordinance shall set forth the amounts levied for the several purposes for which the levies are made. Such tax shall be levied by the city council on property within the city as assessed under current state law and shall take their digest from that prepared by the county tax collector for county taxes for the current year. 
(Code 1972, § 25-1) 
Sec. 19-26. - Taxation of property partly within, partly without, city limits. 
    If improved real estate lies partly within and partly without the city, only that part of the real estate and that part of its improvements that lie within the city shall be taxable, unless the owner declares the entire tract to be within the city. The value for taxation of that part of such real estate and that part of the improvements that lie within the city shall be the proportionate value of such real estate and improvements within the city of the total value of such real estate and improvements. 
(Code 1972, § 25-7) 
Sec. 19-27. - Due date for taxes; tax book or notices. 
    All taxes shall be due as established by the annual millage ordinance, at which time the city clerk shall furnish the city tax collector with a book showing the amount of tax due, such book containing receipts for such taxes properly made out. In lieu of a book as prescribed above, the city clerk and treasurer is hereby authorized to prepare taxes on individual properties on individual tax notices, such notices to be in consecutive number. 
(Code 1972, § 25-8) 
Sec. 19-28. - Discount for early payment of taxes. 
    If city taxes are paid on or before the date established by the annual millage ordinance, a discount as provided in such millage ordinance shall be allowed. 
(Code 1972, § 25-9) 
Sec. 19-29. - Time for payment of taxes without interest. 
    The time for payment of city taxes without interest shall be as established by the annual millage ordinance, after which date interest shall be charged and the city clerk shall issue fi. fas. against all taxes unpaid. 
(Code 1972, § 25-10) 
Sec. 19-30. - Penalties for delinquent payment of taxes; issuance of execution. 
    Upon all property taxes not paid on or before the date established by the annual millage ordinance, a penalty of one percent per month shall be added and collected by the city clerk and treasurer. If such tax is not paid before the date established by the annual millage ordinance, the city clerk shall issue a tax execution for the tax and penalty and an execution fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges against the property of the defaulting tax payer directed to the chief of police or to any other officer designated by the city council for that purpose, who shall proceed to collect the same according to law. 
(Code 1972, § 25-11) 
Sec. 19-31. - Duties of city clerk as tax collector. 
    The city clerk shall be tax collector for the city, and as such he shall give notice to each tax payer by notice by regular mail. Each notice shall contain the amount of taxes due the city, the penalty schedule and whatever else the city council directs. 
(Code 1972, § 25-12) 
Sec. 19-32. - Liens for taxes. 
    Liens for taxes due the city shall cover the taxable property of taxpayers from January 1 until such taxes are paid. 
(Code 1972, § 25-13) 
Sec. 19-33. - Levy of fieri facias for taxes. 
    Whenever any fieri facias shall issue against any person who has property subject to taxation by the city, or who is subject to taxation by the city, or against any property in the city subject to taxation, when the owner is unknown, for taxes due the city, it shall be the duty of the chief of police or his deputy forthwith to levy the same upon the property of the defendant, or a sufficiency thereof to satisfy the execution and cost, or against the property where the owner thereof is unknown. 
(Code 1972, § 25-14) 
Sec. 19-34. - Sale of property for unpaid taxes generally. 
    Whenever the chief of police or his deputy shall levy any execution for unpaid taxes upon any goods, chattels, lands or tenements, he shall advertise the same in the newspaper in the city wherein the sheriff's advertisements for the county are advertised, once a week for four weeks prior to the day of sale; and he shall, on the first Tuesday of the month in which the property was advertised to be sold, between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., sell the property levied on, in front of the court house in the county, at public outcry, and shall knock down such property to the highest bidder, execute titles to the same, and place the purchaser in possession of the property sold, as at sheriff's sales in the state. Notice of such levy and sale shall be given to the owner and/or tenant in possession, and any holder of a security interest in the real estate shall receive written notice of such levy as provided by state law. 
(Code 1972, § 25-15) 
Sec. 19-35. - Special provisions as to sale of perishable property for taxes. 
    Whenever the chief of police or his deputy shall levy on any personal property by virtue of a tax fi. fa., and the same is of a perishable nature or liable to deteriorate in value from keeping, or there is expense in keeping the same, upon these facts being made to appear to the mayor when the council is not in session, by written statement of the chief of police or his deputy an order may be passed requiring the chief of police or his deputy to advertise the property at two or more public places in the city for at least three days, and at the expiration of that time to sell the same in the same manner as other sales for taxes. 
(Code 1972, § 25-16) 
Sec. 19-36. - Liability of purchaser at tax sale. 
    Any person who may become the purchaser of any real or personal property at any sale for taxes made at public outcry by the chief of police or his deputy, and who shall fail or refuse to comply with the terms of such sale when requested so to do, shall be liable for the amount of the purchase money, and it shall be the option of the chief of police or his deputy to proceed against such purchaser for the full amount of the purchase money, or to resell such real or personal property, and then proceed against the first purchaser for the deficiency arising from such sale. 
(Code 1972, § 25-18) 
Sec. 19-37. - Redemption of land sold for unpaid taxes. 
    Whenever any land is sold upon execution for unpaid taxes, the owner thereof shall have the privilege of redeeming such land thus sold within one year, by paying the purchaser the amount paid by such purchaser for such land, with 20 percent interest thereon computed from the date of the purchase to the time of payment. 
(Code 1972, § 25-19) 
Sec. 19-38. - Purchase by city of land at tax sale-Generally. 
    Whenever at any sale of land by the city for taxes due, no one present shall bid for the property as much as the tax for which it is proposed to sell the same, and the officer's cost if any be due thereon, after such property shall have been cried a reasonable time, any duly appointed officer or agent of the city may bid off such property for the city, and the officer making such sale shall make to the city a deed to the property so sold, and deliver the same to the officer designated by the city to receive it, and the title acquired by the city at such sale and by such deed, shall be perfect, valid and binding, after the period provided for redemption by the owner in section 19-37 shall have elapsed, and there is no redemption by the owner, as if purchased by an individual or corporation, other than such city so purchasing; and the officer making the sale shall put the city, through any officer or person it may designate, in possession of the property so sold. 
(Code 1972, § 25-20) 
Sec. 19-39. - Same-City clerk designated as city's purchaser. 
    The city clerk is hereby designated as the officer to buy any property described in section 19-38 under the circumstances mentioned therein and to receive the deed for the city and take possession thereof from the chief of police for the city. 
(Code 1972, § 25-21) 
Cross reference- City clerk and treasurer, § 2-136 et seq. 
Sec. 19-40. - Sale of land purchased by city at tax sale. 
    Neither the city council, during whose term of service any sale provided for in section 19-39 shall take place, nor any subsequently elected governing board, shall be capable of diverting or alienating the title of the corporation to any property so purchased, except by a public sale of the same to the highest bidder unless otherwise provided by law. 
(Code 1972, § 25-22) 
Sec. 19-41. - Garnishment for taxes. 
(a)  When the tax collector can find no property of the defendant on which to levy any tax execution, it shall be his duty to have an entry to that effect made on such execution; and such tax collector may then issue summons of garnishment against any person whom he may believe is indebted to the defaulting taxpayer, or who may have property, money or effects in his hands, and such summons of garnishment shall be served by the tax collector as aforesaid, or by the sheriff, or his deputy, or any constable of the county in which the garnishee may reside, at least 15 days before the sitting of the court to which the same is made returnable, and when so served shall be returned to the superior court of the county as aforesaid. 
(b)  Such tax collector shall enter on the execution the name of the person garnished, and return such execution to the superior court, and all subsequent proceedings shall be the same as now provided by law in relation to garnishment in other cases when judgment has been obtained or execution issued. 
(c)  When the tax collector desires to enforce the payment of taxes due the city by garnishment, as above provided, it shall not be necessary for the said tax collector to make the affidavit or give the bond required by law in other cases of garnishment. 
(Code 1972, § 25-24) 
Secs. 19-42-19-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EXCISE TAX ON HOTELS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14-13, § I, adopted Sept. 9, 2014 , repealed the former Art. III, §§ 19-51-19-56, and enacted a new Art. III as set out herein. The former Art. III pertained to special taxes and derived from Ord. No. 16-94, § I, adopted Nov. 22, 1994; Ord. No. 05-15, § I, adopted May 10, 2005. 

Sec. 19-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases shall, for the purposes of this article and except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, be defined as follows: 
    City. The City of Newnan, Georgia, wherein the city government is empowered to impose this tax by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. 
    City clerk. The duly appointed city clerk, or his designee. 
    Due date. The 20th day after the close of the monthly period for which the tax is to be computed. 
    Estimated tax liability. The lodging provider's prospective tax liability based upon the average monthly tax remittance in the prior fiscal year, as adjusted for change in tax rate or substantial change in circumstances due to damage to the hotel. 
    Folio. Primary documentation produced by a hotel that demonstrates interaction between the lodging provider and the occupant, and which, at a minimum, reflects the name and address given by the occupant, the date(s) of occupancy, the amount of rent charged for each date together with the amounts of applicable excise tax, and the method(s) of payment. 
    Guest room. Accommodations occupied, or intended, arranged, or designed for transient occupancy, by one or more occupants for the purpose of living quarters or residential use. 
    Hotel. Any facility or any portion of a facility, including any lodging house, rooming house, dormitory, Turkish bath, bachelor hotel, studio hotel, motel, motor hotel, auto or trailer court, truck stop, tourist cabin, campground, lodge, inn, time-share or other condominium, apartment community, public club, or private club, containing guest accommodations and which is occupied, or is intended or designed for occupancy, by paying guests, whether rent is paid in money, goods, labor, or otherwise. It does not include any hospital, asylum, sanitarium, orphanage, jail, prison, or other facility in which human beings are housed and detained under legal restraint. 
    Lodging provider. Any person operating a hotel in the city including, but not limited to, the owner or proprietor of such premises, lessee, sublessee, lender in possession, licensee or any other person operating such hotel; and who is subject to the taxation imposed for furnishing for value to the public any rooms, lodgings, or accommodations. 
    Monthly period. The calendar month of any year. 
    Occupancy. The use or possession, or the right to the use or possession of any guest room in a hotel or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the guest room. 
    Occupant. Any person who, for a consideration, uses, possesses, or has the right to use or possess any guest room in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license to use or other agreement, or otherwise. 
    Person. Any individual, firm, partnership, joint adventure, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, cooperative, estate, trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate, or any other group or combination acting as a unit, the plural as well as the singular number; excepting the United States, the State of Georgia and any instrumentality of either thereof upon which the city is without power to impose the tax. 
    Rent. The consideration received for occupancy valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits, and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the lodging provider to the occupant, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. 
    Tax. The tax on occupants imposed by this article, as provided for by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. 
( Ord. No. 14-13, § I, 9-9-14 ) 
Sec. 19-52. - Tax rate and use. 
(a)  There shall be paid for every occupancy of a guest room in a hotel in the city a tax at the rate of five percent of the amount of rent unless an exemption [exception] is provided under section 19-54. 
(b)  The proceeds of this tax shall be used in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(4.6)(A). 
( Ord. No. 14-13, § I, 9-9-14 ) 
Sec. 19-53. - Collection of tax by lodging provider. 
    Every lodging provider furnishing guest rooms in a hotel in the city shall collect a tax of five percent on the amount of rent from the occupant unless an exception is provided under section 19-54. The lodging provider shall provide a receipt to each occupant, which receipt shall reflect both the amount of rent and the amounts of this and other tax applicable. This tax shall be due from the occupant, and shall be collected by the lodging provider at the same time that the rent is collected. The lodging provider shall be liable to the city for the full amount received or collected as tax, whether collected appropriately or inappropriately; and for any amount of tax that should have been collected, but was not. 
(1)  Any person who receives or collects the tax or any consideration represented to be the tax from another person holds the amount so collected in trust for the benefit of the city and is liable to the city for the full amount collected, plus penalty and interest. 
(2)  An individual who controls or supervises the collection of the tax from another person, or an individual who controls the accounting for or remittance of the tax, and who willfully fails to remit or cause to be remitted the tax is liable as a responsible individual for an amount equal to the tax not remitted or caused to be remitted, plus penalty and interest. The dissolution of a corporation, partnership or other business or fraternal association does not affect a responsible individual's liability under this subsection. Furthermore, the liability imposed by this sub-section shall be in addition to any other penalty provided by law. 
( Ord. No. 14-13, § I, 9-9-14 ) 
Sec. 19-54. - Exceptions. 
    No tax shall be collected from an occupant who has occupied any guest room in a hotel for more than 30 continuous days; or from an occupant who certifies in writing that he is staying in such accommodations as a result of his residence having been destroyed by fire or other casualty; or from the United States and the State of Georgia or any instrumentality of either thereof; or from any official or employee of the state, its units of local government or any other instrumentality of the state, when traveling on official business and presenting written substantiation thereof or paying by state or local government credit or debit card; or from a foreign sovereign enjoying exemption by treaty or consular convention, when presenting substantiation issued by the United States Department of State. Occupancy provided without charge in money or otherwise is not subject to this tax. 
( Ord. No. 14-13, § I, 9-9-14 ) 
Sec. 19-55. - Registration of lodging provider; form and contents; execution; certificate of authority. 
    Every person engaging or about to engage in business as a lodging provider in the city shall immediately register with the city manager on a form provided by said official. Persons engaged in such business must so register not later than 30 days after the date that this article becomes effective September 9, 2014. Such registration shall set forth the name under which such person transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of his place(s) of business and such other information which would facilitate the administration of the tax as prescribed by this article. The registration shall be signed by the owner if a natural person; in case of ownership by an association or partnership, by a member or partner; in case of ownership by a corporation, by an officer. The city manager shall, after such registration, issue without charge a certificate of authority to each lodging provider to collect the tax from the occupant. A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of a lodging provider. Each certificate shall state the name and location of the business to which it is applicable. 
( Ord. No. 14-13, § I, 9-9-14 ) 
Sec. 19-56. - Determination generally; returns; payments. 
(a)  Due date of taxes. All amounts of such tax shall be due and payable to the city manager monthly on or before the 20th day of the month next succeeding the respective monthly period. The tax shall become delinquent for any monthly period after the 20th day of each succeeding month during which it remains unpaid. 
(b)  Penalty and interest for failure to pay tax by due date. A lodging provider who fails to make any return or to pay the amount of tax as prescribed, shall be assessed a specific civil penalty to be added to the tax in the amount of five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, if the failure is for one month or less; and an additional five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, for each additional month or fraction thereof in which such failure shall continue; provided, however, that the aggregate penalty for any single violation shall not exceed 25 percent or $25.00, whichever is greater. Delinquent amounts shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, until paid. 
(c)  Acceptance of delinquent return and remittance without imposing penalty and interest; authority; requirements. If the failure to make any return or to pay the amount of tax by the due date results from providential cause shown to the satisfaction of the governing authority of the city by affidavit attached to the return, and remittance is made within ten days of the due date, such return may be accepted exclusive of penalty and interest. 
(d)  Waiving of penalty and interest; authority. O.C.G.A. § 48-2-41, relating to the authority to waive interest, and § 48-2-43, relating to the authority to waive penalty, shall apply; provided, however, that the governing authority shall stand in lieu of the Georgia Commissioner of Revenue, and the city shall stand in lieu of the state. 
(e)  Penalty for fraud. In the case of a false or fraudulent return, or of failure to file a return where willful intent exists to defraud the city of any tax due, a civil penalty of 50 percent shall be assessed. 
(f)  Return; remittance; time of filing; lodging providers required to file; contents. On or before the 20th day of the month succeeding each monthly period, a return for the preceding monthly period together with appropriate remittance shall be filed with the city clerk. The return shall report the gross rent, taxable rent, exempt rent, amount of tax collected or otherwise due for the period, and such other information as may be required by the city clerk. However, if the estimated tax liability for any monthly period shall exceed $2,500.00 for a lodging provider who, in the prior fiscal year remitted tax greater than $2,500.00 in any three consecutive months, such lodging provider shall file an estimated return and remit not less than 50 percent of the estimated tax liability for the monthly period by the 20th day of that same monthly period. The amount of tax so remitted shall be credited against the amount to be due with the regular return for the monthly period to be filed on the 20th day of the succeeding month. 
(g)  Extension of time of filing; authority; requirements; remittance; penalty and interest. The governing authority of the city may, for good cause, extend the time for making returns for not longer than 30 days. No extension shall be valid unless granted in writing upon written application of the lodging provider. Such grant may not be applicable for longer period than 12 consecutive months. A lodging provider granted an extension shall remit tax equaling not less than 100 percent of the tax paid for the corresponding period of the prior fiscal year; such remittance to be made on or before the date the tax would otherwise come due without the grant of extension. No penalty or interest shall be charged during the first ten days of the extension period. Thereafter, interest shall be collected on the unpaid balance at the rate of one percent per month. 
(h)  Collection fee allowed lodging providers.
