Lodging providers collecting the tax shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and paying the amount due, if the amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be three percent of the amount due, but only if the amount due was not delinquent at the time of payment. 
( Ord. No. 14-13, § I, 9-9-14 ) 
Sec. 19-57. - Deficiency determinations. 
(a)  Recomputation of tax; authority to make; basis of recomputation. If the city clerk is not satisfied with the return or returns of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city by any lodging provider, he may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information within his possession or that may come into his possession. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly periods. 
(b)  Penalty and interest for failure to pay tax. Penalty and interest shall be assessed upon the amount of any determination, as provided by section 19-56. 
(c)  Notice of determination; service of The city clerk shall give to the lodging provider written notice of his determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail; if by mail, such service shall be addressed to the lodging provider at his address as it appears in the records of the city. Service by mail is complete when delivered by certified mail with a receipt signed by the addressee, or when made by statutory overnight delivery. 
(d)  Time within which notice of deficiency determination to be mailed. Except in cases of failure to make a return or of fraud, every notice of deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the 20th day of the calendar month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period should last expire. 
(e)  Appeal or protest of deficiency determination. The procedure for contesting a deficiency determination shall be as provided by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-380. 
( Ord. No. 14-13, § I, 9-9-14 ) 
Sec. 19-58. - Determination if no return made. 
(a)  Estimate of gross receipts. If any lodging provider fails to make a return, the city clerk shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the lodging provider, or as the case may be, of the amount of total rentals in the city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period or periods in respect to which the lodging provider failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is or may come into the possession of the city clerk. Written notice shall be given in the manner prescribed in subsection 19-57(c). 
(b)  Penalty and interest for failure to pay tax. Penalty and interest shall be assessed upon the amount of any determination, as provided by section 19-56. 
( Ord. No. 14-13, § I, 9-9-14 ) 
Sec. 19-59. - Collection of tax by city. 
(a)  Action for delinquent tax; time for. At any time within three years after any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected becomes due and payable, and at any time within three years after the delinquency of any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected, the city clerk may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction in the name of the city to collect the amount delinquent together with penalty, interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. 
(b)  Lodging provider selling or quitting business. If any lodging provider liable for any amount under this article sells out his business or quits his business, he shall make a final return and remittance within 15 days after the date of selling or quitting the business. 
(c)  Duty of successors or assignees of lodging provider to withhold tax from purchase money. If any lodging provider liable for any amount of tax, interest or penalty under this article sells out his business or quits the business, his successors or assigns shall withhold sufficiently from the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces from the city clerk either a receipt reflecting full payment or a certificate stating that no amount is due. 
(d)  Liability for failure to withhold. If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold from the purchase price as required, he shall be personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him to the extent of the purchase price. 
(e)  Credit for tax, penalty or interest paid more than once or erroneously or illegally collected. Whenever the amount of any tax, penalty or interest has been paid more than once, or has been erroneously or illegally collected or received by the city, it may be refunded by the governing authority. If the lodging provider or person determines that he has overpaid or paid more than once, which fact has not been determined by the city clerk, such person shall have three years from the date of payment to file a claim in writing stating the specific ground upon which the claim is founded. The claimant may request a hearing before the governing authority at which the claim and any other information available will be considered. The governing authority shall approve or disapprove the claim, and notify the claimant of its action. 
( Ord. No. 14-13, § I, 9-9-14 ) 
Sec. 19-60. - Administration of ordinance; record keeping. 
(a)  Authority of city clerk. The city clerk shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the collection of the tax. 
(b)  Records required from lodging providers, etc.; form. Every lodging provider renting guest rooms in the city shall preserve, for a minimum of three years, all folios, receipts, certificates of exemption and such other documents as the city clerk may prescribe, and in such form as he may require. Said records shall at all times be available for examination within the city. 
(c)  Examination of records; audits. The city clerk or any person authorized in writing by him may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any lodging provider renting guest rooms and any lodging provider liable for the tax, in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the lodging provider, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid. Such examination shall be conducted at the place of lodging provision, unless the city clerk shall stipulate another place within the city. 
(d)  Authority to require reports; contents. In administration of the provisions of this article, the city clerk may require the filing of reports by any person or class of persons having in their possession or custody information relating to the rental of guest rooms which are subject to the tax. The reports shall be filed with the city clerk when required by said official, and shall set forth the rental charged for each occupancy, the date(s) of occupancy, the basis for exemption, or such other information as the city clerk may prescribe. 
( Ord. No. 14-13, § I, 9-9-14 ) 
Sec. 19-61. - Criminal penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any lodging provider to willfully fail to make a return and pay the taxes due under this article by the due date provided. If the tax liability is $10,000.00 or less, any person who violates this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. If the tax liability is more than $10,000.00, any person who violates this section shall be guilty of a felony. 
(b)  Any lodging provider who fails, neglects, or refuses to collect the tax as provided this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $100.00, or confinement in the county jail for a term not to exceed three months, or both. 
(c)  Any lodging provider who fails or refuses to make any return as provided by this article, to keep adequate records, or to open them for inspection by the city, or to furnish other data reasonably requested by the city manager shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $100.00, or confinement in the county jail for a term not to exceed three months, or both. 
(d)  Any lodging provider who makes a false or fraudulent return with intent to evade the tax shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00, nor more than $300.00, or confinement for a term not to exceed three months in the county jail, or both. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any lodging provider to violate any other provision of this article for which punishment is not otherwise provided. Each and every day during any portion of which any violation under this section is committed, continued or permitted, shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punished accordingly. 
( Ord. No. 14-13, § I, 9-9-14 ) 
Secs. 19-62-19-70. - Reserved. 
Chapter 20 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183 of the Uniform Rules of the Road Act, speed limits within the city have been established. A schedule listing the street locations and applicable speed limits has been compiled by the city, an official copy of which is on file in the city clerk's office where it is available for reference during normal business hours. 
Charter reference- Authority of city to regulate operation of motor vehicles, § 1.4(30). 
Cross reference- Emergency services, Ch. 9; law enforcement, Ch. 12; municipal court, Ch. 13; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 14; vehicles for hire, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Authority to provide devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3(a)(4); Uniform Rules of the Road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; power of local authorities generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371; adoption of uniform rules of the road by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372; prosecution of traffic offenses, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Traffic law adopted. 
(a)  By reference. Pursuant to authority vested in the city, there is hereby adopted that certain act known as "The Uniform Act Regulating Traffic On Highways," O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq., and all amendatory acts thereto, known further as the uniform rules of the road; and also all provisions of chapters 1, 2, 5, 7, 8, 9, 11, 13 and 14 of O.C.G.A., title 40, Motor Vehicles and Traffic; are hereby adopted as a part of the traffic ordinances of the city with like effect as if the same were cited at length in this chapter except as provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Conflicts. If any conflict between provisions of "The Uniform Act Regulating Traffic On Highways" and traffic ordinances of the city exist, the traffic ordinances of the city shall prevail. 
(c)  Penalties. Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any section of this chapter shall be punished as provided in section 1-14. 
(Code 1972, § 15-01) 
Sec. 20-2. - Scope of traffic regulations. 
(a)  Obedience to regulations. It shall be unlawful for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required in this chapter. 
(b)  Obedience to police, fire department personnel. No person shall wilfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of a police officer or member of the fire department. 
(Code 1972, § 15-1) 
Sec. 20-3. - Applicability of traffic regulations. 
(a)  Persons propelling pushcarts, riding or driving animals. Every person propelling any pushcart or riding an animal upon a roadway, and every person driving any animal-drawn vehicle, shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the driver of any vehicle, except those provisions of this chapter which by their very nature can have no application. 
(b)  Public employees. The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the driver of any vehicle owned by or used in the service of the United States, this state, county or city, and it shall be unlawful for any such driver to violate any of the provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise permitted in this chapter or by state statute. 
(Code 1972, § 15-2) 
Sec. 20-4. - Applicability of provisions to authorized emergency vehicles. 
(a)  Definition. The term "authorized emergency vehicle" shall include vehicles of the fire department, police vehicles and such ambulances and emergency vehicles of municipal departments or public service corporations as are designated or authorized by the city. 
(b)  Applicability of regulations. The provisions of this chapter regulating the operation, parking and standing of vehicles shall apply to authorized emergency vehicles except as set out in this section. A driver when operating any such vehicle in an emergency, except when otherwise directed by a police officer, may: 
(1)  Park or stand notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign, but only after slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation. 
(3)  Exceed the prima facie speed limits so long as he does not endanger life or property. 
(4)  Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified directions so long as he does not endanger life or property. 
(c)  Siren, bell, light required. The exemptions granted in subsection (b) in reference to the movement of an authorized emergency vehicle shall apply only when the driver of the vehicle sounds a siren, bell or exhaust whistle as may be reasonably necessary and the vehicle displays a lighted lamp visible from the front as a warning to others. 
(d)  Duty. The foregoing exemptions shall not, however, protect the driver of any such vehicle from the consequences of his reckless disregard of the safety of others. 
(Code 1972, § 15-3) 
Sec. 20-5. - Hitchhiking. 
(a)  Thumbing ride. It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to thumb or solicit by thumb a ride in a motor vehicle. 
(b)  Soliciting ride. It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to stand on the streets in the city with the intent and purpose of soliciting a ride in a motor vehicle. 
(Code 1972, § 15-4) 
Sec. 20-6. - Operation of bicycles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle at any time on any sidewalk located within the first fire district of the city. It shall be lawful for persons to ride bicycles in other sections of the city; however, pedestrians on the sidewalks have the right-of-way on the sidewalks. Operators of bicycles on sidewalks outside the first fire district shall grant the right-of-way and yield to pedestrians. It is further ordained that no bicycles shall be operated on any sidewalk after dark unless equipped with proper lighting. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person riding a bicycle to do so without regard to the right-of-way of pedestrians and vehicular traffic, or to ride in a reckless, boisterous or disorderly manner. 
(Code 1972, § 15-5) 
Sec. 20-7. - Riding bicycle without light. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle in the city after dark, without a light so attached to the bicycle as to cast a light in the direction in which the rider is traveling. 
(Code 1972, § 15-6) 
Sec. 20-8. - Skating on roadways. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to skate on any of the roadways within the city. 
(Code 1972, § 15-7) 
Sec. 20-9. - Skating on sidewalks in first fire district. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to skate on the sidewalk within the first fire district. 
(Code 1972, § 15-8) 
Secs. 20-10-20-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TRAFFIC-CONTROL SIGNS, SIGNALS, MARKINGS AND DEVICES 

Sec. 20-36. - Authority to place and maintain signs, signals and devices. 
    The chief of police as traffic engineer shall place and maintain traffic-control signs, signals and devices when and as required under the traffic ordinances and regulations of the city, to make effective the provisions of such regulations, and shall place and maintain such additional traffic-control devices as are deemed necessary to regulate traffic under the traffic regulations of the city or under state law, or to guide and warn traffic. 
(Code 1972, § 15-19) 
Sec. 20-37. - Traffic signs; effect of provisions requiring same. 
    No provision of this chapter for which signs are required shall be enforced against an alleged violator if at the time and place of the alleged violation an official sign is not in proper position and sufficiently legible to be seen by an ordinarily observant person. Whenever a particular section does not state that signs are required, such erection shall be effective even though no signs are erected or in place. 
(Code 1972, § 15-20) 
Sec. 20-38. - Applicability to drivers of vehicles. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall obey the instructions of any official traffic-control device applicable thereto, placed in accordance with the traffic regulations of the city, unless otherwise directed by a police officer, subject to the exceptions granted the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle in this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 15-21) 
Sec. 20-39. - Traffic-control signal legend. 
    Electric traffic signals shall be a green, a red and an amber light. When a green traffic light is flashed or illuminated, the driver of a vehicle shall drive or proceed in the direction in which the green light is pointing. When an amber light is flashed or illuminated, the driver of a vehicle must observe caution and bring his automobile to a stop, and not proceed until a green light is again flashed or illuminated. When a red light is flashed or illuminated, the driver of a vehicle must stop and not proceed or drive in the direction in which the red light is pointing until the green light is flashed or illuminated. 
(Code 1972, § 15-22) 
Sec. 20-40. - Compliance with traffic signals required. 
    It shall be the duty of every person driving or in charge of a moving vehicle in the city to observe and comply with the traffic signals in the city, at and where the signals are installed. 
(Code 1972, § 15-23) 
Sec. 20-41. - Pedestrians to obey electric traffic-control signals. 
    It shall be the duty of pedestrians in the city to observe the green, amber and red electric traffic lights in the city. It shall be unlawful for any pedestrian in the city to cross or attempt to cross any street in the city against any electric traffic signal. Pedestrians in the city shall be privileged to cross the streets of the city at crossings where electric traffic signals are installed only when the green light is flashed or illuminated and shall then cross the street in the direction in which the green light, when illuminated or flashed, is pointing. 
(Code 1972, § 15-24) 
Sec. 20-42. - Applicability of provisions regarding electric traffic-control signals. 
    The terms of this article shall not apply or be enforced when electric traffic signals are not illuminated and being used to give the signals outlined in this article. 
(Code 1972, § 15-25) 
Sec. 20-43. - Signs permitting right turn on red light. 
    Signs shall be installed on all traffic lights on streets in the city, reading as follows: "After full stop, right turn on red light." 
(Code 1972, § 15-26) 
Sec. 20-44. - Authority as to changing of traffic lights. 
    The changing of traffic lights shall be left to the police chief and the city manager. 
(Code 1972, § 15-27) 
Sec. 20-45. - One-way streets and alleys; signs required. 
    Whenever any ordinance of the city designates any one-way street or alley the chief of police as traffic engineer shall place and maintain signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulation shall be effective unless such signs are in place. Signs indicating the direction of lawful traffic movement shall be placed at every intersection where movement of traffic in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(Code 1972, § 15-28) 
Sec. 20-46. - Operation upon one-way streets. 
    When appropriate signs giving notice thereof are erected, traffic upon one-way streets or parts of streets shall proceed only in the direction indicated. 
(Code 1972, § 15-53) 
Sec. 20-47. - Through streets; traffic boulevards; signs required. 
    Whenever any ordinance of the city designates and describes a through street or traffic boulevard, it shall be the duty of the chief of police as traffic engineer to place and maintain a stop sign on each and every street intersecting such through street or traffic boulevard or intersecting that portion thereof described and designated as a through street or traffic boulevard by such ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 15-29) 
Sec. 20-48. - "Stop" intersections; designation, signs required. 
    Whenever any ordinance or regulation of the city designates intersections as "stop" intersections, the chief of police as traffic engineer shall erect stop signs at every intersection so designated. 
(Code 1972, § 15-30) 
Sec. 20-49. - Duty when entering "stop" intersections. 
    When appropriate signs giving notice thereof are erected, vehicles approaching a "stop" intersection shall be brought to a complete stop before proceeding into or across the same. 
(Code 1972, § 15-55) 
Sec. 20-50. - Hazardous intersections; designation, signs required. 
    Whenever an ordinance or regulation of the city designates intersections as having particular hazards, upon other than through streets, the chief of police acting as traffic engineer shall determine whether vehicles shall stop at one or more entrances to any such stop intersection, and shall erect a stop sign at every such place where a stop is required. 
(Code 1972, § 15-31) 
Sec. 20-51. - Turning markers, buttons, signs. 
(a)  Placement. The chief of police as traffic engineer shall place markers, buttons or signs within or approaching intersections indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning at such intersections, and such course to be traveled as so indicated shall conform to that prescribed by law or ordinance. 
(b)  Duty of driver. When authorized markers, buttons or other indications are placed within or approaching an intersection indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning thereat, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of such indications. 
(Code 1972, § 15-32) 
Sec. 20-52. - Restricted turn signs. 
(a)  Placement. Whenever an ordinance or regulation of the city shall determine those intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall not make a right or left turn, the chief of police as traffic engineer shall place proper signs at such intersections. The making of such turns may be prohibited between certain hours of any day and permitted at other hours, in which event the same shall be plainly indicated on the signs, or the signs may be removed when such turns are permitted. 
(b)  Duty of driver. Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right, left or U-turn is permitted, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of any such sign. 
(Code 1972, § 15-33) 
Sec. 20-53. - Crosswalks, safety zones, traffic lanes; designation. 
    The chief of police as traffic engineer is hereby authorized: 
(1)  To designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in his opinion there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at such other places as he may deem necessary. 
(2)  To establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as he may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians. 
(3)  To mark lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places as he may deem advisable, consistent with the traffic regulations of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 15-34) 
Sec. 20-54. - Play streets; establishment, designation. 
(a)  Placement of signs. Whenever any ordinance or regulation of the city declares any street or part thereof a play street, the chief of police as traffic engineer shall place appropriate signs or devices in the roadway indicating and helping to protect the same. 
(b)  Duty of driver. Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating any street or part thereof as a play street, no person shall drive a vehicle upon any such street or portion thereof except drivers of vehicles having business or whose residences are within such closed area, and then any such driver shall exercise the greatest care in driving upon any such street or portion thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 15-35) 
Secs. 20-55-20-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES 

Sec. 20-76. - Careless, reckless operation prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any driver or person in charge of an automobile, motorcycle or other motor vehicle, to operate the same in a careless or reckless manner. Such automobile, motorcycle or other vehicle must be operated with due regard to the safety of persons upon the streets and public places, and in such manner as to avoid collision therewith. 
(Code 1972, § 15-46) 
Sec. 20-77. - Vehicles to be properly equipped. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a vehicle upon the streets of the city which is not equipped in conformity to and compliance with applicable provisions of state law. 
(Code 1972, § 15-47) 
Sec. 20-78. - Drivers to observe rules of road, drive on right-hand side of roadways. 
    Every person operating a motor vehicle must observe the rules of the road, keep to the right-hand side of the street or roadway and drive to the right of the guides or signposts maintained by the city in such streets or roadways. 
(Code 1972, § 15-48) 
Sec. 20-79. - Drivers with ability impaired by alcohol or drugs. 
(a)  A person shall not drive or be in actual physical control of any moving vehicle while: 
(1)  Under the influence of alcohol. 
(2)  Under the influence of any drug to a degree which renders him incapable of safely driving. 
(3)  Under the combined influence of alcohol and any drug to a degree which renders him incapable of safely driving. 
(b)  The fact that any person charged with violating this section is or has been legally entitled to use a drug shall not constitute a defense against any charge of violating this section. 
(c)  Every person convicted of violating this section shall be punished by imprisonment for not less than ten days nor more than one year, or by fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $1,000.00, or by both such fine and imprisonment. On a second or subsequent conviction within three years, he shall be punished by imprisonment for not less than 90 days nor more than one year, and, in the discretion of the court, a fine of not more than $1,000.00. The foregoing limitations on punishment also shall apply when a defendant has been convicted of violating by a single transaction more than one of four provisions of subsection (a) of this section; provided, that no provision of this section shall be construed so as to deprive the court imposing the sentence of the power given by law to the court to stay or suspend the execution of such sentence or to place defendant on probation. 
(d)  Upon the trial of any civil or criminal action or proceeding arising out of acts alleged to have been committed by any person while driving or in actual physical control of a vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or drugs, evidence of the amount of alcohol or drug in a person's blood at the alleged time, as determined by a chemical analysis of the person's blood, urine, breath or other bodily substance, shall be admissible. Where such a chemical test is made, the following provisions shall apply: 
(1)  Chemical analysis of the person's blood, urine, breath, or other bodily substance to be considered valid under the provisions of this section shall have been performed according to methods approved by the state crime laboratory and by an individual possessing a valid permit issued by the state crime laboratory for this purpose. The state crime laboratory is authorized to approve satisfactory techniques or methods, to ascertain the qualifications and competence of individuals to conduct analyses, and to issue permits which shall be subject to termination or revocation at the discretion of the state crime laboratory. 
(2)  When a person shall submit to a blood test at the request of a law enforcement officer under the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-5-55 only a physician or registered nurse (or other qualified person) may withdraw blood for the purpose of determining the alcoholic content therein. This limitation shall not apply to the taking of breath or urine specimens. 
(3)  The person tested may have a physician, or a qualified technician, chemist, registered nurse, or other qualified person of his own choosing administer a chemical test in addition to any administered at the direction of a law enforcement officer. The justifiable failure or inability to obtain an additional test by a person shall not preclude the admission of evidence relating to the test taken at the direction of a law enforcement officer. 
(4)  Upon the request of the person who shall submit to a chemical test at the request of a law enforcement officer, full information concerning the test shall be made available to him or his attorney. The arresting officer at the time of arrest shall advise the person arrested of his rights to a chemical test according to this section. 
(5)  Percent by weight of alcohol in the blood shall be based upon grams of alcohol per 100 cubic centimeters of blood. 
(e)  Upon the trial of any civil or criminal action or proceeding arising out of acts alleged to have been committed by any person while driving or in actual physical control of a moving vehicle while under the influence of alcohol, the amount of alcohol in the person's blood at the time alleged as shown by chemical analysis of the person's blood, urine, breath or other bodily substance shall give rise to the following presumptions: 
(1)  If there was at that time 0.05 percent or less by weight of alcohol in the person's blood, it shall be presumed that the person was not under the influence of the alcohol. 
(2)  If there was at that time in excess of 0.05 percent but less than 0.08 percent by weight of alcohol in the person's blood, such fact shall not give rise to any presumption that the person was or was not under the influence of alcohol, but such fact may be considered with other competent evidence in determining whether the person was under the influence of alcohol. 
(3)  If there was at that time 0.08 percent or more by weight of alcohol in the person's blood, it shall be presumed that the person was under the influence of alcohol. 
(Code 1972, § 15-49) 
State Law reference- Chemical tests for alcohol or drugs in blood, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-392. 
Sec. 20-80. - Applicability of speed regulations to emergency vehicles. 
    The provisions of the city's traffic schedule with respect to speed limits shall not be applicable to authorized emergency vehicles being operated in response to emergency conditions, nor to automobiles of physicians, nor to ambulances responding to emergency calls. 
(Code 1972, § 15-52) 
Sec. 20-81. - Duty to stop upon entering traffic boulevard. 
    Any person operating a vehicle from any intersecting street into or onto that portion of a street designated a traffic boulevard shall, before driving such vehicle into or onto such boulevard, bring his vehicle to a full and complete stop. It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle from any intersecting street into that portion of a street designated a traffic boulevard without bringing his vehicle to a full stop before driving the same from such intersecting street onto or into such street. 
(Code 1972, § 15-54) 
Sec. 20-82. - U-turns prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of a vehicle to make a complete or U-turn at any point in the city. 
(Code 1972, § 15-56) 
Sec. 20-83. - Left turns in business district. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make a left turn at any of the intersections in the business district of the city when an appropriate sign has been erected by the police department prohibiting left turns. 
(Code 1972, § 15-57) 
Sec. 20-84. - Noisy vehicles; operation prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make any unusual or unnecessary noise in the operation or use of any motor vehicle in the city. 
(Code 1972, § 15-58) 
Sec. 20-85. - Adequate muffler required; "gutted," "cut-out" muffler prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motor vehicle or motorcycle in the city with a muffler that is not in good repair or with a muffler that has been "gutted, cut-out" or has been so altered so as to make it produce noises or sounds. It shall also be unlawful for any person to sell within the city any muffler that is not in good repair or that has been "gutted, cut-out" or has been so altered so as to make it produce noises or sounds. 
(Code 1972, § 15-61) 
Sec. 20-86. - Sounding horns on automobiles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, operating an automobile in the city, or any occupant of any automobile in the city, to blow or sound the horn on the automobile except in a reasonable manner for the purpose of warning persons of the approach of such vehicle. 
(Code 1972, § 15-59) 
Sec. 20-87. - Use of signal device on automobile, different from horn. 
    It shall be unlawful for any operator of any automobile in the city, or the occupant of any automobile in the city, equipped with a signal device or horn different from the signal device or horn customarily installed on automobiles or that is equipped with a musical horn device to sound, blow or play the device in the city, except to warn persons of the approach of the automobile; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to emergency vehicles of the police and fire departments or to ambulances. 
(Code 1972, § 15-60) 
Sec. 20-88. - Driving on sidewalks; prohibited, exception. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or place any motor vehicle on any sidewalk or crossway, or in any street which intersects any sidewalk in such manner as to prevent the free passage of persons; provided, that draymen may, subject to the direction of the chief of police, temporarily use the sidewalks in loading or unloading merchandise. 
(Code 1972, § 15-62) 
Sec. 20-89. - Duty of vehicle operator in event of accident. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating a motor vehicle in the city to fail to stop and render aid if and when the driver of any such vehicle collides with any person, vehicle or animal in the city. 
(Code 1972, § 15-63) 
Sec. 20-90. - Operation of motor scooters, minibikes, go-carts and similar vehicles prohibited. 
(a)  The operation of motor scooters, minibikes and go-carts or similar motorized vehicles which do not conform to the standards of motor vehicles and which are not duly licensed by the state and the driver of which is not licensed to operate a motor vehicle by the state is hereby prohibited upon the streets and sidewalks of the city. 
(b)  The finding of any person so operating shall be charged with a misdemeanor and dealt with according to statutes of the city and the state. 
(Code 1972, § 15-64) 
Sec. 20-91. - Right-of-way rules. 
(a)  The vehicle to the right shall have the right-of-way at any unmarked street intersection. All motor vehicles shall yield the right-of-way to any vehicle approaching from the right. 
(b)  The driver of a vehicle approaching an intersection shall yield the right-of-way to a vehicle which has entered the intersection from a different highway. 
(c)  When two vehicles enter an intersection from different highways at approximately the same time the driver of the vehicle on the left shall yield the right-of-way to the vehicle on the right. 
(d)  When the intersection is designated as a "Yield" intersection, the driver of a vehicle approaching a "Yield" sign shall, in obedience to such sign, slow down to a speed reasonable under existing conditions and shall yield the right-of-way to any vehicle in the intersection or approaching on another highway so closely as to constitute an immediate hazard during the time such driver is moving within and across the intersection; provided, however, that a driver approaching a "Yield" sign and driving past same without stopping and becoming involved in a collision with a vehicle moving within and across such intersection shall be deemed prima facie to have failed to yield the right-of-way. 
(e)  The driver of a vehicle within an intersection intending to turn to the left shall yield the right-of-way to any vehicle approaching from the opposite direction which is within the intersection or so close thereto as to constitute an immediate hazard, but such driver, having so yielded and having given a signal when and as required by this law, may make such left turn and the drivers of all other vehicles approaching the intersection from such opposite direction shall yield the right-of-way to the vehicle making the left turn. 
(f)  The driver of a vehicle shall stop as required by this section at the entrance to a through highway and shall yield the right-of-way to other vehicles which have entered the intersection from such through highway or which are approaching so closely on such through highway as to constitute an immediate hazard, but such driver having so yielded may proceed and the drivers of all other vehicles approaching the intersection on such through highway shall yield the right-of-way to the vehicle so proceeding into or across the through highway. 
(g)  The driver of a vehicle shall likewise stop in obedience to a stop sign as required in this article at an intersection where a stop sign is erected at one or more entrances thereto although not a part of a through highway and shall proceed cautiously, yielding to vehicles not so obliged to stop which are within the intersection or approaching so closely as to constitute an immediate hazard, but may then proceed. 
(h)  The driver of a vehicle about to enter or cross a highway from a private road or driveway shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on such highway. 
(i)  Any motor vehicle existing from any parking space or area from any street or on the square in the city shall yield the right-of-way to any oncoming vehicle. 
(Code 1972, § 15-65) 
Sec 20-92. - Speed limit generally; school zones. 
    A speed limit of 25 miles per hour is hereby established for all streets within the city with the exception of those streets indicated in section 20-93 of this code with the further exception of areas of certain streets designated as "School Zones." Speed limits within "School Zones" are hereby established at 20 miles per hour during school hours. 
(Ord. No. 14-93, § I, 6-21-93) 
Sec. 20-93. - Speed limits on specific streets. 
(a)  Established. Pursuant to Georgia Code 40, Article 9, section 40-6-183, of the Uniform Rules of the Road Act, for local authorities to alter lawful speed limits, the following speed limits within the city are established:

(b)  Violations. Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished as provided for by law. 
(Ord. No. 14-93, § II, 6-21-93; Ord. No. 95-24, 10-10-95; Ord. No. 96-23, 10-8-96; Ord. No. 00-15, § I, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 00-40, § 12-26-00; Ord. No. 04-03A, 2-24-04; Ord. No. 06-4, § I, 4-11-06; Ord. No. 12-6, § I(Exh. A), 5-22-12) 
Sec. 20-94. - Speed limit restrictions; construction sites. 
(a)  Notwithstanding the speed limits set forth in section 20-92 or section 20-93 herein, either the department of transportation or the city street superintendent are hereby authorized to establish a maximum speed limit through any construction site located on or adjacent to any street or highway within the city limits. 
(b)  Whenever speed zones are established pursuant to subsection (a) hereinabove by the department of transportation or the street superintendent, there shall be erected or posted a sign of adequate size at the beginning point of such speed zone designating the zone, the speed limit to be observed therein, and the minimum fine for exceeding such speed, and there shall be erected or posted at the end of such speed zone an adequate sign indicating the end of such speed zone, which sign shall also indicate such different speed limit as may then be observed. Where the speed limit established pursuant to subsection (a) hereinabove is at least ten miles per hour less than the established speed limit on the street or highway, there shall be erected at least 600 feet in advance of the beginning of the speed zone a sign of adequate size which shall bear the legend "Reduce Speed Ahead." 
(c)  A person convicted of exceeding the speed limit in any speed zone established pursuant to subsection (a) hereinabove shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of a high and aggravated nature and shall be punished as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 95-22, § I, 9-26-95) 
Sec. 20-95. - Definitions. 
(a)  Truck/trailers: A motorized vehicle having ten wheels or more and/or tandem axles which generally has attached thereto a trailer for the purposes of hauling. 
(b)  Designated truck route: Specific streets authorized for truck/trailer traffic within the corporate limits of the city. Those streets or roads are designated as: 
(1)  Georgia Highway 34, from its intersection with Interstate 85 to its intersection with Georgia Highway 34 By-Pass; and 
(2)  U.S. Highway 29 North from its intersection with the city limits to its intersection with Georgia Highway 34 By-Pass; and 
(3)  Georgia Highway 34 By-Pass. 
(Ord. No. 99-09, § 1, 3-9-99) 
Sec. 20-96. - Prohibited truck trailer travel; exceptions; signage. 
(a)  Through truck trailers not stopping for pick up or deliveries in the city are prohibited from traveling along any streets within the city limits, except along the designated routes as set forth in this section. Truck/trailer deliveries or pick ups within the corporate boundaries of the city are permitted. 
(b)  The city clerk shall keep and maintain accurate maps setting out truck routes and streets upon which truck traffic is permitted; the maps shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk and shall be available to the public. 
(c)  The chief of police shall cause those streets upon which truck traffic is prohibited to be clearly sign-posted to give notice that section 20-96 is in effect. 
(Ord. No. 99-09, § 1, 3-9-99) 
Sec. 20-97. - Violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable pursuant to the provisions of section 1-14 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 99-09, § 1, 3-9-99) 
Secs. 20-98-20-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Standing or parking vehicles containing livestock, § 4-8. 

Sec. 20-111. - Establishment of parking restrictions in designated areas. 
(a)  Placement of signs. When an ordinance or regulation of the city so provides, the city engineer, as traffic engineer, in consultation with the chief of police shall designate those streets or parts of streets in the city upon which parking shall be prohibited, or parking time limits established, or parking is otherwise restricted, and shall erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof. 
(b)  Effect of signs. When such signs are erected and in place, it shall be unlawful for any person to disobey the directions of such signs. 
(Code 1972, § 15-74; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-112. - Signs required to regulate parking. 
    Whenever by the provisions of this chapter or any other regulation of the city any parking time limit is imposed or parking is prohibited or restricted on designated streets or parts of streets, it shall be the duty of the city engineer, as traffic engineer, in consultation with the chief of police to erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulations shall be effective unless such signs are erected and in place at the time of any alleged offense. 
(Code 1972, § 15-75; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-113. - Parking parallel, on right-hand of street unless otherwise indicated; exception for one-way streets. 
    Except where otherwise indicated by appropriate signs, markings or other devices, all parking in the city shall be parallel to the curb, and along the right-hand side of the street facing in the direction of travel; provided, however, that upon one-way streets, vehicles may park along the left-hand side of the street facing in the direction of travel, unless such parking is otherwise prohibited. 
(Code 1972, § 15-76) 
Sec. 20-114. - Engine to be stopped, brakes set when vehicle is parked. 
    The person in charge of a motor vehicle shall not park the same upon a street with the engine running, but in departing therefrom shall stop such engine and set the brakes. 
(Code 1972, § 15-77) 
Sec. 20-115. - Lights on parked vehicles. 
    No motor vehicle shall be left standing on the streets of the city between sunset and sunrise unless there is displayed from the front and rear thereof appropriate illuminating devices. 
(Code 1972, § 15-78) 
Sec. 20-116. - Parking on sidewalk, prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked on any sidewalk in the city any automobile, truck or motor vehicle. 
(Code 1972, § 15-80) 
Sec. 20-117. - Parking between curb and sidewalk adjacent to street, prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked in that area between the curb and the sidewalk adjacent to any street in the city any automobile, truck or other motor vehicle. 
(Code 1972, § 15-79) 
Sec. 20-118. - Parking restrictions; first fire district; city property; other restrictions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked, any automobile or motor vehicle on a public street within the first fire district of the city for more than 24 hours in any one place. Except as provided in subsection (b), it shall also be unlawful for any person to so park any automobile or motor vehicle on a public street outside the first fire district of the city for more than 72 hours in any one place. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked, any automobile or motor vehicle on city property or within a city parking lot for more than 24 hours. This restriction shall not apply to city-owned vehicles. 
(c)  No motorized vehicle in excess of 7,000 pounds (empty weight), trailer, boat, vehicle not in operating condition or currently licensed, vehicle with more than four wheels or a total number of vehicles in excess of four as set forth in the zoning ordinance shall be permitted to be parked in front of or at the side of the main dwelling on a lot in a residential area or neighborhood, unless same is parked or stored completely within an enclosed garage or roofed carport. 
(d)  Notwithstanding the limitation set forth in paragraph (a) of this section, no motorized vehicle in excess of 7,000 pounds (empty weight) or trailer, boat or vehicle with more than four wheels shall be permitted to be parked or left standing along any street or roadway in any residential zoned area or neighborhood. The provisions of this subparagraph (c) shall not apply to vehicles making deliveries of goods or merchandise to residents or businesses located in such residential zoned area or neighborhood or to vehicles temporarily parked for the purpose of loading or unloading household or business goods and furnishings (moving van type vehicles). 
(Code 1972, § 15-81; Ord. No. 96-14, 7-9-96; Ord. No. 99-06, § 1, 1-12-99) 
Sec. 20-119. - Fire lanes, police and handicapped parking zones; designated, use restricted. 
(a)  Unless expressly authorized, by permit or otherwise, it shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked any vehicle of any kind within any area in the city where the curbing is marked by yellow lines. Excepted from the terms of this section are properly marked or licensed emergency or law enforcement vehicles. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked any vehicle of any kind within any area in the city designated and marked as a fire or emergency lane, access or alleyway. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked any vehicle of any kind within any area in the city designated as a handicapped zone unless identification as a handicapped vehicle is properly displayed. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked any vehicle of any kind within any area in the city designated 15-minute zone for any time exceeding 15-minutes. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked any vehicle of any kind within any area in the city designated commercial loading zoning unless actively loading or unloading and in no event for any time exceeding one hour. 
(Code 1972, § 15-82; Ord. No. 14-92, 5-11-92; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-120. - Parking adjacent to schools. 
(a)  Placement of signs. The city engineer, as traffic engineer, in consultation with the chief of police shall erect signs prohibiting parking upon that side of any street adjacent to any school property when it has been determined such parking would interfere with traffic or create a hazardous condition. 
(b)  Effect of signs. When official signs are erected prohibiting parking upon that side of a street adjacent to any school property, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(c)  Prohibited parking. It shall be unlawful for any person to park on Water Works Road and Sewell Road where such roads adjoin the premises of Newnan High School on any school day between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. It shall further be unlawful for any person to park on LaGrange Street and Armory Road, where such street or road adjoins the premises of Newnan High School between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on any school day. Excepted from these restrictions are students, teachers and administrators attending Newnan High School and persons having legitimate business to transact at Newnan High School. 
(Code 1972, § 15-83; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-121. - Parking on narrow streets. 
(a)  Placement of signs. The city engineer, as traffic engineer, in consultation with the chief of police shall erect signs prohibiting parking upon any street when the width of the roadway does not permit free and unobstructed passage of vehicles. 
(b)  Effect of signs. When official signs prohibiting parking are erected upon narrow streets as authorized in this section, no person shall park a vehicle upon any such street in violation of any such sign. 
(Code 1972, § 15-84; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-122. - Parking, standing on one-way roadways. 
(a)  Signs required. If a roadway includes two or more separate lanes and traffic is restricted to the same one-way direction upon each lane of any such roadway, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon the left-hand side of such one-way roadway unless signs are erected to permit such standing or parking. 
(b)  Placement of signs. The city engineer, as traffic engineer, in consultation with the chief of police shall determine when standing or parking may be permitted upon the left-hand side of any such one-way roadway and shall erect signs giving notice thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 15-85; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-123. - Hazardous or congested places. 
(a)  Placement of signs. The city engineer, as traffic engineer, in consultation with the chief of police shall designate by proper signs placed in which the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic. 
(b)  Effect of signs. When official signs are erected at hazardous or congested places as authorized in this section no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Code 1972, § 15-86; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-124. - Designation of curb loading zones. 
    The city engineer, as traffic engineer, in consultation with the chief of police shall determine the location of passenger and freight curb loading zones. hereinafter in this chapter referred to as commercial loading zones, and shall place and maintain appropriate signs or other devices indicating the same and stating the hours during which the restrictions thereof shall apply. 
(Code 1972, § 15-87; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-125. - Bus zones; designation, use restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked any vehicle except a bus within those areas where the curbing is marked by yellow lines and where there is a sign denoting the same as a parking space for buses, such areas being reserved for the use of buses only. 
(Code 1972, § 15-88) 
Sec. 20-126. - Taxicab zones; designation, use restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked any vehicle except a taxicab within those areas where the curbing is marked by yellow lines and where there is a sign denoting the same as a parking space for taxicabs only, such areas being reserved for the use of taxicabs only. 
(Code 1972, § 15-89) 
Sec. 20-127. - Taxicab parking regulated. 
(a)  Use of zones is exclusive. The taxicab companies of the city shall have the exclusive privilege of parking taxicabs in the spaces marked for such purposes. 
(b)  Manner of parking. Taxicabs must and shall park in the space at the points marked off for such taxicabs and must be parked within the lines so marked. 
(c)  Privilege is revocable. The privilege to park in the designated spaces is permissive only and can be revoked at any time by the mayor and city council. 
(d)  Prohibited parking. It shall be unlawful for the operator of any taxicab to park a taxicab at any place except the spaces designated for taxicabs. 
(Code 1972, § 15-90) 
Sec. 20-128. - Parking permits. 
    No permits for parking in the city shall be issued except to the county commissioners for their use while on official business and disabled persons holding doctor's certificates attesting to such disability. 
(Code 1972, § 15-91) 
Sec. 20-129. - Parking, making deliveries by certain vehicles restricted in first fire district. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked on any street within the first fire district of the city a truck and trailer or a trailer exceeding an overall length of 26 feet, for a period of more than one hour at a time in any one place. 
(b)  It shall further be unlawful to make more than one daily delivery to more than one business establishment or to daily pick up or receive goods, wares or merchandise from more than one business establishment with a tractor-trailer within the first fire district of the city between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked on any street outside the first fire district of the city a truck and trailer or a trailer exceeding an overall length of 26 feet, for a period of more than 12 hours at a time or overnight. 
(Code 1972, § 15-92; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-130. - Enforcement of parking regulations. 
(a)  Scope of section. Any and all vehicles parked on any public street or alley in the city shall at all times be subject to the supervision and control of the police force of the city and any officer thereof. This section shall also apply to parking of vehicles in an area where the curbing is marked by yellow lines, in an area designated as fire or emergency lane or in an area designated as a handicapped zone. 
(b)  Duty of enforcement. It shall be the duty of every member of the police department of the city and/or employee clothed with police powers to exercise supervision and control over vehicles parked on the public streets or alleys in the city and to prohibit as far as possible parking that obstructs such streets or alleys. This duty shall apply to enforcement of the parking restrictions set forth in section 20-119; in addition, the chief of police and the fire inspector shall have the duty and authority to issue citations for violations of the restrictions set forth therein. Reasonable discretion shall be exercised in the enforcement of this section. 
(c)  Obedience required. Every person who parks a vehicle on any public street or alley in the city shall park the vehicle subject to the supervision and control of the policeman and/or employees with police power in the city, and every such person shall, when requested or directed by any member of the police department and/or employee clothed with police powers, immediately move his automobile and park it in such place as shall be designated, or if a parking place is not designated to remove it from where it is parked at the time such owner is requested or directed to do so. 
(d)  Violations. It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to move any vehicle parked in the city on streets or alleys after requested or directed to move the vehicle by any member of the police department and/or any employee clothed with police powers. 
(Code 1972, § 15-93) 
Sec. 20-131. - Vehicle owner not to cause or permit parking violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to countenance, cause, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his name to stop, stand or park upon any of the public streets or public places in the city in violation of the provisions of this chapter. However, in no case shall two persons be penalized for any one parking violation. 
(Code 1972, § 15-94; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-132. - Penalty for parking violations. 
(a)  The charge for violation of a 15-minute parking restriction in any designated parking area shall be established by resolution of city council. If the violation is unpaid within seven days, the fine shall be doubled. 
(b)  The charge for violation of a designated handicapped parking space shall be established by resolution of city council. If the violation is unpaid within seven days, the fine shall be doubled. 
(c)  The charge for violation of a designated commercial loading zone shall be established by resolution of city council. If the violation is unpaid within seven days, the fine shall be doubled. 
(d)  Habitual offenders of parking regulations shall be assessed an additional charge as established by city council. Habitual offense shall be defined as conviction of five or more violations of section 20-134 or 20-135 within a calendar year. The habitual offender charge shall be assessed to violators on the fifth and each subsequent violation during the calendar year. 
(e)  If the fine is not paid within 30 days from the date of issuance, a warrant shall be issued for such person commanding such person to appear before the city recorder, and such person, if found guilty of willfully failing to pay the ticket within the prescribed time limit, shall be subject to the penalties prescribed in section 1-14 of this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 15-95; Ord. No. 02-92, 1-6-92; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-133. - Towing away of certain illegally parked vehicles. 
    Subject to state law requirements, the police chief is hereby authorized to tow away and store any vehicle parked in any of the following situations: 
(1)  In a 15-minute zone illegally for more than 30 minutes. 
(2)  In a commercial loading zone illegally for more than one hour. 
(3)  In a designated handicapped space without proper authorization. 
(4)  In the first fire district for more than 24 hours. 
(5)  Outside the first fire district within the city for more than 72 hours. 
(Code 1972, § 15-96; Ord. No. 20-90, 8-6-90; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-134. - Restricted parking in central business district. 
(a)  The city engineer, as traffic engineer, in consultation with the chief of police shall have the authority to determine the location of restricted parking within the city limits. Parking restrictions shall be placed to optimize the use of parking facilities while maintaining adequate traffic flow and safety. 
(b)  The following types of restricted parking shall be allowed: 
(1)  Fifteen-minute zones; 
(2)  Commercial loading zones; 
(3)  Handicapped spaces. 
(Code 1972, § 15-97; Ord. No. 13-89, 4-10-89; Ord. No. 21-90, 8-6-90; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-135. - No parking areas. 
(a)  Temple Avenue. No parking is permitted on Temple Avenue within the corporate limits of the city as described as follows: 
    Beginning at a point 1,065 feet (0.2 mile) east of mile post 8, south side of State Route 16 (Temple Avenue), which point is the west boundary line of Bank of Coweta, point marked by curb delineating west driveway of Bank; thence 159 feet east of point of beginning to east property line of Bank of Coweta; also, north side of State Route 16, between points directly opposite the points described above. 
(b)  Greenville Street. No parking is permitted on Greenville Street (SR 14) at M.P. 14.10 to 14.12, within the city as described as follows: 
    State Route 14, 16. Begin no parking on the east side of State Route 14 at M.P. 14.10 and continue to the north for a distance of 110 feet, M.P. 14.12. 
(c)  State Route 14 (US 29, Jackson Street). No parking is allowed any time on State Route 14 (US 29, Jackson Street), west side only, as follows: 
    Beginning at a point 75 feet north of Wesley Street (M.P. 0.25) and continuing south to Wesley Street (M.P. 0.26), a distance of 0.01 mile. 
(d)  State Route 14 (US 29, Jackson Street). No parking is allowed anytime on State Route 14 (US 29, Jackson Street) east side only, as follows: 
    Beginning at a point 75 feet north of Wesley Street (M.P. 0.25) and continuing south to Wesley Street (M.P. 0.26), a distance of 0.01 mile. 
(Code 1972, § 15-98) 
Sec. 20-136. - Use of parking spaces when doing work at building. 
    Persons doing temporary construction work at a building in the city and using trucks or other vehicles therefore, and desiring to occupy a parking space without being required to move the vehicles each two hours may apply for and obtain a parking permit, the same to be issued upon payment of a fee set forth in the city's schedule of fees per space to be occupied by the applicant for permit. Such permit shall allow the permit holder to occupy the number of spaces designated in the permit without regard to 24 hour and 72 hours limitations set forth in this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 15-99; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-137. - Handicapped parking-Law adopted. 
(a)  Pursuant to section 20-1 of this Code and pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-220 through 40-6-227, such sections of state law are hereby incorporated in this section by reference as and for the handicapped parking laws of this city with the like effect as if recited in this section. 
(b)  The sign designations for handicapped parking places shall be in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 40-6-221. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the failure of the property owner to properly mark and sign handicap parking places in accordance with law, it shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand or park any motor vehicle in any area on public or private property which has been clearly designated and reserved for use by handicapped persons in vehicles displaying a valid handicapped parking permit, unless such vehicle clearly displays a valid unexpired handicapped parking permit or unless there is attached to the vehicle a specifically designated license plate for disabled veterans or other disabled persons authorized under O.C.G.A. § 40-6-222(d). 
(Ord. No. 20-92, § 15-101, 8-24-92) 
Sec. 20-138. - Same-Enforcement. 
(a)  In addition to the enforcement authority set forth in section 20-130, the chief of police, or his designee, shall have the authority to appoint any person who is a citizen of the United States, is of good moral character, has not been previously convicted of a felony, and is a handicapped person as defined under state law, to enforce the provisions of the handicapped parking laws of the city. 
(b)  Each person appointed pursuant to this section shall complete an application, satisfactorily complete a course of training on handicapped parking enforcement, and take and subscribe an oath of office as prescribed by the appointing authority. 
(c)  Upon receipt of the application, the chief of police or his designee shall cause a complete and thorough investigation to be made of the applicant to determine his moral, physical and mental qualifications. 
(d)  Any person appointed under this section and sworn shall have the power to serve citations for violations for failure to comply with the handicapped parking laws of this city, in the manner as any law enforcement officer of the city, subject to the following limitations: 
(1)  No person so appointed shall be deemed a peace officer, nor have the general powers of a police officer, nor an employee of the city, nor receive any compensation therefrom. 
(2)  No person appointed shall be required to complete training or be certified as a peace officer. 
(3)  No person appointed shall have the power or duty to enforce any other traffic or criminal laws. 
(4)  No person appointed shall have the power to possess and carry firearms and other weapons for the purpose of enforcing the handicapped parking laws. 
(5)  No person appointed shall be entitled to any indemnification from the city for any injury or property damage sustained as a result of enforcement activities. Each authorized person shall specifically acknowledge that such person has no rights to any claim of injury or property damage resulting from handicap enforcement activities. 
(6)  The city shall not be liable or accountable for or on account of any act or omission of any person appointed pursuant to this section in connection with such person's enforcement of the handicapped parking laws. Each authorized person shall specifically hold harmless the city, its employees and agents, from liability for any such act or omission by such authorized person. 
(e)  Every person appointed under this section shall be required to wear a lapel badge for identification purposes while in the performance of his duty. 
(Ord. No. 20-92, § 15-102, 8-24-92) 
Secs. 20-139-20-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RAILROADS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Railroad companies, O.C.G.A. § 46-8-1 et seq. 

Sec. 20-156. - Maintenance of crossings, bridges, trestles. 
    It shall be the duty of all railroad companies entering the city to make, keep and maintain good and suitable crossings at all streets where their roadbeds cross; and they shall also keep and maintain all bridges and trestles in good and secure condition. 
(Code 1972, § 22-1) 
Sec. 20-157. - Notice of needed construction, repair. 
    In all cases in which a railroad company is required or liable by law to build bridges in the city or to keep bridges or crossings in the city in repair, on or across a street crossed by the tracks of such railroad company when the building of a new bridge, or the repair of the bridge already built is declared by the city council to be necessary or proper, railroad company shall be notified by the city council to commence the building or repair of such bridge within ten days and to prosecute the same in good faith to completion. 
(Code 1972, § 22-2) 
Sec. 20-158. - Service, contents of notice to construct, repair. 
    The notice provided for in section 20-157 shall be in writing, and shall be served by any policeman of the city, or the principal officer of such railroad company in the city, or by leaving the same at the principal office of the company in the city. Such notice shall contain a general plan or character of the bridge to be built or repaired and material of the same, or a description of the work to be done at a crossing, and also where the bridge to be built or repaired, or the crossing to be improved, is located. 
(Code 1972, § 22-3) 
Sec. 20-159. - Construction, repair by city in lieu of railroad. 
(a)  Authority. Should any railroad company fail or refuse to commence in good faith the building or repairing of a bridge or the repairing of a crossing within the time specified in the notice provided for in section 20-157 and in accordance with the provisions of sections 20-156, 20-157 and 20-158, or to notify the city of a refusal to comply with the notice served, then and in that event the city will proceed to do such work of building or repairing such bridge or crossing at the charge of such railroad company. 
(b)  Collection of cost. Within five days after the completion of such work the street superintendent shall report under oath in writing to the city clerk the amount and value of the services performed or expense incurred in such work, whereupon the clerk shall issue execution for the amount of such value or expense against such defaulting railroad company, to which execution a defense may be made and filed, on oath to the city council and heard by the city council on ten days' notice to such railroad company by the city, such notice to be in writing and served in the manner prescribed in section 20-158. If the issue of the illegality be found against the company filing the same, then the execution shall proceed, and shall be levied on any property of such company in the city and after advertising, as in cases of land sold for taxes, the same may be sold to satisfy the execution. 
(Code 1972, § 22-4) 
Sec. 20-160. - Failure to maintain bridges, crossings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any railroad company whose road crosses any streets in the city, to fail, neglect or refuse to have suitable crossings erected and kept in good repair at the different points on such roads where they cross the streets and public roads; or for any railroad company to refuse, neglect or fail to put in good order, all roads turned for the benefit of such railroad, or for any railroad company to neglect or refuse to build and keep in good repair, bridges of a proper width across their respective roads rendered necessary by excavation in building such road across the city streets. 
(Code 1972, § 22-5) 
Sec. 20-161. - Obstructions at railroad crossings. 
    The several railroad companies whose roads are in the city shall not allow any street to be obstructed by any cars or other things left at any of the crossings, and if it shall become necessary in loading or unloading freight to stop longer than five minutes, it shall be the duty of the conductor of such train of cars to uncouple his cars at the point of crossing to allow vehicles to pass without unnecessary delay or inconvenience. 
(Code 1972, § 22-6) 
Sec. 20-162. - Laying, repairing railroad track. 
(a)  Application to do work. Any railroad company that may desire to lay any railroad track, or to repair any track already laid with the city, shall, before doing so, present in writing to the city council an application to do such work, which application shall show the location of the proposed track or the proposed work to be done on the track already laid. The city council may authorize, modify or reject and refuse such application as may in their judgment be for the best interest of the public. 
(b)  Restoration of street and sidewalk. Any company to whom permission is given to do such work shall restore the sidewalk or street where any such work is done to the same condition that existed before such work was done, and in repairing any such street or sidewalk shall use material similar to that already installed. 
(c)  Violations. It shall be unlawful for any person to do any work, either by excavating earth or by laying crossties, stringers or rails, or to remove cross ties, for the purpose of laying or repairing railroad tracks, within the city without first making application to and obtaining the consent of the city council thereto. 
(Code 1972, § 22-7) 
Sec. 20-163. - Report of additional track laid. 
    It shall be the duty of each railroad company owning or operating trains in and through the city, to report the number of additional feet of track laid in the city, to the city clerk within ten days from the time that the work of laying additional track is completed. 
(Code 1972, § 22-8) 
Sec. 20-164. - Locomotive, railroad cars; maximum speed prescribed. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate or cause to be operated any locomotive or railroad car within the city, at a greater rate of speed than 25 miles per hour. The provisions hereof shall apply both to the railroad company and to the employee of such company in charge of such locomotive or railroad car. 
(Code 1972, § 22-9) 
Sec. 20-165. - Blowing whistles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating a locomotive engine to blow the whistle thereof within the city, except in cases of emergency to prevent injury to persons or property. 
(Code 1972, § 22-10) 
Sec. 20-166. - Flagmen at designated crossings. 
(a)  Duty of railroad. At those railroad crossings in the city not equipped with mechanical devices to indicate the approach of a train, it shall be the duty of the railroad company responsible for such crossing to place a flagman on duty at such crossing, between the hours from 6:00 a.m. until 6:00 p.m. each day. 
(b)  Duty of flagman. It shall be the duty of the flagman during such hours to flag such crossing at the approach of any railroad car or locomotive so that persons attempting to cross such tracks at such point will be warned of the approaching railroad car or locomotive. 
(c)  Police authority of flagman. The flagman while on duty shall be vested with all the authority of a police officer of the city and upon being employed shall appear before the mayor and take and subscribe the oath of a police officer. 
(Code 1972, § 22-11) 
Chapter 21 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes:

Laws 1974, p. 1700, which designates the board of water, sewerage, and light commission of the City of Newnan as the sole operational governing authority of the utility systems of the city; and Act No. 58 passed by the Georgia General Assembly and approved February 24, 1987, provides that Ga. Laws 1978, p. 2347, which provides that the board of water, sewerage and light commission is not empowered to discontinue utility services to the city or change the city any fee therefor, nor empowers the board to take title to and hold real property in its own name, or to set salaries of the persons serving as commissioners on the board, shall not be repealed or deleted on July 1, 1987, as a part of the State Constitution, but are specifically continued in force and effect on and after that date as a part of the State Constitution.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Water, sewerage and light commissioners-Organization. 
(a)  Present commissioners continued. The water, sewerage and light commissioners holding office in the city shall continue in office until the expiration of their respective terms of office and until their successors shall be elected and qualified. 
(b)  Terms of office. The term of office of any water, sewerage and light commissioner shall be three years, except that those elected to fill unexpired terms shall hold office only for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(c)  Eligibility and compensation. No person holding a commission as an officer of the city shall be eligible to election as a water, sewerage and light commissioner. Such commissioners shall receive such compensation as shall be determined by the city council from time to time. 
(Code 1972, § 26-1) 
Charter reference- Boards, commissions and authorities, § 3.2. 
Sec. 21-2. - Same-Powers and duties. 
(a)  Powers. The water, sewerage and light commission shall have complete control and management of the water, sewerage and light works of the city. They are hereby empowered to charge such sum as they deem just and proper for the use of water, sewerage and lights. They shall have authority and power to make all rules and regulations as in their discretion are necessary for the proper management and control of water, sewerage and lights, and shall have power to enforce such rules and regulations by refusing to supply, or by discontinuing the supply to any person who fails or refuses to comply with the rules and regulations. 
(b)  Duties. It shall be the duty of the water, sewerage and light commission to take charge of the water, sewerage and light works of the city, and to manage and control them for the best interest of the city, and the citizens thereof. They shall formulate rules for their own government, and for the government of employees and the management and control of the water, sewerage and light works of the city. They shall elect all employees who work for the commission, and fix their compensation. They shall purchase all material and supplies necessary for the operation and maintenance of the water, sewerage and light works. They shall lay such water mains and install such lights as shall be directed by the city council. They shall make or cause to be made to the city council a monthly statement showing the expenditures and revenues of each department; and at the end of the year they shall make to the city council a detailed statement for the year, which statement shall show all expenditures, and all revenues for the year. 
(Code 1972, § 26-2) 
Sec. 21-3. - Same-Scope, effect of rules. 
    All rules and regulations of the water, sewerage and light commission shall have all the force and effect of ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 26-3) 
Sec. 21-4. - Right of entry, right to terminate service. 
    The water, sewerage and light commission shall have the right at all reasonable hours to enter upon the premises where city water or lights are used or taken, for the purpose of inspecting pipes, wires or fixtures, setting and repairing meters, commencing or discontinuing service, and enforcing the rules generally. Each and every denial of this right will render the offending parties liable to the penalties imposed for the violation of this Code of Ordinances. The water, sewerage and light commission may terminate service in cases of emergency, and for repair or extension of the systems, they being the judges of the times and the necessity, reasonable notice to be given when practicable. 
(Code 1972, § 26-4) 
Sec. 21-5. - Liability for insufficient service. 
    Neither the water, sewerage and light commission nor the city shall be liable for insufficient or inadequate service. 
(Code 1972, § 26-5) 
Sec. 21-6. - Unauthorized receipt of utility services. 
    If any person after being notified by representatives of the water, sewerage and light commission that any utility service has been discontinued to such person, nevertheless continues to use or receive such service, such person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be liable to the penalties imposed by section 1-14. Each day that the offending party continues to use or receive such unauthorized utility service shall be deemed a new offense of this section and shall render such person liable for the additional penalties imposed therefor. 
(Code 1972, § 26-6) 
Sec. 21-7. - Delivery of suit or action against water, sewerage and light commission.
