    If any suit or action of any nature is brought against the Newnan Board of Water, Sewerage, and Light Commission, service of the summons and complaint shall be made by delivering a copy of the summons attached to a copy of the complaint to the chairman of the commission, who is the chief executive officer, or to the secretary of the commission, who is the clerk thereof, and a copy to the city clerk. 
(Code 1972, § 26-7) 
Sec. 21-8. - Defense of commissioners by city. 
    Pursuant to the grant of authority contained in O.C.G.A. § 45-9-21, the water, sewerage and light commission shall undertake to defend any civil, criminal or quasi-criminal actions brought or maintained against the water, sewerage and light commission, any elected or appointed official, or any employees of the water, sewerage and light commission in their individual capacity which arise out of the performance of their duties or are in any way connected therewith, whether based upon negligence, violation of contract rights, or violation of civil, constitutional, common law or statutory rights. However, no defense shall be furnished to any person charged with a criminal offense involving theft, embezzlement or other like crime with respect to the property or money of or in which the water, sewerage and light commission has an interest. Such costs of defense shall include but not be limited to attorney's fees, court costs, deposition costs, witness fees and compensation, and all other like costs, expenses and fees. 
(Code 1972, § 26-8) 
Secs. 21-9-21-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ELECTRICITY 

Sec. 21-36. - Tapping electric wires. 
    No electric wires shall be tapped except by an authorized employee of the water, sewerage and light commission under the supervision of the superintendent. 
(Code 1972, § 26-16) 
Sec. 21-37. - Application for service required. 
    Electrical current shall not be introduced into any building without application having been first made at the office of the water, sewerage and light commission, and permission to do so has been granted. 
(Code 1972, § 26-17) 
Sec. 21-38. - Installation, maintenance, replacement of meters. 
    Meters shall be installed in all premises where electric current is to be used. After the purchase of the first meter the city shall keep the same in repair and replace it with a new one when necessary, except in case of loss by fire, without any further expense to the property owner. No one but an authorized employee of the water, sewerage and light commission shall be allowed to install, remove or handle the meters. Should a meter become out of repair and fail to register, or register improperly, the consumer shall be charged at the average daily rate of consumption as was shown by the meter when the same was in order. 
(Code 1972, § 26-18) 
Sec. 21-39. - Service wires, wiring, etc.; cost, ownership. 
    Service wires from the mains to the premises shall be the property of the city, but the cost of all wiring, fixtures, lamps, etc., shall be paid for by the owner of the building or by the consumer. 
(Code 1972, § 26-19) 
Sec. 21-40. - Wiring to conform to rules, minimum standards. 
    All wiring shall be done according to the rules and minimum standards prescribed by the city, and no current shall be introduced into any premises until such rules and minimum standards have been complied with. 
(Code 1972, § 26-20) 
Sec. 21-41. - Due date for payment of installation charges. 
    All construction work, installation of lights and supplies for the same furnished by the water, sewerage and light commission shall be paid for on or before the first day of the month following the date when the work was completed and materials therefor furnished. 
(Code 1972, § 26-21) 
Sec. 21-42. - Charges for electric service. 
    Charges for consumption and use of electricity shall be fixed by the water, sewerage and light commission. 
(Code 1972, § 26-22) 
Sec. 21-43. - Notice of amount of electric bill. 
    Notice shall be given to consumers monthly of the amount of such consumers' electric bills for the preceding month. 
(Code 1972, § 26-23) 
Sec. 21-44. - Charge, payment for unauthorized use of electricity. 
    If current is used without the knowledge of the water, sewerage and light commission by any person, and it should in any way come to their knowledge that the current had been used, a bill will be made against the user for the time the current has been used or the quantity shown by the meter to have been used, and service shall be discontinued and not resumed until the bill is settled. 
(Code 1972, § 26-25) 
Secs. 21-45-21-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GAS 

Sec. 21-66. - Determination of meter location. 
    The location of the gas meter for any location shall be determined by the gas company. 
(Code 1972, § 26-36) 
Sec. 21-67. - Provision for meter connection. 
(a)  Duty of gas company. In connection with the piping of any structure or building for gas service, provision shall be made at the location designated by the gas company for connecting the gas meter. 
(b)  Drawings. The gas company shall furnish to each fitter applying for same, one copy of a drawing showing the dimensions for such meter connection and shall keep on file at its offices and available for inspection by fitters complete dimension drawings for same, and the fitter shall conform thereto. 
(c)  Stopcock, fittings, etc., on outlet side of meter. The stopcock on the meter riser and all fittings, pipe and appliances from the stopcock to and including a threaded connection on the outlet side of the meter shall be furnished and installed by the gas company and shall be and remain the property of the gas company. 
(Code 1972, § 26-37) 
Sec. 21-68. - Meters to be set, connected by gas company. 
    The gas meter will in all cases be connected by the gas company who may refuse to connect to gas piping which does not conform to this chapter. No other person shall connect, disconnect, adjust, alter or tamper with any gas meter, nor with the connection thereto. 
(Code 1972, § 26-38) 
Sec. 21-69. - Service line; installation from main to property line, from property line to meter. 
    The service line from the street main to the meter cock may be installed by the consumer, subject to the approval and inspection by the utility, or by the utility at the expense of the consumer. That portion of the service line from the main to the property line shall be and remain the gas company's property, but that portion of the service line from the property line to the meter cock shall be the property of the consumer, and the consumer shall reimburse the gas company for the construction thereof in accordance with an agreement to be made in advance of the construction thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 26-39) 
Secs. 21-70-21-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WATER AND SEWERAGE SYSTEM 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 21-91. - Application, permit to tap water, sewer mains. 
    No water or sewer mains shall be tapped unless application is made by the owner of the property, or by his authorized agent, according to the form prescribed by the water, sewerage and light commission. After the applicant has complied with this article, a permit will be issued to a plumber to make proper connections inside the premises for which an application was made. 
(Code 1972, § 26-53) 
Sec. 21-92. - Persons who may tap water or sewer mains. 
    No water or sewer mains, or distributing pipes, shall be tapped except by an authorized employee of the water, sewerage and light commission under the supervision of the superintendent. 
(Code 1972, § 26-54) 
Sec. 21-93. - Power to revoke permit to connect with water or sewer mains. 
    The water, sewerage and light commission shall have the power to revoke or annul any permit to connect with water or sewer mains, and no party interested shall have the right to claim damage in consequence of such permit being revoked or annulled. 
(Code 1972, § 26-55) 
Sec. 21-94. - Stopcock or cutoff between meter and building. 
(a)  A stop and waste cock or cutoff valve must be placed by the property owner between the building and meter, if permissible and possible, not nearer than 20 feet to or 40 feet away from the meter; such cock or valve to be under the control of the tenant or owner, to be used in case of break or other necessity when the pipe to be repaired can be cut off without the necessity of using the city's cutoff. 
(b)  If it becomes necessary for the city's stopcock to be cut off for purposes stated in subsection (a), the same shall be done only by legally authorized personnel of the water, sewerage and light commission, and the charge for cutting off and cutting on the water shall be that reasonable charge which shall be set by the water, sewerage and light commission. A duly licensed plumber may cut on or off water at the city's stopcock to an occupied building or dwelling only, provided the plumber notifies the water, sewerage and light commission prior to using the city's cutoff and further provided the plumber operates the city's cutoff pursuant to water, sewerage and light regulations. 
(Code 1972, § 26-56) 
Sec. 21-95. - Ownership of stopcock, box and meter, of pipe into premises. 
    The stopcock, box and meter at or near the curb are the property of the water, sewerage and light commission. The pipe from the property line or meter into the premises of the consumer are his property, and all plumbing and repairs to the same must be made at his expense. 
(Code 1972, § 26-57) 
Sec. 21-96. - Application prerequisite to use of water. 
    Water shall not be introduced into any premises without application having first been made at the water, sewerage and light commission office and granted officially. 
(Code 1972, § 26-58) 
Sec. 21-97. - Installation, use of meters. 
    Meters shall be attached to all premises wanting water service supply where city water mains are available and in use, and in no case shall two or more houses receive water through the same meter. It shall be unlawful for any person to run or extend water or sewer lines from one lot across lot lines on private property for the purpose of serving more than one house through any water meter without obtaining the approval of the superintendent. Meters shall be set on the sidewalk back of the curbline whenever this can be done, and when this is impracticable, at such locations as may be approved by the superintendent. No one but an authorized employee on the water, sewerage and light commission shall be allowed to install, remove or handle meters. 
(Code 1972, § 26-59) 
Sec. 21-98. - Meter changes by plumber. 
    A licensed plumber before making any meter changes, shall obtain a permit from the water, sewerage and light commission and must state plainly in his application the work to be done. This application must be made to the superintendent, who will issue the permit if the location is practicably accessible to a water or sewer line. Under no circumstances shall work be done without such permit. The plumber shall report all uses of water which may come to his notice that are contrary to the rules. 
(Code 1972, § 26-60) 
Sec. 21-99. - Turning water supply on or off. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone, unless authorized by the water, sewerage and light commission, to turn on or off water at meter, sidewalk or alley, anywhere city water lines are used to furnish water. A duly licensed plumber is authorized to turn on or off water at meter, sidewalk or alley to any occupied building or dwelling in the city, provided the plumber notifies the water, sewerage and light commission prior to turning on or off the water and further provided the plumber does so pursuant to water, sewerage and light regulations for turning on or off water at meters. 
(Code 1972, § 26-61) 
Sec. 21-100. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 00-17, § II, adopted June 20, 2000, amended the Code by repealing former § 21-100 in its entirety. Former § 21-100 pertained to use of water for certain purposes, and derived from the Code of 1972, § 26-63. 
Sec. 21-101. - Charges for water and sewer service. 
    Charges for the consumption and use of water and for sewer service shall be fixed by the water, sewerage and light commission. 
(Code 1972, § 26-64) 
Charter reference- Power of city to levy sewer service charges, etc., § 1.4(25). 
Sec. 21-102. - Interfering with distribution of water. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to injure or interfere with the public founts, hydrants, aqueduct, pipe, conduit, machinery or other property used or required for procuring and distributing water within the city, or between the city and the waterworks, or at the waterworks, or for any person maliciously and wilfully to divert the water, or any part thereof, from the waterworks or to corrupt or render the water impure or unwholesome. 
(Code 1972, § 26-66) 
Sec. 21-103. - Maintenance of water meters; charges when meter is out of repair. 
    After the purchase of the first water meter by the property owner, the city shall keep the same in repair, and replace it with a new one when necessary, without any further expense to the property owner. Should a meter become out of repair and fail to register or register improperly, the consumer shall be charged at the average daily consumption as had been shown by the meter when the same was in order. 
(Code 1972, § 26-67) 
Sec. 21-104. - Notice of amount of water account. 
    Notice shall be given to all water customers on a monthly basis of the respective amounts of their water accounts. 
(Code 1972, § 26-68) 
Sec. 21-105. - Buildings occupied by two or more tenants; responsibility for water charges. 
    When any building is occupied by two or more tenants using water through one meter, the owner of such building shall be liable for the payment of water used by such tenants. In case the owner of a building occupied by two or more tenants shall refuse to be liable for water used by the tenants, then each tenant shall be required to have a separate water meter installed. 
(Code 1972, § 26-69) 
Sec. 21-106. - Landlords, agents renting property; notice as to use of water required. 
    Landlords or their agents renting property shall in every case give the water, sewerage and light commission written notice of the renewal of the tenant, or of nonuse of water, and shall be liable for water charges until such notice is given. 
(Code 1972, § 26-70) 
Sec. 21-107. - Charge, payment for unauthorized use of water. 
    If water is used without the knowledge of the water, sewerage and light commission by any person and it should in any way come to their knowledge that water had been so used, a bill will be made against the premises for the time the water had been used, or the quantity shown by the meter to have been used, and water service shall be discontinued and not resumed until the bill is paid. 
(Code 1972, § 26-72) 
Sec. 21-108. - Watershed protection. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to carry on the business of a slaughterhouse or slaughter pen, or stockyard or stock pen on any ground in the city draining into the waterworks reservoir, or on any land held for the purpose of enabling the city to preserve the purity of such waterworks water. 
(Code 1972, § 26-74) 
Sec. 21-109. - Interfering with city sanitary sewer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to tap, interfere with or molest any city sanitary sewer. 
(Code 1972, § 26-75) 
Sec. 21-110. - Regulations for use of sewerage system. 
(a)  Use is permissive. The right to connect with and use the sanitary sewerage mains or system shall be permissive only and no person shall acquire any vested right to use such mains or system by prescription or long uninterrupted use of same. 
(b)  Permission revocable. Permission to any person to connect with and use the mains or system shall be subject to the right of the water, sewerage and light commission and/or the city council to revoke any such permission to any person at any time and for any cause in their discretion, that renders the revoking of such permission for the best interest of the city. 
(c)  Misuse. No person permitted to use the mains or system shall empty into the same any refuse water or matter that creates a nuisance, either at the source, at any point along such main, at the outflow thereof or on lands beyond the outflow, and if any person permitted to connect with and use such mains or system shall in connection with the use thereof, create a nuisance, the water, sewerage, and light commission or city council, or either, may, without notice, revoke the permit to such person, and if such person creates such nuisance or is suspected of creating such nuisance either of such authorities shall break the connection at the source thereof or at any point along such mains or system to prevent its use. 
(d)  Responsibilities of city. Permission shall be granted only on the express condition that if the use thereof creates a nuisance neither the water, sewerage and light commission nor the city council nor the city shall be required to extend its system to obviate the nuisance, or provide disposal plants to avoid the results of any such nuisance created by such person. Permission shall be granted only upon the agreement that neither the water, sewerage and light commission, the city council nor the city shall be liable for damage to any person whose permission to connect with and use such mains or system is revoked for any cause. 
(e)  Effect of pollution. After any applicant has connected with and is using the system or any part thereof for the purpose of caring for and disposing of any water that is mixed, polluted and/or contaminated with dyes, chemicals or any other things used in manufacture and complaint is made by any person that the outflow or discharge from the sanitary system of the city creates a nuisance, then the applicant shall discontinue the use of the system for the purpose of disposing of such water for a sufficient time for the city to determine whether the nuisance complained of is created by the use of the system for such purpose, and the applicant shall pay the cost incurred by the city to determine whether the applicant's use creates such nuisance, including any and all expense the city may incur to analyze the contents of the outflow or that may be paid to any expert to determine the origin of the nuisance complained of. 
(f)  Burden on system. Any permission to use the system shall be revoked if the use thereof becomes a burden to the system. 
(Code 1972, § 26-76) 
Sec. 21-111. - Pretreatment of industrial waste prior to discharge into sewerage system. 
    It shall be unlawful for any industrial or business establishment to discharge into the sewerage system of the city any industrial waste for treatment unless and until such waste shall have been pretreated by the industrial or business establishment in compliance with applicable state and federal laws and regulations and cleared for treatment by appropriate federal and state agencies. 
(Code 1972, § 26-77) 
Sec. 21-112. - Supervision of the installation of utility systems in new subdivisions and multifamily developments located in the city. 
(a)  Prior to the installation of any water or sewerage system (hereinafter referred to as "utility system") in any subdivision or multifamily development hereafter developed or constructed in the city, the plans for such system shall be submitted to the superintendent or inspector of the water, sewerage and light commission. Once the approval of the superintendent or inspector is obtained, the owner/developer of the proposed subdivision or multifamily development shall be permitted to begin construction of such utility system; provided, however, the developer and/or owner must either: 
(1)  Elect for the water, sewerage and light commission to supervise the construction of the utility system by requesting the commission to take charge of all facets of the construction project from the invitation for bids to the final approval, all on behalf of the owner/developer. If this alternative is selected, the following procedure shall be adhered to: 
a.  The owner/developer shall ask that the commission make an estimate of the total cost of the project; 
b.  Once such an estimate is obtained, the owner/developer will deposit in an escrow account approved by the commission an amount of funds sufficient to pay such estimated costs; 
c.  The commission will then publicly advertise for bids for the construction of such project; 
d.  When the bids are received, the commission shall select the lowest and best bid; 
e.  If the estimated cost is not sufficient to pay the bid price selected, the owner/developer will deposit such additional funds into escrow as are necessary to cover the bid price and all other costs of construction including supervision, if any; 
f.  The bidder chosen will then be awarded the contract and will perform the construction of the project under the supervision of the commission until the utility system is installed in accordance with the approved plans and final approval of system is given by the commission; or 
(2)  Elect that the construction of the utility system will be done by a contractor selected, paid and supervised by the owner/developer, but with additional direct supervision by a representative of the water, sewerage and light commission, the total cost of which supervision shall be paid by the owner/developer to the commission. The owner/developer may elect this alternative (2) in lieu of alternative (1) prior to any of the steps enumerated in alternative (1) above, but shall pay all costs incurred by commission up to that point prior to being allowed to utilize this alternative (2). 
(b)  In either event, no person shall be allowed to occupy or inhabit subdivision or the multifamily development until such time as the final approval of the utility system as installed is given by the proper representative of the water, sewerage and light commission. 
(Code 1972, § 26-78) 
Sec. 21-113. - Floodproof design of water supply and sanitary sewerage systems. 
    Within areas determined by the city to be subject to periodic flooding, new and replacement water supply systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems. New and replacement sanitary sewerage systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems and discharges from the systems into floodwaters. 
(Code 1972, § 26-79) 
Sec. 21-114. - Backflow and cross connections prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause to be made or knowingly to allow to exist any cross connections for any purpose whatsoever between any water line of the water, sewerage and light commission and any other line or source of supply or potential supply, or to cause to be made, or knowingly to allow to exist any connection between any water line of the water, sewerage and light commission and any other piping system capable of transporting liquid emanating from any other source of supply. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause to be made or to knowingly allow to exist any connection or cross connection between any water line of the water, sewerage and light commission and any storage tank, standpipe, reservoir, pool or any other tank or container which contains, or which may be subject to contamination of any kind. No person shall cause or knowingly allow to exist the passage of any water line supplied by the water, sewerage and light commission through or into any tank, storage tank, standpipe, reservoir, pool, vat, or any other tank or container that may contain, or which may be subject to contamination of any kind. No water connection shall be made by any person unless it be in such manner as to prevent back siphoning into the water supply system of the water, sewerage and light commission. 
(b)  Prior to the commencement of work on any pipe, connection or plumbing to any system to which water is supplied from the supply of the water, sewerage and light commission, plans must be presented to and approved by the building department of the city, and by the water, sewerage and light commission. Such plans must include provisions for a backflow preventer. 
(c)  Any person whose premises now supplied with water from the water, sewerage and light commission in which there exists a condition in violation of this section shall correct such condition within the time designated by the building department of the city and the water, sewerage and light commission. If the violation consists of water lines passing through or into tanks, storage tanks, standpipes, reservoirs, pools, vats or any other tank or container that may contain, or which may be subject to contamination of any kind, such condition shall be corrected by causing such line to be removed from such tank, storage tank, standpipe, reservoir, pool, vat or any other tank or container. 
(d)  Any person whose premises are supplied with water from the water, sewerage and light commission shall, at the request of the water, sewerage and light commission and the building department of the city, install or cause to be installed at their own expense a back-flow preventer approved by American Water Works Association and water, sewerage and light commission. 
(e)  Any person who neglects or refuses to comply with any of the provisions of this section shall be given notice in writing by the building department of the city and the water, sewerage and light commission that unless full compliance of this section as described in such notice is made within ten days from date therein, the water, sewerage and light commission may discontinue its water supply to the premises covered by such notice. 
(f)  Any person whose meter is connected with a backflow preventer shall have such device inspected each 12 months following installation, and shall furnish the water, sewerage and light commission and the building department of the city with proof in writing that the device is in proper working order. Failure to do so shall be sufficient reason for the water, sewerage and light commission to discontinue service until such test is completed. All costs in connection with testing and repair shall be the responsibility of the customer. 
(g)  The building department of the city and the water, sewerage and light commission shall have the authority to go upon the premises of any person to inspect any and all plumbing or piping to check for violations of this section. 
(h)  Any person violating this section shall be liable to the penalties imposed by section 1-14. 
(i)  Any plumber who violates any subsection of this section by his work shall be subject to having his license revoked. 
(Code 1972, § 26-80) 
Sec. 21-115. - Use of phosphates. 
(a)  Declaration of policy. O.C.G.A. § 12-5-27.1 provides that whenever a local governmental entity is required by the environmental protection division to reduce phosphorus in its wastewater being discharged into the waters of the state, such local government entity shall pass an ordinance mandating the retail sale of low phosphorus household laundry detergent as part of its phosphorus reduction process. It is hereby declared to be the public policy of the city to encourage the use of clean, phosphate-free household laundry detergents and to prohibit the sale of household laundry detergents which contain more than 0.5 percent phosphorus by weight. The city finds that such use and sale will be a cost-effective way to reduce the amount of phosphorus in wastewater discharge so as to protect the state's rivers and lakes downstream and promote health, safety and welfare, prevent injury to human health, plant and animal life and property. It is vital to the health, well-being and welfare of present and future inhabitants of the city that these sources be protected against contamination and pollution. 
(b)  Definitions. The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this section: 
(1)  Household laundry detergent means a laundering cleaning compound in liquid, bar, spray, tablets, flake, powder, or other form used for domestic clothes cleaning purposes. The term "household laundry detergent" shall not mean: 
a.  A dishwashing compound, household cleaner, metal cleaner, degreasing compound, commercial cleaner, industrial cleaner or other substance that is intended to be used for nonlaundry cleaning purposes. 
b.  A detergent used in dairy, beverage or food processing cleaning equipment. 
c.  A phosphorus acid product, including a sanitizer, brightener, acid cleaner or metal conditioner. 
d.  A detergent used in hospitals, veterinary hospitals or clinics or health care facilities or in agricultural production. 
e.  A detergent used by industry for metal cleaning or conditioning. 
f.  A detergent manufactured, stored or distributed for use or sale outside of the state. 
g.  A detergent used in any laboratory, including a biological laboratory, research facility, chemical laboratory and engineering laboratory. 
h.  A detergent used in a commercial laundry that provides laundry services for hospital, health care facilities, or veterinary hospital. 
(2)  Phosphorus means elemental phosphorus. 
(c)  Prohibition. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell at the retail level a household laundry detergent which contains greater than 0.5 percent phosphorus by weight and is intended to be used for domestic clothes cleaning purposes. 
(d)  Penalties for violation. Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be subject to a fine as provided in section 1-14. Each sales transaction shall constitute a separate offense. 
(e)  Civil remedy. In addition to the penalty provided in subsection (d) of this section, the city may maintain an action or proceeding in any court of competent jurisdiction to compel compliance with or restrain any violation of this section. 
(f)  Right to damages. Nothing in this section shall be construed to abridge, limit or otherwise impair the right to any person to damages or other relief on account of injuries to persons or property arising out of a violation of this section and to maintain any action or other appropriate proceeding thereof. 
(Ord. No. 8-90, § 26-81, 1-22-90) 
Sec. 21-116. - Fat, oils, and grease management. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Food service facility or facility, means any food service facility which prepares and/or packages food or beverages for sale or consumption, on or off site, with the exception of private residences. Food service facilities shall include, but are not limited to; food courts, food manufacturers, food packagers, restaurants, grocery stores, bakeries, lounges, hospitals, hotels, nursing homes, churches, schools and all other food service facilities not listed above. 
    Garbage disposal, means a device which shreds or grinds up waste materials into smaller portions for discharge into the city's wastewater collection system. 
    GMP official, means a member of the staff of Newnan Utilities grease management program, appointed by the GMP official of public utilities to implement a grease management program. 
    Gray water, means all of the liquid contained in a grease interceptor that lies below the floating grease layer and above the food solids layer. 
    Grease, means a material either liquid or solid, composed primarily of fat, oil and grease from animal or vegetable sources. The terms "fats oils and grease" (FOG), "oil and grease" or "oil and grease substances" shall all be included within this definition. 
    Grease hauler, means a person who collects the contents of a grease interceptor or trap and transports it to an approved recycling or disposal facility. A grease hauler may also provide other services to a food service facility related to grease interceptor maintenance. 
    Grease interceptor, means a device located underground and outside of a food service facility designed to collect, contain or remove food wastes and grease from the wastestream while allowing the balance of the liquid waste to discharge to the wastewater collection system by gravity. Interceptors shall have at least two inspection hatch on the top surface to facilitate inspection, cleaning and maintenance by a grease hauler. Grease interceptors will be a minimum of 1,500 gallons. 
    Grease trap, means a device located in a food service facility or under a sink designed to collect, contain or remove food wastes and grease from the wastestream while allowing the balance of the liquid waste to discharge to the wastewater collection system by gravity. Traps shall have a removable lid on the top surface to facilitate inspection, cleaning and maintenance. 
(b)  Purpose and applicability. 
(1)  Purpose. This section establishes uniform registration, maintenance and monitoring requirements for controlling the discharge of grease from food service facilities discharging into the city's wastewater collection system and commercial grease haulers. The objectives of this section are: 
a.  To prevent the introduction of excessive amounts of grease into the city's wastewater collection system; 
b.  To prevent clogging or blocking of the city's sewer lines due to grease buildup causing backup and flooding of streets, residences and commercial buildings, resulting in potential liability to the city; 
c.  To implement a procedure to recover the costs incurred in cleaning and maintaining sewer lines and disposing of grease blockages; 
d.  To implement a procedure to recover costs for any liability incurred by the city for damage caused by grease blockages resulting in the flooding of streets, residences or commercial buildings; and 
e.  To establish fees for the recovery of costs resulting from the program established herein. 
(2)  Applicability. This shall apply to all food service facilities that are connected to the Newnan Utilities collection system. 
(c)  Grease traps and interceptors. 
(1)  Requirements. All food service facilities are required to have a grease trap or grease interceptor. The requirements in this section are in addition to any applicable requirements of the Georgia Plumbing Code and the Standard Plumbing Code. 
a.  New facilities. On or after the effective date of this section, food service facilities which are newly proposed or constructed, or existing facilities which will be expanded or renovated to include a food service facility, where such facility did not previously exist, shall be required to install, operate and maintain a grease interceptor or grease trap according to the requirements contained in this section. Grease interceptors or grease traps shall be installed prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. 
b.  Existing facilities. For the purposes of sizing and installation of grease interceptors, all food service facilities existing within the city prior to the effective date of this section shall be permitted to operate and maintain existing grease interceptors or grease traps provided their grease interceptors or grease traps are in efficient operating condition. 
On or after the effective date of this section, the city may require an existing food service facility to install, operate and maintain a new grease interceptor or trap that complies with the requirements of this section or to modify or repair any noncompliant plumbing or existing interceptor or trap within 90 days of written notification by the city when any one or more of the following conditions exist. 
1.  The facility is found to be contributing oils and grease in quantities sufficient to cause line stoppages or necessitate increased maintenance on the wastewater collection system. 
2.  The facility does not have a grease interceptor or trap. 
3.  The facility has an undersized, irreparable or defective grease interceptor or trap. 
4.  Remodeling of the food preparation or kitchen waste plumbing system is performed which requires a plumbing permit to be issued by the city. 
5.  The existing facility is sold or undergoes a change of ownership. 
6.  The existing facility does not have plumbing connections to a grease interceptor or trap in compliance with the requirements of this section. 
(2)  Plumbing connections. Grease interceptors or traps shall be located in the food service facility's lateral sewer line between all fixtures which may introduce grease into the sewer system and the connection to the city's wastewater collection system. Such fixtures shall include but not be limited to, sinks, dishwashers, garbage disposals, automatic hood wash units, floor drains in food preparation and storage areas, and any other fixture which is determined to be a potential source of grease. Wastewater from sanitary facilities and other similar fixtures shall not be introduced into the grease interceptor or trap under any circumstances. 
(3)  Grease traps. Grease traps shall be prohibited for new food service facilities, except for those facilities where inadequate space is available for the installation of a grease interceptor. Approval of the installation of a grease trap instead of a grease interceptor at a new food service facility shall meet the following criteria: 
a.  Trap design and location. Grease traps shall conform to the standards in the state plumbing code. Grease traps shall be installed in strict accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. Grease traps shall be equipped with a cover that can be opened for inspection and sampling and a mechanism for a secure closing. 
b.  Trap capacity. The capacity of the grease trap shall be related to the flow rate as indicated in Table 1 and the appendix of the PDI Standards G101 document. 
c.  Flow-through rate. Flow-through rates shall be calculated in accordance with the procedures in the PDI Standard G101. 
d.  Flow control device. Grease traps shall be equipped with a device to control the rate of flow through the unit. The rate of flow shall not exceed the manufacturers rated capacity recommended in gallons per minute for the unit. 
e.  Venting. The flow-control device and the grease trap shall be vented in accordance with the state plumbing code current edition. The vent shall terminate not less than six inches above the flood-rim level or in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. 
f.  Inspection, cleaning and maintenance. Newnan Utilities will be responsible for inspection and cleaning of grease traps. This will be performed at a frequency deemed appropriate by representatives of Newnan Utilities. All repairs and maintenance of grease traps are the responsibility of the owner. A written notice to repair will be issued by Newnan Utilities. Once this notice has been issued the owner has 30 days to complete repairs. 
g.  Inspection. Grease traps shall be inspected by Newnan Utilities as necessary to assure proper efficiency of the grease trap is being achieved. 
h.  Repairs. The food service facility shall be responsible for the cost and scheduling of all repairs to its grease trap(s). Repairs required by a GMP official shall be completed within 30 calendar days after the date of written notice of required repairs is received by the facility, unless the city approves in writing of a different schedule. 
i.  Disposal. Grease and solid materials removed from a grease trap shall be disposed of in the solid waste disposal system. 
j.  Location. Grease traps must be located at the furthest possible point from the sink in order for the trap to work at a high degree of efficiency. 
(4)  Grease interceptors. Grease interceptors shall be installed at all new food service facilities except where physical space is limited. All new and existing grease interceptors shall meet the following criteria: 
a.  Interceptor design and location. Grease interceptors shall have a minimum of two compartments and shall be capable of separation and retention of grease and storage of settled solids. Interceptor design shall conform with the requirements of the state plumbing code. A control manhole over each compartment for monitoring purposes shall be required and installed at the owner/operator's sole expense. Covers shall have a gas tight fit. The grease interceptor shall be designed, constructed and installed for adequate load-bearing capacity. Flow control devices shall be required where the water flow through the interceptor may exceed its rated flow. Interceptors shall be installed in a location outside of the building which provides easy access at all times for inspections, cleaning and proper maintenance, including pumping. 
b.  Interceptor capacity. The owner/operator of the facility shall furnish definite and complete information on the facility as set forth herein. The owner/operator shall be responsible for the accuracy thereof. If the size of the initially installed grease interceptor fails, in Newnan Utilities' opinion, to adequately perform, the owner/operator shall install a grease interceptor which in Newnan Utilities opinion will adequately perform. Grease interceptor capacity calculations shall then be performed by Newnan Utilities based on size and type of operation according to the state plumbing code. Minimum capacity of any one unit shall be 750 gallons. Where sufficient capacity cannot be achieved with a single unit, installation of grease interceptors in series is required. Interceptor capacity calculations shall be performed by the GMP official prior to the installation of the interceptor(s). The capacity of the grease interceptor required for food manufacturing or processing facilities which are not covered by the state plumbing code shall be approved by the GMP official according to the mass and type of food prepared, the wastewater volume produced from food preparation or manufacture, total hours of operation per day and a load factor depending on the installed equipment. 
Grease interceptor sizing formula: 
(# of seats)(gallons of water/meal)(Hours/2)(loading factor) 
# of seats: The total seating capacity of the restaurant gallons of water/meal: estimated # of gallons of water used per meal served. 
5 if full service restaurant 
2 if take out restaurant only 
Hours/2: # of hours restaurant is open for business divided by 2. 
Loading factor: 
1.25: Interstate highway 
1.0: Freeways and recreational areas 
0.8: Main highway 
0.5: Other roads/streets 
c.  Inspection, pumping and maintenance. Newnan Utilities shall be responsible for pumping, cleaning, and inspection of all grease interceptors. The food service facility will be responsible for installation and repairs of grease interceptors. Pumping services shall include the initial complete removal of all contents, including floating materials, wastewater and bottom sludges and solids from the interceptor. 
Waste haulers must have written permission from Newnan Utilities, in order to return any gray water back into the grease interceptor. This permission will be granted on a case by case basis and will depend upon the methods by which the solids and grease are separated in order to assure that clear water is the only material returned to the grease interceptor. 
d.  Interceptor pumping frequency. Each facilities' grease interceptor will be pumped at least once every 12 weeks. Newnan Utilities also has the right to pump a facilities' grease interceptor more frequently pumping if Newnan Utilities determines it to be necessary or prudent. 
e.  Variance procedure. If a food service facility determines that pumping once every 12 weeks is excessive then the facility may make written application for a variance from the above described pumping schedule. 
1.  The food service facility will submit an application on a form provided by Newnan Utilities. 
2.  The food service facility will also be required to pay a variance fee of $300.00 plus any sampling done by Newnan Utilities. 
3.  At the time which the grease interceptor is due to be pumped a representative of Newnan Utilities will collect a sample from the discharge point of the grease interceptor. After the sample is collected it will be analyzed for fats, oils, and grease content by a laboratory chosen by Newnan Utilities. 
4.  For the variance to be considered, the sample must show a fats, oils, and grease content of less than 100 mg/l. If the sample does show a level below this then a sample will be taken once a week until the sample exceeds the 100 mg/l mark established. Thus the time elapsed between the last pumping and the time at which the sample exceeds the above mentioned mark will then be the frequency at which that particular trap is pumped. 
5.  If at any time the food service facility changes ownership or does any type of renovation the schedule will revert to the original schedule established by Newnan Utilities. 
6.  If the initial sample taken from a grease interceptor is not below the 100 mg/l mark then the variance will not be considered. 
f.  Inspection. Grease interceptors shall be inspected by a GMP official as necessary. 
g.  Repairs. Each food service facility shall be responsible for the cost and scheduling of all repairs to its grease interceptor(s). Repairs required by a GMP official shall be corrected within 30 calendar days after the date a written notice requiring the repairs is received by the facility or unless notice from Newnan Utilities establishes a different compliance date. 
h.  Disposal. Wastes removed from each grease interceptor shall be disposed of at a facility permitted by the State of Georgia Environmental Protection Chapter of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources to receive such wastes or at a location designated by Newnan Utilities for such purposes. Neither grease or solid materials removed from interceptors shall be returned to any grease interceptor, private sewer line or to any portion of Newnan Utilities wastewater collection system or water reclamation facilities without prior written permission GMP official. 
i.  Interceptor additives. Any chemicals, enzymes, emulsifiers, live bacteria or other grease cutters or additives are not permitted by Newnan Utilities unless authorized by a GMP official. MSDS sheets and any other applicable information concerning the composition, frequency of use and mode of action of the proposed additive shall be sent to the city together with a written statement outlining the proposed use of the additive(s). Based upon the information received and any other information solicited from the potential user or supplier, the city shall permit or deny the use of the additive in writing. Permission to use any specific additive may be withdrawn by the city at any time. 
j.  Alternative grease removal devices or technologies. Alternative devices and technologies such as automatic grease removal systems shall be subject to written approval by a GMP official prior to installation. Approval of the device shall be based on demonstrated (proven) removal efficiencies and reliability of operation. The city may approve these types of devices depending on manufacturer's specifications on a case by case basis. 
(d)  Food service facility application procedure. 
(1)  Application form. Newnan Utilities shall provide an registration form for all food service facilities. The appropriate form shall be sent to all food service facilities identified by Newnan Utilities. All food service facilities identified by Newnan Utilities shall submit a completed registration form to Newnan Utilities at the address shown on the form within 30 calendar days of receipt of the form. Each application form submitted shall include the following information: 
(2)  Entry. Each food service facility shall allow the GMP official and other duly authorized employees or agents of Newnan Utilities bearing proper credentials and identifications access at all reasonable times to all parts of the premises for the purpose of inspection, observation, records examination, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of this section. The refusal of any food service facility to allow the GMP official entry to or upon the facility's premises for purposes of inspection, sampling effluents or inspecting and copying records or performing such other duties as shall be required by this section shall constitute a violation of this section. The GMP official may seek a warrant or use such other legal procedures as may be advisable and reasonably necessary to discharge his duties pursuant to this section. 
(3)  Inspection. All food service facilities shall be inspected as follows: 
a.  Inspections. The GMP official shall inspect food service facilities on both a scheduled and unscheduled basis. If any deficiencies are recorded by the GMP official during an inspection, the GMP official shall provide the food service facility a written notice to correct the deficiency within 30 calendar days, and a tentative date for a first reinspection. 
b.  Re-inspections. The GMP official shall re-inspect food service facilities which received deficiency notices after the original inspection. The GMP official shall inspect any repairs or other deficiencies and shall provide written notice of compliance or noncompliance as the case may be. In the event that the food service facility has returned to compliance with all of the deficiencies, there shall be no charge for the re-inspection. 
In the event of continuing noncompliance, successive re-inspections will be scheduled and appropriate fees shall be charged to the food service facility concerned for the first and all successive re-inspections. A first re-inspection shall be performed after a minimum of 30 calendar days have elapsed to allow for corrective action by the food service facility to be completed. 
(4)  Monitoring. The city shall have the right to sample and analyze the wastewater from any food service facility at any time to determine levels of grease contained within a facilities discharge. 
(e)  Grease haulers. 
(1)  Spill reporting. Any accident, spill, or other discharge of grease or gray water which occurs within the city shall be reported to Newnan Utilities by the grease hauler as soon as possible but not longer than 24 hours after the incident. The grease hauler shall comply with all procedures contained in federal, state and local regulations. The grease hauler shall be responsible for all clean-up procedures and costs. 
(2)  Record keeping. Grease haulers shall retain and make available for inspection and copying, all records related to grease interceptor pumping and grease disposal from businesses connected to Newnan Utilities wastewater collection service system. These records shall remain available for a period of at least three years. Newnan Utilities may require additional record keeping and reporting, as necessary, to ensure compliance with the terms of this section. 
(3)  Vehicle inspection. Grease haulers shall permit the city to inspect grease hauler's registered vehicles. 
(f)  Fees. 
(1)  Fees and billing. The fees provided for in this section are separate and distinct from all other fees chargeable by the city. All fees shall become immediately due and owing to the city upon receipt of invoice(s) for rendition of services or expenditure by the city and shall become delinquent if not fully paid within 45 days after receipt. Any delinquent amount shall be subject to a late charge of 15 percent. Fees applicable to this section are as follows: 
a.  Food service facility registration. A fee of $100.00 will be charged to all food service facilities discharging into Newnan Utilities collection system upon completion of the food service facility registration form. 
b.  Variance fee. A food service facility applying for a variance shall submit an application fee of $300.00. 
c.  Failure to repair fee. Any food service facility failing to adhere to repair request within the allotted 30 days will be charged $50.00 per day over and beyond 30 days. 
d.  Pumping fees. Facilities shall be charged $0.23 per gallon pumped and a $75.00 entry fee for pumping traps/interceptors located inside a facility. 
e.  All fees provided for herein may be adjusted by the city water, sewerage and light commission as it deems to be appropriate. 
(g)  Legal proceedings. 
(1)  Search warrant. Newnan Utilities, through the city attorney may seek to obtain a search warrant from the appropriate authority to gain access to a food service facility for the purposes of inspection and monitoring if such lawful entry has previously been denied by the food service facility. 
(2)  Injunctive and other relief. The city, through the city attorney, may file a petition in the name of the city in the municipal court, the superior court of the county or such other courts as may have jurisdiction seeking the issuance of an injunction, damages, or other appropriate relief to enforce the provisions of this section or other applicable law or regulation. Suit may be brought to recover any and all damages suffered by the city as a result of any action or inaction of any person who causes or suffers damage to occur to the city's wastewater collection system, or for any other expense, loss or damage of any kind or nature suffered by the city. 
(3)  Criminal mischief. No person shall maliciously, willfully or deliberately break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part Newnan Utilities sewer system or utilities department. Any person violating this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under charge of destruction of public property. 
(4)  Citations. Violators of the provisions of this section shall be subject to be issued a citation to appear in the city municipal court to answer to the charge. 
(5)  Remedies nonexclusive. The remedies provided for in this section are not mutually exclusive. The GMP official may take any, all, or any combination of these actions against a noncompliance person. 
(h)  Penalties-Falsifying information. Any person who knowingly makes any false statements, representation or certification in any application, record, report, plan or other document filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this section, or who falsifies, tampers with or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device or method required under this section or shall violate any other provision of this section, shall be subject to be issued a citation to appear in the city municipal court and shall, upon conviction, be subject to a penalty in an amount not to exceed $500.00 or by imprisonment for not more than six months, or by both. Each day on which a violation shall occur or continue shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. 
(i)  Administrative enforcement and abatement. 
(1)  Service revocation. Any services provided by Newnan Utilities may be suspended for the following reasons: 
a.  Falsification of any information submitted as part of the registration. 
b.  Failure to comply with any requirements or regulations concerning discharges to the Newnan Utilities wastewater collection system. 
c.  Failure to comply with any requirements or regulations concerning grease interceptors. 
d.  Failure to pay required fees, or any assessed surcharges in a timely manner. 
(Ord. No. 03-22, § I, 7-22-03) 
Secs. 21-117-21-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SEWERAGE IMPACT FEE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 01-07, § 1, adopted February 27, 2001, amended the Code by repealing former div. 2, §§ 21-126-21-138, and added a new div. 2, §§ 21-126-21-141, to read as herein set out. Former div. 2 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 9-89, adopted February 28, 1989. 

Sec. 21-126. - Short title, authority and applicability. 
(a)  This division shall be known and may be cited as the "Sewer Impact Fee Ordinance of the City of Newnan, Georgia." 
(b)  The city has the authority to adopt this division pursuant to Article IX, Section II, Paragraph IV, of the Constitution of the State of Georgia, and O.C.G.A. tit. 36, ch. 71. 
(c)  This division shall apply to the incorporated areas of the city. 
(Ord. No. 01-07, § 1, 2-27-01; Ord. No. 04-16, § 1, 9-14-04) 
Sec. 21-127. - Intents and purposes. 
(a)  This division is intended to implement and be consistent with the city comprehensive land use plan adopted in accordance with O.C.G.A. tit. 36, ch. 70 and pursuant to the minimum standards and procedures established by the department of community affairs. 
(b)  The purpose of this division is to regulate the use and development of land so as to assure that new development bears a proportionate share of the cost of system improvements necessary to provide wastewater treatment capacity and transmission and required facilities in the city. 
(Ord. No. 01-07, § 1, 2-27-01) 
Sec. 21-128. - Rules of construction. 
(a)  The provisions of this division shall be liberally construed so as to effectively carry out its purpose in the interest of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(b)  For the purposes of administration and enforcement of this division, unless otherwise stated in this division, the following rules of construction shall apply to the text of this division: 
(1)  In the case of any difference of meaning or implication between the text of this division and any caption, illustration, summary table, or illustrative table, the text shall control. 
(2)  The word "shall" is always mandatory and not discretionary; the word "may" is permissive. 
(3)  Words used in the present tense shall include the future; and words used in the singular number shall include the plural, and the plural the singular, unless the context clearly indicates the contrary. 
(4)  The phrase "used for" includes "arranged for," "designed for," "maintained for," or "occupied for." 
(5)  The word "person" includes an individual, a corporation, a partnership, an incorporated association, or any other similar entity. 
(6)  Unless the context clearly indicates the contrary, where a regulation involves two or more items, conditions, provisions or events connected by the conjunction "and," "or" or "either...or," the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows: 
a.  "And" indicates that all the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events shall apply. 
b.  "Or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions or events may apply singly or in any combination. 
c.  "Either...or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions or evens shall apply singly but not in combination. 
(7)  The word "includes" shall not limit a term to the specific example but is intended to extend its meaning to all other instances or circumstances of like, kind or character. 
(8)  The land-use types listed in section 21-131, computation of the amount of development impact fees, of this division shall have the same meaning as under the zoning ordinance. 
(9)  All wastewater terms used herein shall have the same meaning as in the city comprehensive land use plan and the development regulations unless otherwise indicated. 
(Ord. No. 01-07, § 1, 2-27-01) 
Sec. 21-129. - Definitions. 
    Building permit means the document issued by the city authorizing the construction, repair, alteration or addition to a structure, or authorizing the installation of a mobile home or recreational vehicle. For the purposes of this division, a building permit also means a change of use permit. 
    Capital improvement means an improvement with a useful life of ten years or more, by new construction or other action, which increases the wastewater treatment and transmission facilities of the city. 
    Capital improvements element means that portion of the comprehensive land use plan, which sets out projected needs for system improvements during a planning horizon established in the Newnan Comprehensive Land Use Plan, a schedule of capital improvements that will meet the anticipated need for system improvements, and a description of anticipated funding sources for each required improvement. 
    Commission means the water, sewerage and light commission of the city, the city water sewerage and light commission or city utilities. 
    Comprehensive plan means the city comprehensive land use plan as it is not adopted or as it may be further amended. 
    Developer means any person who engages in development activity and may include the owner, occupant, tenant or other entity responsible for payment of the development impact fee. 
    Development activity means any construction or expansion of a building, structure or use, any change in use of a building or structure, or any change in the use of land requiring the issuance of a building permit. 
    Development impact fee district means a geographic area identified by the city and described in section 21-137. 
    Development impact fee(s) means a payment of money imposed upon development activity as a condition of development approval to pay for a proportionate share of the cost of system improvements needed to serve new growth and development. 
    Encumber means to legally obligate by contract or otherwise commit to use by appropriation or other official act of the city. 
    Feepayor means that person who pays a development impact fee or his successor in interest with the right or entitlement to any refund of previously paid development impact fees which is required by this division and which has been expressly transferred or assigned to the successor in interest. In the absence of an express transfer or assignment of the right or entitlement to any refund of previously paid development impact fees, the right or entitlement shall be deemed "not to run with the land." 
    General manager means the general manager of the commission or his designee. 
    Individual fee calculation study means the economic documentation prepared by a feepayor to allow determination of the development impact fee other than by use of the fee schedule in section 21-131, computation of the amount of development impact fees, of this division as required by O.C.G.A. § 36-71-4(g). 
    Individual fee determination means the development impact fee determined by the general manager pursuant to an individual fee calculation study. 
    Level of service is a qualitative measure that represents the collective factors of wastewater treatment capacity and transmission services, taking into account the type, use, and capacity of existing facilities. 
    Living unit is any temporary or permanent unit utilized for or designed or intended to be utilized for human habitation. 
    Present value means the current value of past, present or future payments, or contributions or dedications of goods, services, materials, construction, or money. 
    Project or development project means a particular development on an identified parcel of land. 
    Project improvements means site improvements and facilities that are planned and designed to provide service for a particular development project and that are necessary for the use and convenience for the occupants or users of the project and are not system improvements. The character of the improvement shall control a determination of whether an improvement is a project improvement or system improvement and the physical location of the improvement on-site or off-site shall not be considered determinative of whether an improvement is a project improvement or a system improvement. If an improvement or facility provides or will provide more than incidental service or facilities capacity to persons other than users or occupants of a particular project, the improvement or facility is a system improvement and shall not be considered a project improvement. 
    Proportionate share means that portion of the cost of system improvements which is reasonably related to the demands and needs of a project. 
    System improvements means capital improvements that are implemented to provide wastewater treatment capacity and transmission and required facilities which are designed to provide service to the community at large, in contrast to project improvements. 
    System improvement costs means costs incurred to provide additional wastewater treatment capacity and transmission needed to serve new growth and development for planning, design and construction, land acquisition, land improvements, design and engineering related thereto, including the cost of constructing or reconstructing system improvements or facility expansions, including but not limited to the construction contract price, surveying and engineering fees, related land acquisition costs (including land purchases, court award and costs, attorney's fees, and expert witness fees) and expenses incurred for qualified staff or any qualified engineer, planner, architect, landscape architect, or financial consultant for preparing or updating the capital improvement element, and administrative costs equal to three percent of the total amount of the costs. System improvement costs shall also include projected interest charges and other finance costs if the development impact fees are to be used for the payment of principal and interest on bonds, notes, or other financial obligations issued by or on behalf of the city or commission to finance the capital improvement elements. Such costs do not include routine and periodic maintenance expenditures, personnel training, and other operating costs. 
(Ord. No. 01-07, § 1, 2-27-01) 
Sec. 21-130. - Imposition of development impact fee. 
(a)  Any person who engages in development activity shall pay a development impact fee in the manner and amount set forth in this article. 
(b)  No building permit for any activity requiring payment of a development impact fee pursuant to this article shall be issued by the city's building department unless and until the required development impact fee has been paid. 
(c)  The development impact fee shall be paid at the office of the general manager of the commission and evidence of such payment presented to the city's building department at the time application is made for a building permit. 
(Ord. No. 01-07, § 1, 2-27-01) 
Sec. 21-131. - Computation of the amount of development impact fees. 
(a)  At the option of the developer, the amount of the development impact fee may be determined by the schedule set forth below. 
DEVELOPMENT IMPACT FEE SCHEDULE 
NEWNAN, GEORGIA 
(1)  $12.00 per gallon of annual average daily use of treated water for all uses. 
(2)  In the case of change of use, redevelopment or modification of an existing use which requires the issuance of a building permit, the development impact fee shall be based upon the net increase in the fee for the new use as compared to the previous use. 
(b)  If a developer shall elect not to have the development impact fee determined according to paragraph (a) of this section, then pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 36-71-4(g) the developer may apply for individual fee determination. A developer applying for an individual fee determination shall prepare and submit to the general manager an individual fee calculation study for the development activity for which a building permit is sought. The individual fee calculation study shall follow the prescribed methodologies and formats for the study established by the general manager, or subject to approval of the general manager, such other professionally accepted methodology that identifies a project's proportionate share. This documentation shall be prepared and presented by qualified professionals in their respective fields and shall follow best professional practices and methodologies. 
The general manager shall provide the developer with the individual fee determination within 30 days after presentation of the individual fee calculation study. 
(c)  (1)  Upon application to the general manager, any person contemplating engaging in development activity requiring payment of a development impact fee may apply for and shall receive from the general manager a certification of the development impact fee schedule or a certification of an individual fee determination. 
(2)  Applications shall include the following information and items: 
a.  A full and complete description of the project; 
b.  A full and complete description of the proposed land use and development activity; 
c.  A complete set of final engineering drawings stamped by an engineer registered in the state; 
d.  A statement as to whether the applicant seeks a certification of the development impact fee schedule or a certification of the individual fee determination; and 
e.  If the applicant seeks a certification of an individual fee determination, an individual fee calculation study complying with the requirements of paragraph (b) of this section 21-131. 
(3)  The general manager shall provide an applicant with a written certification of the development impact fee schedule within a minimum of 15 business days after the general manager's receipt of a completed application. The fee schedule certified by the general manager shall establish the development impact fee schedule for the proposed development activity for a period of 180 days from the date of certification. The general manager shall provide the applicant with a written certification of an individual fee determination within 30 business days after receipt of a completed application. The individual fee determination certified by the general manager shall establish the development impact fee for the 180-day period immediately following the date of such certification. Notwithstanding the issuance of any such certification, any changes in or additions to the proposed development activity different from the development activity identified in the original application shall be subject to increased or additional development impact fees to the extent that such changes or additions require capital improvements or facilities expansions. The additional development impact fees shall be based upon the most current development impact fee schedule. 
(d)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, prior to engaging in development activity, and in addition to any other applicable requirements, the developer shall certify in writing to the general manager: 
(1)  A full and complete description of the project; 
(2)  A full and complete description of the proposed land use or uses; and 
(3)  A statement of the gross square footage applicable to each category of land use. 
Prior to the completion of the project, and as a condition to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy, the developer shall recertify in writing to the general manager the actual land use or uses of the project, and shall present an architect's certificate of the actual gross square footage attributable to each use. In the event that the actual land use or uses and/or the actual gross square footage applicable to the actual use or uses differs from that originally certified, and in the event that the impact fee applicable to the actual use or uses and/or gross square footage exceeds the impact fee previously paid, the developer shall be required to pay the amount of the excess as a condition to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. The amount of the excess shall be based upon the most current development impact fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. 01-07, § 1, 2-27-01) 
Sec. 21-132. - Payment of development impact fees. 
(a)  Any person required to pay development impact fees pursuant to this ordinance shall pay such fees to the general manager prior to the issuance of a building permit. 
(b)  All funds collected pursuant to this article shall be properly identified as development impact fees and promptly transferred for deposit into the development impact fee trust fund to be held as a separate account as determined in section 21-133, development impact fee trust fund established, of this article. Funds shall be used solely for the purpose specified in this article. 
(Ord. No. 01-07, § 1, 2-27-01) 
Sec. 21-133. - Use of funds. 
(a)  Funds collected from development fees shall be used for system improvements, by the commission for such purpose. No funds shall be used for periodic or routine maintenance or for any purpose not in accordance with the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 36-71-8. 
(b)  Development impact fees shall be used exclusively for system improvements in the development impact fee district in which the project for which the fees were paid is located. 
(c)  Funds shall be expended in the order in which they are collected. 
(d)  Each fiscal period the general manager of the commission shall present to the mayor and council an annual report describing the amount of development impact fees collected, encumbered and used during the preceding year. Monies, including any accrued interest, not assigned in any fiscal period shall be retained in the development impact fee trust fund until the next fiscal period except as provided in section 21-136, refunds, of this division. 
(e)  The commission shall be entitled to retain up to three percent of all development impact fees it collects as an administrative fee to offset the costs of administering this division. 
(f)  Development impact fees may be used for the payment of principal and interest on bonds, notes or other financial obligations issued by or on behalf of the commission to finance wastewater treatment, capacity and transmission facilities. 
(Ord. No. 01-07, § 1, 2-27-01) 
Sec. 21-134. - Credits. 
    Due to the nature of the development impact fees provided for in this division there are no credits available hereunder, specifically: 
(1)  Project improvements costs shall not be credited against the development impact fees due. 
(2)  No pre-ordinance credits shall be credited against the development impact fees due. 
(3)  No post-ordinance credits shall be credited against the development impact fees due. 
(4)  No system improvement credits shall be credited against the development impact fees due. 
(Ord. No. 01-07, § 1, 2-27-01) 
Sec. 21-135. - Exemptions. 
(a)  The following shall be exempted from payment of development impact fees: 
(1)  The replacement of a building, home or structure that was constructed prior to the adoption of a development impact fee or for which the correct development impact fee had been paid if constructed after the adoption of an impact fee or otherwise provided for, with a new building, home or structure of the same use. 
(2)  All or part of a particular project if and to the extent the commission determines such project to create extraordinary economic development and employment growth and provided that such project's proportionate share of system improvements is funded through a revenue source other than development impact fees. 
(3)  The construction of accessory buildings or structures on a lot where a building, home or structure was in place on the effective date of this division. 
(b)  A person claiming exemption(s) pursuant to paragraphs (a)(1), (2) or (3) above shall submit to the general manager information and documentation sufficient to permit the general manager to determine whether such exemption claimed is proper, and, if so, the extent of such exemption. A person seeking exemption under paragraph (a)(2) above shall submit to the commission information and documentation sufficient to permit the commission to determine whether such exemption claimed is proper, and, if so, the extent of such exemption. 
(c)  Exemptions must be applied for at the time of the application for a building permit. Any exemptions not so applied for shall be deemed waived. 
(Ord. No. 01-07, § 1, 2-27-01) 
Sec. 21-136. - Refunds. 
    Refunds of development impact fees shall be made only in the following instances and in the following manner: 
(1)  Upon application to the general manager by the feepayor, the commission shall refund 97 percent of the development impact fee paid if capacity is available and service is denied. The commission shall retain three percent of the fee paid as an administrative fee. 
(2)  a.  Upon application to the general manager by the feepayor, the commission shall refund 97 percent of the development impact fee paid and not expended or encumbered if the commission, after collecting the fee when service is not available, has failed to encumber the fee or commence construction within ten years from the date the development impact fee was paid. The commission shall retain three percent of the fee paid as an administrative fee. In determining whether development impact fees have been expended or encumbered, fees shall be considered encumbered on a first-in, first-out (FIFO) basis. 
b.  When the right to a refund exists due to a failure to encumber development impact fees, the commission shall provide written notice of entitlement to a refund to the feepayor who paid the development impact fee at the address shown on the application for development approval, or to a feepayor's successor in interest who has given the commission notice of the transfer or assignment of the right or entitlement to a refund and who has provided the commission a mailing address. The commission shall also publish such notice within 30 days after the expiration of the ten-year period from the date development impact fee was paid. The published notice shall contain the heading "notice of entitlement to development impact fee refund." 
(3)  A refund application shall be made to the general manager within one year from the date such refund becomes payable under paragraphs (1) and (2) of this section or within one year from the date of publication of the notice of entitlement of a refund under paragraph (2) of this section, whichever is later. Any refund not applied for within said time period shall be deemed waived. 
(4)  A refund application shall include information and documentation sufficient to permit the general manager to determine whether the refund claimed is proper, and, if so, the amount of such refund. 
(5)  A refund shall include a pro rata share of interest actually earned on the unused or excess development impact fee paid. 
(6)  All refunds shall be paid within 60 days after the general manager determines that such refund is due. 
(Ord. No. 01-07, § 1, 2-27-01) 
Sec. 21-137. - Development impact fee district established. 
    The development impact fee district hereby established shall include the incorporated areas of the city, as it now exists or as it is hereinafter amended. 
(Ord. No. 01-07, § 1, 2-27-01) 
Sec. 21-138. - Development impact fee trust funds established. 
(a)  There is hereby established one development impact fee trust fund for the development impact fee district described in section 21-137. 
(b)  Funds shall be deposited and maintained in an interest bearing account. Interest earned on funds shall be subject to all restrictions imposed by section 21-133, use of funds, of this division. 
(c)  Funds withdrawn from this account must be used in accordance with the provisions of section 21-133, use of funds, of this division. 
(Ord. No. 01-07, § 1, 2-27-01) 
Sec. 21-139. - Review of fee structure. 
    The development impact fees structure shall be reviewed by the commission annually; provided, however, the failure to review such structure shall not invalidate this division. 
(Ord. No. 01-07, § 1, 2-27-01) 
Sec. 21-140. - Administrative appeals.
